title: David Perdue
added: In Ocober 2020, Perdue made international news<ref>https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/republican-senator-perdue-s-mocking-mispronunciation-of-kamala-harris-name-earns-him-flak/story-SM63GwuX8pdgugIpc5dxPL.html</ref><ref>https://www.gulftoday.ae/news/2020/10/17/republican-senator-perdue-mocks-kamala-harris-name-at-trump-rally</ref><ref>https://www.smh.com.au/world/north-america/gop-senator-mispronounces-kamala-harris-name-at-trump-rally-20201017-p5660i.html</ref> after he appeared to mock Democratic Vice Presidential nominee [[Kamala Harris]] by repeatedly mispronouncing her name. In the campaign appearance, Perdue described Harris as "Kah-mah-la or Kah-ma-la or Kamamboamamla", a remark which drew laughter from the crowd. A spokesman for Perdue responded to the criticism with the statement "Senator Perdue simply mispronounced Senator Harris' name, and he didn't mean anything by it. He was making an argument against the radical socialist agenda that she and her endorsed candidate Jon Ossoff are pushing."<ref>https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2020/10/16/georgia-sen-perdue-faces-criticism-after-mocking-kamala-harris-name/3686517001/</ref><ref>https://www.cbsnews.com/news/david-perdue-republican-senator-criticized-for-repeatedly-mispronouncing-kamala-harris-name-at-rally/</ref><ref>https://www.cnn.com/2020/10/16/politics/david-perdue-kamala-harris/index.html</ref><ref>https://www.politico.com/news/2020/10/16/david-perdue-mocks-kamala-harris-name-429996</ref>

title: 1972 Democratic Party presidential primaries
added: [[Hubert Humphrey]] made another run at the nomination, in an era when previous nominees were considered legitimate contenders even after losing a general election ([[Adlai Stevenson II|Adlai Stevenson]] had been successful at being re-nominated by Democrats in 1956, and Nixon by the GOP in 1968).  He fell just short in delegates, despite winning the popular vote in the 24 states and the District of Columbia which held preference primary and caucus elections open to the rank and file Democratic voter.  His bid to contest the results of the California winner-take-all primary failed. Humphrey, like Senator [[Henry "Scoop" Jackson]], was considered the favorite of the party establishment after Muskie's withdrawal.

title: Julian Castro
added: During the third Democratic Presidential Debate, Castro was accused of ageism after he attacked [[Joe Biden]] in a heated exchange over health care plains with Castro taunting Biden saying "Are you forgetting what you just said two minutes ago", repeating it multiple times. Castro was rebuked for his remarked by various members of the candidates on stage including, [[Andrew Yang]], [[Amy Klobuchar]], and [[Pete Buttigieg]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.huffpost.com/entry/amy-klobuchar-julian-castro-donald-trump-debate_n_5d7b4920e4b077dcbd5bd20a|title= Amy Klobuchar Blasts Julián Castro For Sounding Like A Donald Trump Tweet In Debate|website= [[Huffington Post]]|accessdate= September 1, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2UWVO0Trd1c|title= ABC News Democratic Debate - WATCH THE FULL DEBATE (2019)|website= YouTube|accessdate= September 1, 2020}}</ref> Castro was widely criticized for what was seen as a "low blow", and with many accusing Castro of "bullying", and engaging in "[[ageism]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2019/09/13/activists-bristle-candidate-question-are-you-forgetting-what-you-said-two-minutes-ago/c8QBl2bCbF1zuAwUkAhNeP/story.htm|title= Anti-ageism activists bristle at Julián Castro’s question to Joe Biden: ‘Are you forgetting what you said 2 minutes ago?’|website= [[The Boston Globe]]|accessdate= September 1, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/former-obama-adviser-slams-julian-castro-for-ageist-comment|title= Former Obama adviser slams Julián Castro for 'ageist' comment|website= [[The Washington Examiner]]|accessdate= September 1, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://theweek.com/speedreads/864753/msnbcs-joe-scarborough-bashes-julin-castro-cheap-shot-bidens-memory|title= MSNBC's Joe Scarborough bashes Julián Castro for 'cheap shot' at Biden's memory|website= The Week|accessdate= September 1, 2020}}</ref> Journalist [[Gayle King]] saw the interaction as a "personal attack".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YfUZ1KzXsEM|title= Why Julian Castro may have made a mistake in targeting Joe Biden|website= [[YouTube]]|accessdate= September 1, 2020}}</ref> On ''[[The Late Show with Stephen Colbert]]'', [[Stephen Colbert]] described the interaction as both "mean and inaccurate",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eBszyJcmtbY|title= Jake Tapper Weighs In On Julián Castro's Attack On Joe Biden|website=[[YouTube]]|accessdate= September 1, 2020}}</ref> since Castro was factually incorrect in his attack against Biden according to [[Politifact]].<ref>{{cite plan falls flat|website= [[PolitiFact]]|accessdate= September 1, 2020}}</ref>

Many remarked that the exchange was the beginning of the end of Castro's presidential campaign.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/put-a-fork-in-it-the-campaign-is-over-the-view-slams-julian-castros-ageism|title= 'Put a fork in it, the campaign is over': The View slams Julián Castro's 'ageism'|website= The Washington Examiner|accessdate= September 1, 2020}}</ref> Castro has defended his attack against Biden saying he "wouldn't do it differently" and insisted he wasn't making fun of Biden."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2019/09/13/julian-castro-attack-joe-biden-1494504|title= 'I wouldn't do it differently': Castro defends his Biden attack|website= [[Politico]]|accessdate= September 1, 2020}}</ref>

title: Julian Castro
added: === San Antonio city council and mayor ===

In 2001, Castro was elected to the [[San Antonio City Council]], winning 61 percent of the vote against five challengers. At age 26 he was the youngest city councilman in San Antonio history, surpassing [[Henry Cisneros]], who won his council seat in 1975 at age 27. Castro represented District 7, a precinct on the city's west side with 115,000 residents. The population was 70 percent Hispanic and included a large number of senior citizens.<ref>{{cite web|last=Milanese|first=Marisa|title=Man on a Fast Track|url=http://alumni.stanford.edu/get/page/magazine/article/?article_id=39260|work=Stanford Magazine|accessdate=September 4, 2012|year=2001}}</ref> As a councilman from 2001 to 2005, he opposed a PGA-approved golf course and large-scale real estate development on the city's outer rim.<ref>{{cite web|last=Russell|first=Jan Jarboe|title=Alamo Heights|url=http://www.texasmonthly.com/2010-05-01/letterfromsanantonio.php|work=[[Texas Monthly]]|accessdate=September 4, 2012|date=May 1, 2010}}</ref>

Castro ran for mayor of San Antonio [[2005 San Antonio mayoral election|in 2005]] and was widely viewed as the front runner in a field that also included retired judge [[Phil Hardberger]] and conservative city councilman Carroll Schubert. He was defeated by approximately 4000 votes when Hardberger received 51.5% of the votes in the runoff.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/article/New-mayor-sets-high-goals-for-San-Antonio-1505990.php|title=New mayor sets high goals for San Antonio|date=June 9, 2005|work=Houston Chronicle|accessdate=September 5, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2005-06-15-san-antonio_x.htm | work=USA Today | first1=William M. | last1=Welch | title=San Antonio vote about issues | date=June 16, 2005}}</ref> Following his election defeat, Castro established his own law practice.<ref name="akroll">{{cite news|last1=Kroll|first1=Andy|title=The Power of Two: Inside the Rise of the Castro Brothers|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2015/01/the-power-of-two-inside-the-rise-of-the-castro-brothers/440034/|accessdate=March 31, 2016|publisher=The Atlantic|date=January 23, 2015}}</ref>

Castro ran for mayor of San Antonio again in 2009. Castro hired Christian Archer, who had run Hardberger's campaign in 2005, to run his own 2009 campaign.<ref name="akroll"/> Castro won the election on May 9, 2009 with 56.23% of the vote, his closest opponent being Trish DeBerry-Mejia.<ref>[http://www.bexar.org/el45A.HTM Bexar County, Texas Primary Runoff Election May 27, 2014 Statistics] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090510164400/http://www.bexar.org/el45A.HTM |date=May 10, 2009 }}, www.bexar.org</ref> He became the fifth Latino mayor in the history of San Antonio. He was the youngest mayor of a top-50 American city.<ref name="bio">{{cite web|url=http://www.sanantonio.gov/Mayor/castrobio.aspx|title=Mayor Julian Castro|work=Office of the Mayor|publisher=City of San Antonio|accessdate=April 23, 2014}}</ref> Castro easily won re-election in 2011 and 2013, receiving 82.9% of the vote in 2011<ref name="elections">[http://elections.bexar.org/reports/PDF/May%202011%20-%20Election%20Totals%20Report.HTM Bexar County, Texas Joint General & Special May 14, 2011] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305085428/http://elections.bexar.org/reports/PDF/May%202011%20-%20Election%20Totals%20Report.HTM |date=March 5, 2016 }}, www.bexar.org</ref> and 67% of the vote in 2013.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.citymayors.com/mayors/san-antonio-mayor-castro.html | title=Mayor of the Month for November 2012: Julian Castro Mayor of San Antonio, USA | publisher=[[CityMayors.com]] | date=May 21, 2013 | accessdate=May 23, 2014 | author=Baker, Brian}}</ref>

In 2010, Castro created SA2020, a community-wide visioning effort. It generated a list of goals created by the people of San Antonio based on their collective vision for San Antonio in the year 2020. SA2020 then became a nonprofit organization tasked with turning that vision into a reality.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sa2020.org/what-is-sa2020/|title=What is SA2020?|publisher=sa2020.org|accessdate=April 29, 2014}}</ref> Castro also established Cafe College in 2010, offering college guidance to San Antonio-area students. In 2012 he led a voter referendum to expand pre-kindergarten education.<ref name="bio" /> Castro persuaded two of the most prominent businessmen in San Antonio, [[Charles Butt]] and Joe Robles, to lead an effort to pass a $30 million sales tax to fund the pre-kindergarten education program.<ref name="akroll"/>

In March 2010, Castro was named to the [[World Economic Forum]]'s list of Young Global Leaders. Later that year, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine placed him on its "40 under 40" list of rising stars in American politics.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/blog/author/secretary-juli%C3%A1n-castro|title=Secretary Julián Castro|date=November 6, 2013|website=whitehouse.gov|language=en|access-date=December 26, 2018}}</ref>

Castro gained national attention in 2012 when he was the first Hispanic to deliver the [[keynote address]] at a [[2012 Democratic National Convention|Democratic National Convention]] in Charlotte, North Carolina.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/latino-mayor-to-keynote-dnc-convention/2012/07/31/gJQA3fpqNX_story.html | title=Julian Castro, Latino mayor of San Antonio, to keynote DNC convention | work=[[The Washington Post]] | date=July 31, 2012 | accessdate=August 1, 2012 | author=Henderson, Nia-Malika}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.politico.com/politico44/2012/07/julian-castro-to-deliver-dnc-keynote-130589.html | title=Julian Castro to deliver DNC keynote | work=[[Politico (newspaper)|Politico]] | date=July 31, 2012 | accessdate=August 1, 2012 | author=Tau, Byron}}</ref> Following the 2012 elections, Castro declined the position of [[United States Secretary of Transportation]], partly with an eye on running for governor of Texas after 2017.<ref name="akroll"/> However, in 2014, Castro accepted President [[Barack Obama]]'s offer of the position of [[United States Secretary of Housing and Urban Development]].<ref name="akroll"/> Castro resigned as mayor effective July 22, 2014, so that he could take up his duties in Washington. The San Antonio City Council elected councilmember [[Ivy Taylor]] to replace him.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ksat.com/content/pns/ksat/news/2014/07/22/councilmemberssaygoodbyetomayorcastro.html|title=Council members say goodbye to Julian Castro|last=Mendoza|first=Mariza|work=ABC KSAT 12|accessdate=July 23, 2014|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812084349/http://www.ksat.com/content/pns/ksat/news/2014/07/22/councilmemberssaygoodbyetomayorcastro.html|archivedate=August 12, 2014}}</ref>

title: Julian Castro
deleted: In 2007, Castro married Erica Lira, an elementary school teacher. title: Julian Castro
deleted: Castro<ref name="Reuters">{{cite news|last=MacLaggan|first=Corrie|title=For San Antonio mayor, reflections of American Dream in convention speech|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/09/03/us-usa-campaign-castro-idUSBRE8820A220120903|agency=Reuters|date=September 3, 2012|accessdate=September 3, 2012}}</ref> was born in [[San Antonio]], [[Texas]], the son of [[Rosie Castro|Maria "Rosie" Castro]] and Jessie Guzman.<ref>{{cite web|title=Interview with Julian Castro|url=http://digital.utsa.edu/cdm/ref/collection/p15125coll4/id/2016|publisher=[[University of Texas San Antonio]]|accessdate=August 31, 2012|date=November 9, 2005}}</ref> He is the [[identical twin]] brother of current [[United States House of Representatives|United States Representative]] [[Joaquin Castro]];<ref name="Reuters"/> Julián is one minute older than Joaquin: they were born at 2:40 and 2:41 am, respectively.<ref>{{cite web|title=Interview and quiz with Julian Castro|url=https://www.npr.org/2016/07/16/486031234/not-my-job-we-quiz-the-secretary-of-urban-development-on-urban-dictionary|date=July 16, 2016}}</ref>

Castro is of Mexican descent. His mother is a [[Chicano Movement|Chicana]] political activist who helped establish the Chicano political party [[Raza Unida Party|La Raza Unida]],<ref name="expnews1"/> and who ran for the [[San Antonio City Council]] in 1971.<ref name="Reuters" /> Castro once stated, "My mother is probably the biggest reason that my brother and I are in public service. Growing up, she would take us to a lot of rallies and organizational meetings and other things that are very boring for an 8-, 9-, 10-year-old".<ref>{{cite news|last=Fernandez|first=Manny|title=A Spotlight with Precedent Beckons a Mayor From Texas|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/03/us/politics/democratic-convention-spotlight-beckons-san-antonio-mayor.html?pagewanted=all|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=September 4, 2012|date=September 3, 2012}}</ref>  His father, Jessie Guzman, is a retired mathematics teacher and political activist. Never married, Rosie and Jessie separated when Castro and his brother were eight years old.<ref name="expnews1"/> Castro's Texan roots trace back to 1920, when his grandmother Victoria Castro joined extended family members there as a six-year-old orphan from northern Mexico.<ref name="Reuters"/>

title: Jon Tester
deleted: In June 2010, after giving a brief talk to a few attorneys at the offices of Thornton Law Firm in Boston, Tester received a total of $26,400 in campaign contributions from attendees.<ref name="ThorntonLaw">"[https://m.huffpost.com/us/entry/12708092 Millions in political donations fueled by matching bonuses at Boston law firm]". ''OpenSecrets Blog''. ''[[HuffPost]]''. October 29, 2016; updated October 30, 2017. Retrieved February 21, 2018.</ref><ref name="ThorntonLaw" />

''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]'' reported in April 2011 that Tester had "reaped a windfall in contributions from banks and lobbyists since introducing legislation to delay new regulations on debit-card swipe fees. Tester collected nearly $60,000 in contributions from credit card companies and other opponents of the proposed caps on swipe fees in the 17 days following the introduction of his bill." Much of the money came from executives at [[TCF Financial Corporation]], the lead plaintiff in a federal lawsuit to block the "[[Durbin amendment|Durbin rule]]," which would lower the fees that banks could charge retailers for debit-card transactions.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bolton|first1=Alexander|title=Swipe-fee opponents shower Sen. Tester with campaign contributions|url=http://thehill.com/business-a-lobbying/156911-swipe-fee-opponents-direct-campaign-money-to-tester|website=The Hill|accessdate=29 March 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025235238/http://thehill.com/business-a-lobbying/156911-swipe-fee-opponents-direct-campaign-money-to-tester|archive-date=October 25, 2012|url-status=live|df=mdy-all|date=April 20, 2011}}</ref>

In March 2012, the Montana GOP filed a complaint with the [[United States Senate Select Committee on Ethics|Senate Ethics Committee]] requesting an investigation into the actions of Tester and [[Max Baucus]]. The complaint cited a ''[[Politico]]'' report suggesting that Baucus' K Street connections were "warning clients against giving campaign contributions to Tester's Republican challenger Rep. Denny Rehberg". Tester denied any wrongdoing.<ref name="Investigation called for">{{cite news |first1=Anna |last1=Palmer |first2=Robin |last2=Bravender |title=Max Baucus, Jon Tester investigation called for by Montana GOP |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0312/73558.html |newspaper=Politico |date=March 2, 2012 |accessdate=October 6, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121120022008/http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0312/73558.html |archive-date=November 20, 2012 |url-status=live |df=mdy-all }}</ref>

Hiram Bond
deleted: Between 1879 and 1887 Judge Hiram Bond was also chief officer of a firm financed by investors from Boston led by [[Willard T. Sears]] and [[Moses Kimball]]. This firm had acquired rights to construct an urban transit system under the name [[Kings County Elevated Railway]]. This line was to run from the Fulton Ferry Terminal inland to the Queens border at City Line. Williard T. Sears was an architect who was able to add value designing the overpasses and bridges. Their package of rights and initial construction was eventually sold off to New York City investors led by Gen. [http://localhistory.morrisville.edu/sites/unitinfo/jourdan-158.html James Jourdan] due to the lack of support for the Bostonians by the local political leaders. Due to the persistence of Jourdan the project eventually got off the ground. The company directors besides Jourdan were [[Edward A. Abbott]], [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1890/08/02/103255739.pdf Henry J. Davison], [[Harvey Farrington]], [[Wendell Goodwin]], [[Henry J. Robinson]], [[James O. Sheldon]] and [[William A. Read]]. William A. Read was the financier whose company Read & Company later became [[Dillon, Read]]. Hiram's association with the KCER was so well known that it was commonly referred to as "Judge Bond's Road" according to the New York Times. During this period of time he was inducted into the [[The Players (New York City)|Players Club]] at [[Gramercy Park]] founded by actor [[Edwin Booth]] for actors and lovers of the theater. He was also a member of the [[Union League Club of New York]] and Lawyers Club of New York. During this time he maintained an office at 115 Broadway in Manhattan and a townhouse in Brooklyn.

title: 1930 Pennsylvania gubernatorial election
added: {{main|1926 United States Senate election in Pennsylvania}}

In 1926, Gifford Pinchot (then Governor of Pennsylvania) and [[William Scott Vare]] (U.S. Representative and boss of the powerful Philadelphia political machine) both challenged incumbent United States Senator [[George W. Pepper]] in the Republican primary. Pepper carried nearly every county in the state, but Vare the race won narrowly thanks to a 224,000 vote margin in [[Philadelphia County]].<ref>https://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=817591</ref> Vare went on to win the general election by a wider margin, again relying on a large margin from Philadelphia.

Pinchot, acting in his role as Governor, declined to certify the results of Vare's election. After a year-long review of the contested election, the Senate voted 58–22 not to seat Vare on the grounds that he had fraudulently and extravagantly financed his campaign against Pepper.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Weigley |first1=Russell Frank |title=Philadelphia: A 300 Year History |date=1982 |publisher=WW Norton & Company |location=New York - London |isbn=0-393-01610-2 |page=[https://archive.org/details/philadelphia300y00weig/page/584 584] |url=https://archive.org/details/philadelphia300y00weig |url-access=registration |accessdate=5 January 2019}}</ref> During the lengthy investigation, Vare suffered a stroke brought on by stress.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Keels |first1=Thomas H. |title=Contractor Bosses (1880s to 1930s) |url=https://philadelphiaencyclopedia.org/archive/contractor-bosses-1880s-to-1930s/ |website=www.philadelphiaencylopedia.org |accessdate=3 January 2019}}</ref>

title: Social media in the 2020 United States presidential election
Social media in the 2020 United States presidential election
added: With the constant advancement and innovation of technology, social media has been integrated into many individuals' day-to-day lives and has become an influential strategy as well as tool for many political campaigns. In recent years, specifically 2020, social media use has increased <ref>{{Cite web|last=NW|first=1615 L. St|last2=Suite 800Washington|last3=Inquiries|first3=DC 20036USA202-419-4300 {{!}} Main202-857-8562 {{!}} Fax202-419-4372 {{!}} Media|title=Demographics of Social Media Users and Adoption in the United States|url=https://www.pewresearch.org/internet/fact-sheet/social-media/|access-date=2020-10-07|website=Pew Research Center: Internet, Science & Tech|language=en-US}}</ref>and, as a result, the use of social media in politics has gained traction due to COVID-19 as the structure of many political campaigns leading up to the 2020 U.S. Presidential Election has turned virtual. Additionally, in the beginning stages of the COVID-19 pandemic, quarantine and stay-at-home orders<ref>{{Cite news|last=Mervosh|first=Sarah|last2=Lu|first2=Denise|last3=Swales|first3=Vanessa|date=2020-03-31|title=See Which States and Cities Have Told Residents to Stay at Home|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/coronavirus-stay-at-home-order.html|access-date=2020-10-07|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> were enforced across the United States as well as the world just as the U.S. Presidential Election was starting to reach the peak of campaigning. This created an increase in traffic on popular social media sites, including Facebook, TikTok, Instagram, and Snapchat, where there are many political ads and content circulating through social media feeds to promote people to vote for the respective candidates.

title: Social media in the 2020 United States presidential election
added: With the constant advancement and innovation of technology, social media has been integrated into many individuals' day-to-day lives and has become an influential strategy as well as tool for many political campaigns. In recent years, specifically 2020, social media use has increased <ref>{{Cite web|last=NW|first=1615 L. St|last2=Suite 800Washington|last3=Inquiries|first3=DC 20036USA202-419-4300 {{!}} Main202-857-8562 {{!}} Fax202-419-4372 {{!}} Media|title=Demographics of Social Media Users and Adoption in the United States|url=https://www.pewresearch.org/internet/fact-sheet/social-media/|access-date=2020-10-07|website=Pew Research Center: Internet, Science & Tech|language=en-US}}</ref>and, as a result, the use of social media in politics has gained traction due to COVID-19 as the structure of many political campaigns leading up to the 2020 U.S. Presidential Election has turned virtual. Additionally, in the beginning stages of the COVID-19 pandemic, quarantine and stay-at-home orders<ref>{{Cite news|last=Mervosh|first=Sarah|last2=Lu|first2=Denise|last3=Swales|first3=Vanessa|date=2020-03-31|title=See Which States and Cities Have Told Residents to Stay at Home|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/coronavirus-stay-at-home-order.html|access-date=2020-10-07|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> were enforced across the United States as well as the world just as the U.S. Presidential Election was starting to reach the peak of campaigning. This created an increase in traffic on popular social media sites, including Facebook, TikTok, Instagram, and Snapchat, where there are many political ads and content circulating through social media feeds to promote people to vote for the respective candidates.

As the Election Day for the 2020 U.S. Presidential Election gets closer, users on social media as well as candidates' campaigns are creating informational content to share to promote voting, regardless of in-person or mail-in voting. As previously mentioned, due to COVID-19, the increase of social media usage goes beyond the human craving to stay connected. In recent months, social media influencers have expressed political views and opinions on the upcoming election to encourage followers to vote. Additionally, due to the significant presence of Black Lives Matter movement and the handling of the COVID-19 pandemic by the Trump administration<ref>{{Cite web|title=How Black Lives Matter Could Reshape the 2020 Elections|url=https://time.com/5852534/black-lives-matter-2020-elections-voting/|access-date=2020-10-07|website=Time}}</ref> on social media, there is an urgency among eligible voters of all ages to cast a vote. Normally, voting in-person has been the traditional way for the U.S. to account for votes and conduct elections from primary to presidential elections for decades. However, recently, the 2020 U.S. Presidential Election will be mainly mail-in voting due to the new social distancing regulations for safety reasons during the COVID-19 pandemic. There will be some areas across the U.S. that will be hosting in-person voting that accommodate with COVID-19 safety regulations, such as social distancing and mandatory masks<ref>{{Cite web|title=Voting & COVID-19 - Vote.org|url=https://vote.org/covid-19|access-date=2020-10-07|website=vote.org|language=en-US}}</ref>. Overall, a majority of states across the United States will be mailing ballots to voters.

title: Shelley Moore Capito
added: In September 2020, with less than two months to the next presidential election, Capito supported an immediate vote on President Trump's nominee "to fill the Supreme Court vacancy" caused by the death of justice [[Ruth Bader Ginsburg]]. Previously in March 2016, Capito had taken the opposite position when facing President Obama's nominee, instead saying that a Supreme Court justice should not be considered during a presidential election year because "West Virginians and the American people should have the ability to weigh in at the ballot box".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Desjardins |first1=Lisa |title=What every Republican senator has said about filling a Supreme Court vacancy in an election year |url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/politics/what-every-republican-senator-has-said-about-filling-a-supreme-court-vacancy-in-an-election-year |accessdate=September 27, 2020 |work=[[PBS NewsHour]] |date=September 22, 2020}}</ref>

added: The Trump campaign ran video and pictorial advertisements on Facebook, YouTube, and Google, which falsely claimed that Joe Biden used a teleprompter during a April 2020 interview with James Corden. A teleprompter was seen on Biden's screen during that interview, but that was in fact Corden's teleprompter, not Biden's. The teleprompter was shared on the screens of Corden's interviewees via Zoom. The Trump campaign used the advertisement to claim that Biden "can't handle an interview", "can't handle presidency".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Dale |first1=Daniel |last2=O'Sullivan |first2=Donie |title=Fact check: Trump campaign runs ads falsely accusing Biden of using teleprompter on James Corden's show |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2020/09/24/politics/fact-check-biden-teleprompter-corden/index.html |accessdate=October 4, 2020 |work=[[CNN]] |date=September 25, 2020}}</ref>

title: Adam Laxalt
deleted: In 2017, Laxalt spoke at the NRA-ILA Leadership Forum in [[Atlanta, Georgia]]. In his speech, Laxalt criticized a bill passed by the Nevada Senate, comparing the bill to the film ''[[Minority Report (film)|Minority Report]]'', saying the bill was based in “a concept called pre-crime” and would allow the government to “take your second amendment rights based merely on suspicion or threat.”<ref>{{Citation|last=NRA|title=Adam Laxalt: 2017 NRA-ILA Leadership Forum|date=2017-04-28|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9K9LMeK56pw|access-date=2018-09-17}}</ref> In 2018, months after the [[National Rifle Association|NRA]] published a video calling greater adoption of these laws,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thenevadaindependent.com/article/laxalt-support-for-red-flag-gun-confiscation-laws-came-after-he-panned-similar-idea-in-2017-nra-speech|title=Laxalt support for 'Red Flag' gun confiscation laws came after he panned similar idea in 2017 NRA speech|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en}}</ref> Laxalt recommended that the legislature consider such a law in 2018, though he would not comment on if such laws were constitutional.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rgj.com/story/news/politics/2018/08/14/laxalt-makes-campaign-return-reno-vet-event/993181002/|title=Laxalt on his (sometimes icy) relationship with Sandoval: 'I hope to earn his vote'|work=Reno Gazette Journal|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en}}</ref> Laxalt was slated to speak at the NRA's 2018 annual conference until his photo was mysteriously removed from the event website, days after the [[Parkland shooting]], raising questions about what happened and whether he still planned to attend.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kkoh.com/2018/02/28/dems-say-laxalt-needs-to-reveal-interactions-with-the-nra/|title=Dems Say Laxalt Needs to Reveal Interactions With the NRA|date=2018-02-28|work=kkoh-am|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en-US}}</ref>

As attorney general, Laxalt signed Nevada onto at least four known lawsuits supporting abortion restrictions or pro-life entities in other states.<ref name="thenevadaindependent.com">{{Cite news|url=https://thenevadaindependent.com/article/laxalt-signs-nevada-on-to-support-alabama-abortion-restrictions-had-backed-similar-law-in-texas|title=Laxalt signs Nevada on to support Alabama abortion restrictions; had backed similar law in Texas|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en}}</ref> Laxalt signed onto two lawsuits supporting bans on the most commonly used second-trimester abortion procedure.<ref name="thenevadaindependent.com"/> Republican pro-choice Governor Brian Sandoval's office said it was not consulted before Laxalt signed Nevada onto the Texas abortion ban brief. In the Supreme Court case [[Whole Woman's Health v. Hellerstedt]], Laxalt signed an amicus brief<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scotusblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/15-274-bsac-IndOh21otherStates.pdf|title=Whole Woman's Health v. Hellerstedt|last=|first=|date=|website=SCOTUS Blog|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref> in support of a Texas [[TRAP law]] that imposed medically unnecessary restrictions on abortion clinics in order to curb the availability of abortion providers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2014/08/28/343990460/texas-law-could-lead-to-closure-of-clinics-that-offer-abortions|title=Texas Law Could Lead To Closure Of Clinics That Offer Abortions|work=NPR.org|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en}}</ref> The Supreme Court found the restrictions were an unconstitutional violation of the prohibition on placing an “undue burden” on the right to obtain an abortion.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/28/us/supreme-court-texas-abortion.html|title=Supreme Court Strikes Down Texas Abortion Restrictions|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en}}</ref>

Laxalt signed onto a California lawsuit to support keeping secret the identities of the donors to one of his biggest political backers, the [[Americans for Prosperity]] Foundation, backed by the GOP megadonors Charles and David Koch.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/news/politics-and-government/nevada/adam-laxalt-adds-name-to-lawsuit-concerning-top-gop-donors/|title=Adam Laxalt adds name to lawsuit concerning top GOP donors|date=2018-06-25|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en-US}}</ref> Laxalt opposed a multi-state investigation into [[ExxonMobil]]'s alleged role in downplaying climate change, condemning it as an attempt to stifle an “ongoing public policy debate” over human-caused global warming. Laxalt took legal action to keep fraud investigators from scrutinizing groups connected to the Koch network, which went on to spend $2.5 million to support Laxalt's governor campaign.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rgj.com/story/news/politics/2018/09/10/adam-laxalt-nevada-republican-nominee-exxon-mobil-koch-brothers-donor-foil/1203690002/|title=Laxalt joined Koch brothers, his campaign allies, in bid to block ExxonMobil fraud probe|work=Reno Gazette Journal|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en}}</ref>

title: 1850 United States House of Representatives election in Florida
added: Despite the weakness of the [[Whig Party (United States)|Whig Party]] after the death of President [[Zachary Taylor]], Beard was a source of great controversy. Beard, a staunch advocate of [[Nullification (U.S. Constitution)|nullification]] while he was in [[North Carolina]], became one of Florida's earliest secessionists. Beard claimed that with the admission of [[Texas]] to the United States, the [[Dixie|South]] had enough power to break free through war.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Nicholson|first=Angus W.|date=1850-10-05|title=Cabell vs. Beard - 1850|pages=2|work=Pensacola Gazette|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/61257632/cabell-vs-beard-1850/|url-status=live|access-date=2020-10-17}}</ref>

Cabell ran on the complete opposite as Beard, arguing that the [[Compromise of 1850]] will bring peace and an end to the slavery question. Many Floridians were also skeptical of breaking free from a Union they had just joined.<ref>{{Cite news|date=1850-09-21|title=To the Voters of Florida|pages=2|work=Pensacola Gazette|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/61257674/to-the-voters-of-florida/|access-date=2020-10-17}}</ref>

title: Arnold J. Toynbee
added: In regards to [[Ukraine]], or ''[[Little Russia]]'', Toynbee rejected both [[home rule]]<ref>[https://archive.org/details/nationalitywar00toyngoog/page/n346/mode/2up?q=slovenia]</ref> and a federal solution for Ukraine.<ref>[https://archive.org/details/nationalitywar00toyngoog/page/n348/mode/2up?q=slovenia]</ref> Toynbee's objection to the federal solution stemmed from his fear that a federated Russia would be too divided to have a unifying center of gravity and would thus be at risk of fragmentation and breaking up just like the [[United States of America]] previously did for a time during [[American Civil War|its own civil war]].<ref>[https://archive.org/details/nationalitywar00toyngoog/page/n348/mode/2up?q=slovenia]</ref> In place of autonomy, Toynbee proposed making the [[Ukrainian language]] [[Official language|co-official]] in the [[Great Russian]] parts of the Russian Empire so that Ukrainians (or Little Russians) could become members of the Russian body politic as Great Russians' peers rather than as Great Russians' inferiors.<ref>[https://archive.org/details/nationalitywar00toyngoog/page/n350/mode/2up?q=slovenia]</ref> Toynbee also argued that if the Ukrainian language will not be able to become competitive with Russian even if the Ukrainian language will be given official status in Russia, then this would prove once and for all the superior vitality of the [[Russian language]].<ref>[https://archive.org/details/nationalitywar00toyngoog/page/n354/mode/2up?q=slovenia]</ref>

In regards to future Russian expansion, Toynbee endorsed the idea of Russia conquering [[Outer Mongolia]] and the [[Tarim Basin]], arguing the Russia could improve and revitalize these territories just like the US did when it conquered the [[Mexican Cession]] territories from Mexico back in 1847.<ref>[https://archive.org/details/nationalitywar00toyngoog/page/n362/mode/2up?q=slovenia]</ref> In his book, Toynbee also endorsed the idea of having Russia annex both [[Pontus]] and the [[Armenian Vilayets]] of the [[Ottoman Empire]].<ref>[https://archive.org/details/nationalitywar00toyngoog/page/n424/mode/2up?q=slovenia]</ref>

title: Cindy O'Laughlin
added: O’Laughlin serves as the chair of the [https://www.senate.mo.gov/educ/ Missouri Senate Committee on Education] and also the Missouri General Assembly’s [https://www.senate.mo.gov/jc-education/ Joint Committee on Education]. She has sponsored legislation to [https://www.senate.mo.gov/20info/bts_web/Bill.aspx?SessionType=R&BillID=26838221 expand charter schools] and is a strong supporter of allowing Missouri families to decide what school best meets the needs of their students.
Prior to being elected to the Missouri Senate, Sen. O’Laughlin served as a member of the school board at her local public school and as an administrator at a local private school.

During a lecture on patriotism, Kaczynski also said "everyone must accept Christianity".<ref>{{cite web|url= http://time.com/5577841/lgbt-poland-jaroslaw-kaczynski/|title=Poland's Ruling Party Chair Calls LGBT Rights a Threat to the Nation|publisher=Time|accessdate=25 April 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/party-leader-calls-lgbt-rights-an-imported-threat-to-poland/4891764.html|title=Party Leader Calls LGBT Rights an Imported Threat to Poland|publisher=Voice of America|accessdate=25 April 2019}}</ref> That same month, after an activist displayed posters of the [[Black Madonna]] with a rainbow halo, Interior Minister [[Joachim Brudzinski]] denounced the posters as "cultural barbarism". The activist was subsequently arrested by the police on charges of "[[offending religious feelings]]". [[Amnesty International]] condemned the arrest as "just another example of the constant harassment" and said that the activist "now faces up to two years in prison if found guilty under these absurd charges".<ref>[https://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/lgbt-poles-latest-victims-nation-identity-crisis-190511212951252.html LGBT Poles are the latest victims of nation's 'identity crisis'], Al-Jazeera, Ylenia Gostoli, 12 May 2019</ref>

title: Benjamin Butler
added: According to biographer Hans L. Trefousse:

:Butler was one of the most controversial 19th-century American politicians. Demagogue, speculator, military bungler, and sharp legal practitioner--he was all of these; and he also was a fearless advocate of justice for the downtrodden, a resourceful military administrator, and an astonishing innovator.  He was passionately hated and equally strongly admired, and if the South called him "Beast," his constituents in Massachusetts were fascinated by him....As a leading advocate of radical Reconstruction, Butler played an important role in the conflict between president and Congress. His effectiveness was marred by the frequency with which engaged in personal altercations, and his conduct as one of the principal managers of the impeachment trial of Andrew Johnson was dubious. Nevertheless he deserves recognition as a persistent critic of southern terrorism and is one of the chief authors of the civil Rights act of 1875.  <ref>Hans L. Trefousse, “Butler, Benjamin Franklin” in  John A. Garraty, ed. ''Encyclopedia of American Biography'' (2nd ed. 1996) pp. 154–156. [https://archive.org/details/isbn_9780062700179/page/94/mode/2up online] </ref>

title: Jim Cramer
added: ===Calling House Speaker Nancy Pelosi "Crazy Nancy" during interview===

On September 16, 2020, Cramer addressed House Speaker [[Nancy Pelosi]] as “Crazy Nancy” during a TV interview, then sent several tweets in which he defended his actions before apologizing for using the phrase, which is also employed frequently by President [[Trump|Donald Trump]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sonmez |first1=Felicia |title=CNBC’s Jim Cramer calls Pelosi ‘Crazy Nancy’ to her face in live interview |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/pelosi-trump-cramer-interview/2020/09/15/4b5fae88-f785-11ea-89e3-4b9efa36dc64_story.html#comments-wrapper |work=Washington Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Levin |first1=Bess |title=Jim Cramer Is Offended People Didn’t Get the Subtle Nuance of Him Calling Nancy Pelosi “Crazy Nancy” to Her Face |url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2020/09/jim-cramer-nancy-pelosi |work=Vanity Fair |language=en-us}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Balluck |first1=Kyle |title=CNBC's Cramer calls Pelosi 'crazy Nancy' in live interview |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/house/516493-pelosi-says-trump-calls-other-people-crazy-because-he-knows-he-is |work=TheHill |date=15 September 2020 |language=en}}</ref>  During a discussion about the likelihood of a coronavirus relief bill, Cramer expressed doubt over the deal saying, "I mean, what deal can we have, Crazy Nancy?”.  He then quickly added  “I’m sorry, I — that was the president. I have such reverence for the office, I would never use that term.”<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sonmez |first1=Felicia |title=CNBC’s Jim Cramer calls Pelosi ‘Crazy Nancy’ to her face in live interview |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/pelosi-trump-cramer-interview/2020/09/15/4b5fae88-f785-11ea-89e3-4b9efa36dc64_story.html#comments-wrapper |work=Washington Post}}</ref>

deleted: In late November 2018, it was reported the [[FBI]] had classified the Proud Boys as an extremist group with ties to [[white nationalism]].<ref name="Gdn20181119" /><ref name=oregonian/> Two weeks later, an FBI official briefing [[Clark County, Washington]] law enforcement officials on the group, denied that it was their intent to classify the entire group in this manner and ascribed the mistake to a misunderstanding. title: Proud Boys
added: In early October 2020, a campaign from the [[LGBT community]] on Twitter, seemingly started by actor [[George Takei]], was launched to 'reclaim' the [[hashtag]] #proudboys from hate and bigotry, to inclusion and joy.<ref>{{cite news|last=Yo|first=Patricia|date=4 October 2020|title=Gay Men Take Over Proud Boys Hashtag With Photos Of Queer Love|work=[[The Daily Beast]]|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/gay-men-take-over-proud-boys-hashtag-with-photos-of-queer-love|url-status=live|access-date=5 October 2020}}</ref><ref name=":11">{{Cite news|last=Rosenblatt|first=Kalhan|date=5 October 2020|title=Gay Twitter users flood #ProudBoys hashtag with LGBTQ pride images|work=[[NBC News]]|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/feature/nbc-out/twitter-users-flood-proudboys-hashtag-gay-pride-images-n1242101?cid=sm_npd_nn_tw_ma&fbclid=IwAR3iFfimOtkLIvqVEG4aa1OeuI_hQebEbc8tpxdWfbPG6sGrjrISpmT7woo|url-status=live|access-date=6 October 2020}}</ref> The hashtag was previously used by the group to identify bigoted content, but it begun to be taken over by positive messages celebrating LGBT families and communities, with photos of gay friends, families and [[Internet meme|memes]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Strapagiel|first=Lauren|date=4 October 2020|title=The "Proud Boys" Hashtag Has Been Taken Over By Gay Love|work=[[BuzzFeed News]]|url=https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/laurenstrapagiel/proud-boys-hashtag-reclaimed-gay-love-photos|url-status=live|accessdate=5 October 2020}}</ref>

Reception to the take over has largely been positive, with the hashtag trending on October 4. Tweets from prominent figures such as journalist Jane Lytvynenko and Florida Representative [[Carlos Guillermo Smith]] have greeted the campaign, with Takei tweeting that "our community and allies answered hate with love."<ref name=":8" /><ref name="Forbes #proudboys">{{Cite news|last=Brown|first=Abram|date=4 October 2020|title=The Proud Boys Are Furious That Gay Men Have Taken Over #ProudBoys On Twitter|work=[[Forbes]]|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/abrambrown/2020/10/04/the-proud-boys-are-furious-that-gay-men-have-taken-over-proudboys-on-twitter/#316e4ae12aaf|url-status=live|access-date=6 October 2020}}</ref> The [[Canadian Armed Forces]] in the United States also tweeted out support, with a picture of [[Corporal]] Brent Kenny kissing another man, with the [[Royal Canadian Navy]] and the account for [[HMCS Winnipeg (FFH 338)|HMCS Winnipeg]] (that Kenny sailed on) retweeting.<ref name="Forbes #proudboys" /> In a later tweet, the Canadian Armed Forces in the United States posted: "If you wear our uniform, know what it means. If you're thinking about wearing our uniform, know what it means. Love is love."<ref name=":11" />

In response to the tweets, Proud Boys leader Tarrio officially commented that it was hysterical and that "this isn't something that's offensive to us. It's not an insult. We aren't homophobic. We don't care who people sleep with. People think it's going to bother us. It doesn't."<ref name=":8">{{cite news|title=Gay men have taken over the Proud Boys Twitter hashtag|url=https://lite.cnn.com/en/article/h_cc7024535acb2ef3b8abbf7409e0781f|date=October 4, 2020|accessdate=October 5, 2020|publisher=[[CNN]]}}</ref> On largely-conservative social media app [[Parler]], messages posted by members contained chiefly hateful comments such as "fags, can't stand gay people...should be illegal." ''[[Forbes]]'' has also reported Tarrio had posted opposing comments on Parler, describing how he believes "the left was attempting to turn the group's name into 'a slur' and that the gay pride campaign with #proudboys was an attempt 'to drown out the voices of our supporters.'"<ref name="Forbes #proudboys" />

title: Steve Scalise
added: In February 2019, Scalise filed a [[discharge petition]] on H.R. 962, [[Ann Wagner|Rep. Ann Wagner]]'s Born-Alive Abortion Survivors Protection Act. The bill would establish requirements for the degree of care a health care practitioner must exercise in the event a child is born alive following an abortion or attempted abortion.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Wagner|first=Ann|date=2019-03-22|title=H.R.962 - 116th Congress (2019-2020): Born-Alive Abortion Survivors Protection Act|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/962|access-date=2020-10-01|website=www.congress.gov}}</ref> In the weeks after filing the petition, Scalise and Wagner encouraged other [[Member of Congress|representatives]] to sign on.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2019-04-02|title=Rep. Scalise Files Petition to Bring Born-Alive Bill to House Floor|url=https://www.nationalreview.com/corner/rep-scalise-files-petition-to-bring-born-alive-bill-to-house-floor/|access-date=2020-10-01|website=National Review|language=en-US}}</ref> 218 signatures are required to force the [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker]] to schedule a [[United States House of Representatives|House Floor]] vote on H.R. 962. The petition has received 205 signatures.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Clerk|first=U.S. House|date=|title=Discharge Petition|url=https://clerk.house.gov/dp/116/lrc/pd/petitions/DisPet0001.xml|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=October 1, 2020|website=House Clerk Website}}</ref>

title: Political parties in the United States
deleted: The modern political party system in the United States is dominated by the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] and the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]]. These two parties have won every [[United States presidential election]] since 1852 and have controlled the [[United States Congress]] to some extent [[Divided government in the United States|since at least 1856]]. There are numerous minor, or third parties. The Libertarian, Green, Reform, Independent and other parties have won elections throughout history at different levels, but the success of those parties is sparse.

title: Henry Cuellar
added: On March 7, 2006, Cuellar again defeated Rodriguez in the Democratic primary with 52 percent of the vote in a three-way race. No Republican even attempted to file, ostensibly assuring him of reelection in November.

On June 29, the [[U.S. Supreme Court]] declared that the [[Texas Legislature]] had violated the rights of Latino voters when it shifted most of Laredo out of the 23rd and replaced it with several heavily Republican [[San Antonio]] suburbs.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2006/06/29/ap/politics/mainD8IHPP180.shtml |title=Redistrict Ruling May Affect Nov Election, Ruling That Congressional District in Texas Is Unconstitutional May Effect Nov Election – CBS News |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081005151900/http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2006/06/29/ap/politics/mainD8IHPP180.shtml |archivedate=October 5, 2008 }}</ref> As a result, nearly every congressional district from [[El Paso]] to San Antonio had to be redrawn, and the primary results for these districts were invalidated. A court drew a new map in which all of Laredo was moved into the 28th district while the south San Antonio area was moved to the 23rd. An election open to all candidates with a [[two-round system|runoff]] if no candidate won 50% was scheduled for the date of the general election, November 7, 2006.

In the general election on November 7, 2006, Cuellar had no Republican opposition but handily defeated Ron Avery of [[McQueeney, Texas|McQueeney]], the chairman of the conservative [[Constitution Party (United States)|Constitution Party]] in [[Guadalupe County, Texas|Guadalupe County]] and trial attorney and Democrat Frank Enriquez of McAllen by taking nearly 68 percent of the more than 77,000 votes cast in the House race.

Cuellar's two main political rivals, Bonilla and Rodriguez, ran against each other in the 23rd, and Rodriguez won the election in the runoff. The Republican Bonilla was hence out of Congress for the first time since his upset election in 1992.
Cuellar was unopposed in the March 4, 2008, Democratic primary.

In the November 4 [[general election]], Cuellar easily defeated Republican James Taylor Fish.<ref>{{cite news |author=Julian Aguilar |title=DA, sheriff tilts evoke lively campaign brawls |newspaper=Laredo Morning Times |date=January 4, 2008 |pages=1, 11A |url=http://preview.ussearch.com/preview/newsearch;jsessionid=618096F8C7F060B6E662B8F7B2BCCEF9?searchFName=james&searchMName=&searchLName=fish&searchCity=cibolo&searchState=TX&searchApproxAge=45&adID=10002101&searchtab=people&x=40&y=15 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080105051712/http://preview.ussearch.com/preview/newsearch |archivedate=2008-01-05}}</ref> Jim Fish, as he is known, was a health-care administrator for seventeen years while he served in the [[United States Air Force]]. He also taught [[finance]] at the Army-[[Baylor University]] Graduate School of Health Care Administration. Fish, an ordained [[Southern Baptist]] deacon, opposed [[same-sex marriage]]. Fish said that he had decided to oppose Cuellar after watching the congressman's exchange with Sheriff Rick Flores over border security issues on a 2007 broadcast of the [[Glenn Beck]] [[television]] program, then on [[CNN]].<ref>Julian Aguilar, "Jim Fish steps up to run against Cuellar for House", ''Laredo Morning Times'', October 10, 2008, p. 3A</ref>

Cuellar received 123,310 votes (69 percent) to Fish's 52,394 (29 percent) and 3,715 (2 percent) for [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian]] Ross Lynn Leone. In his own Webb County, Cuellar polled 41,567 votes (90 percent) to Fish's 4,089 votes (9 percent).<ref>Texas Secretary of State, November 4, 2008, election returns:http://team1.sos.state.tx.us/enr/results/nov04_141_state.htm{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>

Cuellar was unopposed for the Democratic nomination in 2010. Motivated by Cuellar's votes on cap and trade and the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]], two Republicans, Daniel Chavez, a utility company employee from [[Mission, Texas|Mission]] in [[Hidalgo County, Texas|Hidalgo County]], and Bryan Keith Underwood, a carpenter from Seguin in Guadalupe County, filed for their party's nomination to oppose Cuellar in the November 2 general election. Underwood polled 13,599 votes (74 percent) to Chavez's 4,794 (26 percent).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://enr.sos.state.tx.us/enr/results/mar02_148_state.htm?x=0&y=18482&id=272 |title=Texas Republican primary election returns, March 2, 2010 |publisher=Texas Secretary of State |accessdate=March 3, 2010 }}{{dead link|date=March 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>

Underwood raised more funds than Cuellar's previous Republican opponents, but questions were raised in Underwood's hometown newspaper, the ''Seguin Gazette'', about his criminal record, which included a guilty plea for a [[felony]] [[criminal mischief]] charge, which is normally a [[misdemeanor]]. Underwood had also refused on one occasion to present his identification to a law enforcement officer.

Cuellar prevailed, as expected, with 62,055 votes (56 percent) to Underwood's 46,417 (42 percent). The remaining 1,880 votes (2 percent) were cast for Libertarian Party candidate Stephen Kaat. While Underwood won in Guadalupe, Wilson, [[McMullen County, Texas|McMullen]], and [[Atascosa County, Texas|Atascosa]] counties, Cuellar's margin in his own heavily Democratic Webb County (25,415 to 3,569) was more than enough assure him a seat in the incoming Republican-majority House of Representatives.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://enr.sos.state.tx.us/enr/results/nov02_154_race27.htm|title=Texas general election returns, November 2, 2010 |publisher=Texas Secretary of State |accessdate=November 3, 2010}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes}}</ref>

Cuellar was opposed in the November 6 general election by Republican William R. Hayward and the Libertarian Patrick Hisel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politics1.com/tx.htm|title=Texas|publisher=politics1.com|accessdate=March 11, 2012}}</ref> Hisel ran unsuccessfully as a Libertarian in 2010 against the Republican U.S. Representative [[Kay Granger]] from the [[Tarrant County, Texas|Tarrant County]]-based [[Texas' 12th congressional district|12th District]]. Hisel's current city of residence is unknown.

Guadalupe County, a Republican stronghold that usually opposed Cuellar for reelection, was removed from the reconfigured District 28.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://seguingazette.com/news/article_ff39ae6c-6aea-11e1-8157-001871e3ce6c.html|title=On the Ballot: Filing finally closes for upcoming primary, March 10, 2012|newspaper=Seguin Gazette|accessdate=March 11, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120315174045/http://seguingazette.com/news/article_ff39ae6c-6aea-11e1-8157-001871e3ce6c.html|archive-date=March 15, 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref>

Cuellar defeated Hayward, 112,262 (68 percent) to 49,095 (30 percent). Hisel polled 2 percent of the vote, and a [[Green Party of the United States|Green Party]] candidate held the remaining 1 percent of the ballots.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/2012-election/map/#/House/2012/|title=2016 Election Results: President Live Map by State, Real-Time Voting Updates|publisher=Election Hub |accessdate=26 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://team1.sos.state.tx.us/enr/results/nov06_164_state.htm|title=Texas general election returns, November 6, 2012|publisher=Texas Secretary of State|accessdate=November 10, 2012|url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121205022857/https://team1.sos.state.tx.us/enr/results/nov06_164_state.htm|archivedate=December 5, 2012}}</ref>

Cuellar faced no Republican opposition in 2014. Then Webb County Republican chairman Randall Scott "Randy" Blair (1960-2019) of Laredo criticized Cuellar's vote for the Obama health law in 2010 but said the GOP could not find an opposing candidate because of Cuellar's personal popularity, political longevity, occasional cooperation with Republicans, and strong campaign organization.<ref name="cuellarhomeinterview"/>

Cuellar won a rematch in the March 1, 2016 Democratic primary with former Republican congressional candidate William R. Hayward, who switched parties to run again for the House. Cuellar received 49,962 votes (89.8 percent) to Hayward's 5,682 votes (10.2 percent).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://enrpages.sos.state.tx.us/public/mar01_233_state.htm?x=0&y=2456&id=904 |title=Democratic Primary returns |date=March 1, 2016 |accessdate=March 2, 2016 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306081855/https://enrpages.sos.state.tx.us/public/mar01_233_state.htm |archivedate=March 6, 2016}}</ref> Cuellar then defeated Republican Zeffen Patrick Hardin in the November 8, 2016 general election, 122,086 (66.2 percent) to 57,740 (31.3 percent). Michael D. Cary, nominee of the Green Party, received 4,616 votes (2.5 percent).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://elections.sos.state.tx.us/elchist319_state.htm|title=General Election Results|date=November 8, 2016|publisher=Texas Secretary of State|accessdate=December 16, 2016}}</ref>

In the general election held on November 6, 2018, Cuellar overwhelmed his lone challenger, Libertarian Arthur Thomas, IV, 117,178 votes (84.4 percent) to 21,647 (15.6 percent).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lmtonline.com/local/politics/article/Final-voting-results-from-the-November-2018-13371054.php|title=Final voting results from the November 2018 general and special elections in Webb County|newspaper=The Laredo Morning Times |date=November 7, 2018|accessdate=November 8, 2018}}</ref>

On January 11, 2019, the progressive organization [[Justice Democrats]], which supported the successful 2018 primary campaign in [[New York City]] for U.S. Representative [[Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez]], announced that it was seeking a primary challenger against Cuellar in the Democratic primary scheduled for March 4, 2020.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/left-wing-group-creates-fund-to-oust-texas-democrat/2019/01/11/eceb3d94-15aa-11e9-90a8-136fa44b80ba_story.html?noredirect=on|title=Left-wing group creates fund to oust Texas Democrat from Congress|last=Weigel|first=David|date=January 11, 2019|website=The Washington Post|access-date=January 11, 2019}}</ref> On July 13, 2019, Justice Democrats announced their support for Jessica Cisneros, a 26-year-old immigration and human rights attorney from Laredo who has announced a primary campaign against Cuellar.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2019/6/13/18663332/justice-democrats-henry-cuellar-primary|title=Justice Democrats have a primary challenger for Rep. Henry Cuellar — their top target|last=Nilsen|first=Ella|date=2019-06-13|website=Vox|access-date=2019-06-13}}</ref> However, Cuellar fended off the primary challenge by 51.8 percent to 48.2 percent.<ref>https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/485776-henry-cuellar-fends-off-democratic-challenger-in-texas-house-primary</ref>

Cuellar is a member of the [[New Democrat Coalition]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Members|url=https://newdemocratcoalition-himes.house.gov/members|publisher=New Democrat Coalition|date=|accessdate=5 February 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180208100356/https://newdemocratcoalition-himes.house.gov/members|archive-date=8 February 2018|url-status=dead}}</ref>

Cuellar describes himself as a "moderate-centrist" or sometimes as a [[conservative Democrat]].<ref name="cuellarhomeinterview" /> During the 115th Congress, he voted with President Donald Trump nearly 70% of the time, and he has advocated that more Democrats should embrace a more conservative voting record.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/a-qa-with-the-house-democrat-whos-voted-with-trump-75-percent-of-the-time/|title=A Q&A With The House Democrat Who's Voted With Trump 75 Percent Of The Time|last=Malone|first=Clare|date=2017-02-10|website=FiveThirtyEight|language=en-US|access-date=2019-11-05}}</ref> Other sources have stated that he votes with the Republican party 75% of the time.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://theintercept.com/2020/03/04/jessica-cisneros-texas-28-henry-cuellar-congress-primary/|title=Jessica Cisneros, a Progressive Favorite, Loses to Incumbent Henry Cuellar|author=Lee Fang|work=theintercept.com|date=March 4, 2020|accessdate=March 5, 2020}}</ref>

In 2010, Cuellar's ratings from various groups included the following: NARAL Pro-Choice America, 50; National Right to Life Center, 20; ACLU, 67; Human Rights Campaign, 70; American Conservative Union, 12; Americans for Democratic Action, 80; Drum Major Institute, A; Family Research Council, 29; Children's Defense Fund, 100; League of Conservation Voters, 100; Numbers USA, D; American Public Health Association, 89; Alliance for Retired Americans, 88; AFL-CIO, 81; National Education Association, A; AFSCME, 86; BIPAC, 60; Chamber of Commerce, 72; [[Club for Growth]], 9; National Federation of Independent Business, 73; Taxes & Spending Americans for Tax Reform, 15; Citizens Against Government Waste, 22; National Taxpayers Union, 7; Defense and Peace Council for a Livable World, 50; Center for Security Policy, 50; Friends Committee on National Legislation, 50; Peace Action, 23; Gunowners of America, C (now F<ref name="Gunowners Of America">{{cite web|title=Congressional Ratings Texas|url=https://gunowners.org/tx-rating-2016.htm|publisher=Gunowners Of America}}</ref>); Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence, 0.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rep. Henry Cuellar |url=http://thehill.com/resources/lawmaker-ratings/81669-rep-henry-cuellar-d-texas|work=The Hill|date=2010-02-18}}</ref>

On issues of gun control and the right to bear arms, he allies closely with the [[National Rifle Association]], which gave him a 93% score for 2018.<ref>{{cite web |title= Henry Cuellar's Ratings and Endorsements |publisher=Vote Smart |url=https://votesmart.org/candidate/evaluations/5486/henry-cuellar}}</ref> He is one of two [[Blue Dog Democrat]]s<ref name="Blue Dog members">{{cite web|title=Members|author=|url=https://bluedogcaucus-costa.house.gov/members|format=|publisher=Blue Dog Coalition|accessdate=7 February 2018}}</ref> in Texas's congressional delegation.

Cuellar's boosting of [[automated license plate recognition]] federal contractor [[Perceptics LLC]] was published in February 2020, showing lobbying by [[Podesta Group]] from 2009 onwards, including Cuellar using talking points related to Perceptics contracts. He was called "our Cuellar firepower" and described by Perceptics CEO John Dalton as a "friendly congressman" for the company.<ref name="thei_Emai">{{Cite web |title=Emails Show Rep. Henry Cuellar Provided Extensive Favors to Border Security Lobbyists |author= |work=The Intercept |date= |access-date=1 March 2020 |url= https://theintercept.com/2020/02/26/henry-cuellar-perceptics-hack/ |quote=about pilots going on at Laredo that sound a lot like Perceptics’ }}</ref>

On February 10, 2010, ''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]'' wrote that Cuellar "votes against his party. He rejected the first House bailout bill, which was voted down, but backed the final version that passed in the fall of 2008. Cuellar was also one of 27 Democrats who opposed the House financial regulatory reform bill, a top priority for Obama. As of June 7, 2017, Cuellar has voted with president Trump 70% of the time, the highest percentage of any Democrat in Congress."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/congress-trump-score/henry-cuellar/|title=Five Thirty Eight|date=2017-01-30}}</ref> Cuellar consistently works with members on both sides of the aisle, a rarity for House members. In fact, he says his best friend in the lower chamber is a Republican: Rep. Michael McCaul (Texas)."<ref>{{cite news |last=Hooper|first=Molly|title=Long shunned, Dems embrace Cuellar|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/house/80461-long-shunned-cuellar-now-embraced-by-house-dems|newspaper=The Hill|date=February 10, 2010}}</ref>

Cuellar was ranked the fifth most bipartisan member of the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] in the first session of the [[115th United States Congress]] by the [[Richard Lugar|Lugar Center]] and [[Georgetown University|Georgetown's]] [[McCourt School of Public Policy]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thelugarcenter.org/assets/htmldocuments/House%20Scores%20115th%20Congress%20First%20Session.pdf|publisher=The Lugar Center|title=The Lugar Center - McCourt School Bipartisan Index|date=April 24, 2018|accessdate=July 3, 2018|location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://texasborderbusiness.com/rep-cuellar-ranked-5th-most-bipartisan-member-in-congress/|title=Rep. Cuellar Ranked 5th Most Bipartisan Member in Cognress|publisher=Texas Border Business|location=McAllen, Texas|date=April 25, 2018|accessdate=July 3, 2018}}</ref>

On June 26, 2009, Cuellar voted with the House majority to pass, 219–212, the [[American Clean Energy and Security Act]], also known as the [[cap and trade]] bill<ref>{{cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2009/roll477.xml|title=Final Vote Results for Roll Call 477|publisher=Clerk.house.gov|accessdate=July 4, 2009}}</ref> He also supported the [[Affordable Health Care for America Act]], which narrowly passed the House and in December 2009 met the threshold for shutting off debate in the U.S. Senate by a single vote. As an [[anti-abortion]] Democrat,<ref name=":0" /> Cuellar expressed concerns that the Senate health care bill allowed federal funding for abortion. He has voted for a ban on abortion after week 20.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.vogue.com/article/jessica-cisneros-justice-democrats-henry-cuellar-primary-challenge-2020|title=Is Jessica Cisneros the Next Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez?|website=Vogue|language=en|access-date=2019-06-17}}</ref> Cuellar voted on March 21, 2010, for the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]], which passed the chamber by a vote of 219–212.<ref>{{cite web|author=Christina Bellantoni | date =March 20, 2010 |url=http://tpmdc.talkingpointsmemo.com/2010/03/cuellar-to-vote-yes.php |title=Cuellar To Vote 'Yes' | TPMDC |publisher=Tpmdc.talkingpointsmemo.com |accessdate=2010-08-29}}</ref>

On June 15, 2007, Cuellar announced that he was endorsing then [[U.S. Senator]] [[Hillary Clinton]] for President in 2008, saying that "Senator Clinton is the only candidate with the experience and toughness to hit the ground running on her first day in the White House." In 2007, Cuellar held a fundraiser for Clinton in Laredo, which raised over $200,000 – aided by the presence of former President [[Bill Clinton]]. Laredo's Democratic [[Mayor]] [[Raul G. Salinas]] joined Cuellar in giving his early support to Hillary Clinton, who came to Laredo in October 2008 to endorse Cuellar's reelection to the U.S. House. On November 4, 2008, Democrat [[Barack Obama]] defeated Republican [[John McCain]] in Webb County with 71% of the vote to McCain's 28%.

Congressman Cuellar is the author and one of two main co-sponsors of legislation seeking to honor slain ICE agent [[Jaime Zapata]]. Billed as a [http://www.mysanantonio.com/news/politics/article/Border-security-bill-named-after-slain-ICE-agent-1042950.php border security bill], it would increase cooperation among state, local, and federal law enforcement agencies during investigations of human and drug smuggling from Mexico.

On July 24, 2013, Cuellar voted to continue funding NSA surveillance of U.S. citizens who are not suspected of committing any crime, in violation of their Fourth Amendment rights according to some views of the Bill of Rights.

In 2013, in a statement with House colleagues [[Beto O'Rourke]] of [[El Paso, Texas|El Paso]] and [[Filemon Vela, Jr.|Filemon Vela]] of [[Brownsville, Texas|Brownsville]], Cuellar renewed his opposition to a border fence along the Rio Grande between the United States and Mexico. He denounced inclusion in the Senate immigration bill of an amendment sponsored by [[Bob Corker]] of [[Tennessee]] and [[John Hoeven]] of [[North Dakota]], which calls for seven hundred additional miles of border fencing. Cuellar called the fence an antiquated solution to a new-age problem. The fence, he said, ignores the economic ties between the two nations which reached $500 billion in 2012.<ref>JJ Velasquez, "Immigration Reform: Cuellar sounds off on Senate bill", ''Laredo Morning Times'', July 5, 2013, pp. 1, 9A.</ref>

In 2014, Cuellar was the only House Democrat to vote for a House bill that would have made it easier to deport unaccompanied minors to [[Central America]]. He also released unauthorized photographs of unsanitary conditions in [[United States Border Patrol|Border Patrol]] [[Immigration detention|detention centers]]. Despite these actions, Cuellar said he is firmly in support of "comprehensive immigration reform".<ref name="cuellarhomeinterview"/>

In May 2015, Cuellar called for 55 more federal judges to handle the overload of some 450,000 immigration cases. There were 260 such judges in 58 courts. Twenty-eight of the judges serve Texas; no immigration judge holds court in Laredo. Many of those awaiting hearings are held in detention centers or released on bond. In many cases those on bond never come to their scheduled hearings. Cuellar said South Texas and Laredo have particular need for the judges.<ref>Gabriela A. Trevino, "Rep wants more judges: Immigration cases await hearings", ''Laredo Morning Times'', May 18, 2015, pp. 1, 12A</ref>

On July 23, 2015, the occasion of [[Donald Trump]]'s Republican presidential campaign visit to Laredo, the Democrat Cuellar said that the [[New York City]] business tycoon has "overgeneralized and exacerbated a rhetoric of immigrant crime that has offended many, particularly those of Mexican heritage". Cuellar added that Trump's meeting with border officials provided an opportunity for him to view Laredo as a "culturally-rich and safe border community".<ref>Kendra Ablaza, "Trump visits Laredo: To meet with law enforcement, ''Laredo Morning Times'', July 23, 2015, pp. 1, 7A.</ref>

In April 2017, Cuellar issued a statement which accuses President Trump with: "threatening to shut down the government if he doesn't get to build his symbolic [[Border barrier|border wall]]. He wants to cut things like education, transportation, and health care, to fund his pet project. Now that he is facing bipartisan opposition to this irresponsible plan, he wants to punish the American people by shutting down the government."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lmtonline.com/local/politics/article/Laredo-congressman-Trump-wants-to-punish-the-11094834.php|title=Laredo congressman: Trump wants to 'punish the American people' with shutdown|newspaper=Laredo Morning Times |date=April 24, 2017|accessdate=April 26, 2017}}</ref>

Cuellar was one of three Democrats to vote for [[Kate's Law]], which expands maximum sentences for immigrants who re-enter the United States after being deported.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/448343-justice-democrats-endorse-rep-cuellar-challenger|title=Justice Democrats endorse primary challenge to Texas Dem Cuellar|last=Rodrigo|first=Chris Mills|date=2019-06-13|website=TheHill|language=en|access-date=2019-06-17}}</ref> He supported legislation to strip federal funding for jurisdictions that have [[Sanctuary city|sanctuary policies]] in place.<ref name=":0" />
On December 18, 2019, Cuellar voted for both articles of impeachment against President Donald J. Trump.<ref>https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-impeachment-vote-results-house-2019-12</ref>

According to one measure, Cuellar voted with President Trump more than any other Democrat in Congress, except one.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/first-shot-fired-democratic-civil-war-8-term-incumbent-gets-n1016976|title=First shot fired in Democratic civil war as 8-term incumbent gets a challenger|website=NBC News|language=en|access-date=2019-06-17}}</ref>

Cueller received the most financial contributions by the private prison industry than any member of Congress, except one Republican.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://rewire.news/article/2018/09/14/private-prison-campaign-cash-still-welcomed-by-some-democrats-in-the-trump-era/|title=Private Prison Campaign Cash Still Welcomed by Some Democrats in the Trump Era|website=Rewire.News|language=en|access-date=2019-06-17}}</ref>

Cuellar and his wife, Imelda, have two daughters. The city of Laredo has recognized him by naming two schools in his honor: the Doctor Henry Cuellar Elementary School and the Representative Henry Cuellar Charter School.

In 2014, Cuellar portrayed [[George Washington]] in the annual [[Washington's Birthday Celebration]] in Laredo.<ref>Miguel Timoshenkov, "Congressman, educator named new George, Martha", ''Laredo Morning Times'', April 2, 2013, p. 3A</ref>

title: Politics of Texas

title: Donald Trump
added: {{Main|List of federal judges appointed by Donald Trump|Donald Trump judicial appointment controversies}}

Trump has appointed more than 200 [[United States federal judges|federal judges]] who were confirmed by the Senate.<ref name=WheelerFriday>{{Cite web|author=Russell Wheeler|url=https://www.brookings.edu/blog/fixgov/2020/06/26/trumps-200th-judicial-appointment-less-than-meets-the-eye/|publisher=Brookings Institution|work=FixGov|title=Trump's 200th judicial appointment: Less than meets the eye|date=June 26, 2020}}</ref><ref name=Hulse>{{Cite web|author=Carl Hulse|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/24/us/trump-senate-judges-wilson.html|title=With Wilson Confirmation, Trump and Senate Republicans Achieve a Milestone|newspaper=New York Times|date=June 24, 2020}}</ref> Senate Republicans, led by Senate Majority Leader [[Mitch McConnell]], have rapidly confirmed Trump's judicial appointees, usually against unified Democratic opposition.<ref name=Hulse/><ref name=Ruiz>{{Cite web|author=Rebecca R. Ruiz, Robert Gebeloff, Steve Eder & Ben Protess|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/14/us/trump-appeals-court-judges.html|title=A Conservative Agenda Unleashed on the Federal Courts|date=March 14, 2020|newspaper=New York Times}}</ref> Trump's appointments have shifted the federal judiciary to the [[Right-wing politics|right]].<ref name=Ruiz/> Trump's judicial appointments have been overwhelmingly white men,<ref name=Ruiz/><ref name=Cohen>{{Cite web|author=Andrew Cohen|date=July 1, 2020|url=https://www.brennancenter.org/our-work/analysis-opinion/trump-and-mcconnells-overwhelmingly-white-male-judicial-appointments|publisher=Brennan Center for Justice, NYU School of Law|title=Trump and McConnell's Overwhelmingly White Male Judicial Appointments}}</ref> and are younger on average than appointees by Trump's predecessors.<ref name=Ruiz/> Many are affiliated with the [[Federalist Society]].<ref name=Ruiz/>

Trump has made three nominations to the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]]: [[Neil Gorsuch]], [[Brett Kavanaugh]], and [[Amy Coney Barrett]].<ref name=Barrett>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/25/us/politics/amy-coney-barrett-supreme-court.html|title=Trump Selects Amy Coney Barrett to Fill Ginsburg's Seat on the Supreme Court|author=Peter Baker & Maggie Haberman|date=September 25, 2020|newspaper=New York Times}}</ref> Gorsuch was [[Neil Gorsuch Supreme Court nomination|confirmed]] in 2017 in a mostly [[party-line vote]] of 54–45, after Republicans invoked the "[[nuclear option]]" (a historic change to Senate rules removing the 60-vote threshold for advancing Supreme Court nominations) to defeat a Democratic [[filibuster]].<ref name=Caldwell>{{Cite web|author=Leigh Ann Caldwell|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/congress/neil-gorsuch-confirmed-supreme-court-after-senate-uses-nuclear-option-n743766|publisher=NBC News|title=Neil Gorsuch Confirmed to Supreme Court After Senate Uses 'Nuclear Option'|date=April 7, 2020}}</ref> Trump's predecessor Obama had [[Merrick Garland Supreme Court nomination|nominated]] [[Merrick Garland]] in 2016 to fill the vacancy, left by the death of [[Antonin Scalia]], but Senate Republicans under McConnell refused to consider the nomination in the last year of Obama's presidency, angering Democrats.<ref name=Caldwell/> Trump [[Brett Kavanaugh Supreme Court nomination|nominated Kavanagh]] in 2018 to replace retiring Justice [[Anthony Kennedy]]; the Senate confirmed Kavanagh in a mostly party-line vote of 50–48, after a bitter confirmation battle centered on [[Christine Blasey Ford]]'s allegation that Kavanagh had attempted to rape her when they were teenagers, which Kavanagh denied.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Sheryl Gay Stolberg|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/06/us/politics/brett-kavanaugh-supreme-court.html|date=October 6, 2018|title=Kavanaugh Is Sworn In After Close Confirmation Vote in Senate|newspaper=New York Times}}</ref> In 2020, weeks before the elections, Trump [[Amy Coney Barrett Supreme Court nomination|nominated]] [[Amy Coney Barrett]] to fill the vacancy left by the [[death of Ruth Bader Ginsburg|death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg]]; if confirmed, the  [[Ideological leanings of United States Supreme Court justices|ideological composition of the Supreme Court]] would be substantially changed.<ref name=Barrett/>

As president, Trump has disparaged courts and judges who he disagrees with, often in personal terms, and has questioned the judiciary's constitutional authority. Trump's attacks on the courts have drawn rebukes from observers, including sitting federal judges, who concerned with the effect of Trump's statements on the [[judicial independence]] and public confidence in the judiciary.<ref>{{Cite news|authors=Abby Phillip, Robert Barnes & Ed O'Keefe|title=Supreme Court nominee Gorsuch says Trump's attacks on judiciary are 'demoralizing'|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/supreme-court-nominee-gorsuch-says-trumps-attacks-on-judiciary-are-demoralizing/2017/02/08/64e03fe2-ee3f-11e6-9662-6eedf1627882_story.html|newspaper=Washington Post|date=February 8, 2017}}</ref><ref name=OwnWords>{{Cite report|title=In His Own Words: The President's Attacks on the Courts|url=https://www.brennancenter.org/our-work/research-reports/his-own-words-presidents-attacks-courts|publisher=Brennan Center for Justice, NYU School of Law|date=February 14, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|author=Katie Shepherd|title=Trump 'violates all recognized democratic norms,' federal judge says in biting speech on judicial independence|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2019/11/08/judge-says-trump-violates-democratic-norms-judiciary-speech/|newspaper=Washington Post|date=November 8, 2019}}</ref>
