title: Mike Turner
added: In both 2008 and 2010 Turner was listed as one of the "most corrupt members of Congress" by the [[Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington]] for "enrichment of self, family, or friends" and "solicitation of gifts".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.citizensforethics.org/press-release/crew-releases-fourth-annual-most-corrupt-members-of-congress-report/|title=Crew Releases Fourth Annual Most Corrupt Members of Congress Report|website=CREW|language=en-US|access-date=January 28, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.citizensforethics.org/press-release/crew-26-lawmakers-corrupting-halls-congress/|title=CREW: House and Senate Ethics Committees Protecting the Most Corrupt Members of Congress|website=CREW|language=en-US|access-date=January 28, 2019}}</ref>

title: Mike Turner
deleted: In both 2008 and 2010 Turner was listed as one of the "most corrupt members of Congress" by the [[Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington]] for "enrichment of self, family, or friends" and "solicitation of gifts".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.citizensforethics.org/press-release/crew-releases-fourth-annual-most-corrupt-members-of-congress-report/|title=Crew Releases Fourth Annual Most Corrupt Members of Congress Report|website=CREW|language=en-US|access-date=January 28, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.citizensforethics.org/press-release/crew-26-lawmakers-corrupting-halls-congress/|title=CREW: House and Senate Ethics Committees Protecting the Most Corrupt Members of Congress|website=CREW|language=en-US|access-date=January 28, 2019}}</ref>

In 2006, a marketing firm owned by Turner's first wife, Lori, was hired without competitive bidding by the Dayton Development Coalition, an organization which lobbies for federal funds from congressmen such as Representative Turner, to develop a regional re-branding campaign. She withdrew from the coalition in 2008 weeks after reports of the agreement surfaced which also revealed that her firm was compensated at least $300,000 to produce the slogan "Get Midwest".<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.pressreader.com/usa/dayton-daily-news/20101221/textview|title=Lori Turner named VP at Kettering Health Network|last=|first=|date=October 21, 2010|work=Dayton Daily News|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.daytondailynews.com/news/state--regional-govt--politics/turner-facing-roberts-congressional-race/tBONNRB7AfAYioLgJ8ckiN/|title=Turner facing Roberts in congressional race|last=Lynn Hulsey|first=Staff Writer|website=daytondailynews|language=english|access-date=January 28, 2019}}</ref>

A 2008 report released by the Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington detailed $54,065 that Turner's election committee had paid to his wife's marketing company between 2002 and 2006 based on public campaign finance disclosures.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.citizensforethics.org/press-release/crew-releases-new-report-detailing-the-houses-use-of-campaign-funds-to-bene/|title=CREW Releases New Report Detailing the House's Use of Campaign Funds to Benefit Family Members|website=CREW|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190128045814/https://s3.amazonaws.com/storage.citizensforethics.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/20022732/Family%20Affair%20(House)%20-%20Full%20Report.pdf|archive-date=January 28, 2019|url-status=|access-date=January 28, 2019}}</ref>

According to analysis conducted by the [[Dayton Daily News]] in 2016<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.daytondailynews.com/news/national-govt--politics/most-come-congress-rich-and-then-get-richer-analysis-shows/JWJBTtnLbHSM6gvFAIDyPP/|title=Most come to Congress rich, and then get richer, analysis shows|last=Jessica Wehrman|first=Washington Bureau|website=daytondailynews|language=English|access-date=January 28, 2019}}</ref>, when Rep. Mike Turner came to Congress in 2002, he claimed between $153,026 and $695,000 worth of assets on his financial disclosure form. In 2016, he claimed between $2.8 million and $10.3 million. The paper credited his second marriage (now also divorced) to an energy lobbyist as a contributing reason for the increase, since her assets as well as his were listed on his 2016 financial disclosure form. Their relationship raised red-flags<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mydaytondailynews.com/news/national-govt--politics/turner-says-fiancee-business-dealings-pose-conflict/Te8SPvivz2nAnfsxbCSAvO/|title=Turner says fianceeâ€™s business dealings pose no conflict|last=Josh Sweigart|first=Staff Writer|website=mydaytondailynews|language=english|access-date=January 28, 2019}}</ref> when Turner was accused of authoring natural gas legislation that might benefit her employer at the time, Cheniere Energy.

At multiple times throughout his tenure in Congress, Turner has faced protests from constituents for refusing to host public town hall events,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.daytondailynews.com/news/national-govt--politics/with-protesters-outside-republicans-local-gop-dinner-stressed-unity/vIJ3YktiOSxQ2EejXwUkyI/|title=With protesters outside, Republicans at local GOP dinner stressed unity|last=Lynn Hulsey|first=Staff Writer|website=daytondailynews|language=English|access-date=February 6, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wyso.org/post/weekend-where-s-mike-town-hall-protest-draws-crowd|title=Weekend “Where’s Mike” Town Hall Protest Draws Crowd|last=Mador|first=Jess|website=www.wyso.org|language=en|access-date=February 6, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fox45now.com/news/local/where-is-representative-mike-turner-protesters-calling-for-a-town-hall-meeting|title=Where is Representative Mike Turner? Protesters calling for a town hall meeting|last=Sullivan|first=Michael|date=February 21, 2017|website=WRGT|access-date=February 6, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wdtn.com/news/local-news/protests-against-trump-s-anti-illegal-immigration-policy/1240144721|title=Protests against Trump's anti-illegal immigration policy|last=Smith|first=Dana|date=June 15, 2018|website=WDTN|language=en-US|access-date=February 6, 2019}}</ref> presumably over fear that the events would draw strong backlash from constituents over repeated efforts to repeal the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act|Affordable Care Act]] that Republicans in neighboring districts<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wdtn.com/news/tempers-flare-at-town-hall-meeting-with-rep-warren-davidson/1003150974|title=Tempers flare at town hall meeting with Rep. Warren Davidson|last=Allen|first=Kim|date=April 12, 2017|website=WDTN|language=en-US|access-date=February 6, 2019}}</ref> and around the country<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/09/us/politics/town-hall-meetings-.html|title=Critics at Town Halls Confront Republicans Over Health Care|last=Fortin|first=Jacey|date=May 9, 2017|work=The New York Times|access-date=February 6, 2019|last2=Victor|first2=Daniel|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/05/tom-macarthur-republican-town-hall-health-care/526338/|title=A Republican Congressman Meets His Angry Constituency|last=Berman|first=Russell|date=May 11, 2017|website=The Atlantic|language=en-US|access-date=February 6, 2019}}</ref> experienced.

At various times Turner has been criticized by fiscally conservative groups, such as the [[Citizens Against Government Waste]], for siphoning federal taxpayer dollars to local line-item projects, specifically after obtaining $250,000 to a [[Murphy Theatre|local theater]] in his district in [[Wilmington, Ohio]]<ref>{{Cite book|title=2010 Congressional Pig Book Summary|last=|first=|publisher=Citizens Against Government Waste|year=2010|isbn=|location=https://www.cagw.org/content/2010-pig-book-summary|pages=}}</ref> and $4,000,000 for Open Source Research Centers intended for Radiance Technologies in [[Fairborn, Ohio]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cagw.org/media/press-releases/pork-alert-house-department-defense|title=Pork Alert: House Department of Defense|date=June 24, 2009|website=Citizens Against Government Waste|url-status=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170210180737/https://www.cagw.org/media/press-releases/pork-alert-house-department-defense|archive-date=February 10, 2017}}</ref>

In April 2019, [[Citizens Against Government Waste]] named Turner the "Porker of the Month"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cagw.org/porker-of-the-month/cagw-names-rep-mike-turner-april-2019-porker-month|title=CAGW Names Rep. Mike Turner April 2019 Porker of the Month|last=admin|date=April 23, 2019|website=Citizens Against Government Waste|language=en|access-date=October 7, 2019}}</ref> for leading the effort to "spend more taxpayer dollars on the most expensive weapons system in U.S. history", the [[Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II|F-35]] program. This designation came in recognition for his continued support for expansion<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://turner.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/joint-strike-fighter-jsf-caucus-co-chairs-announce-record-support-for|title=Joint Strike Fighter (JSF) Caucus Co-Chairs Announce Record Support for Program|date=April 3, 2019|website=Congressman Michael Turner|language=en|access-date=October 7, 2019}}</ref> of the program which had already been in development for 17 years, was seven years behind schedule, and was nearly $200 billion over budget.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sullivan|first=Michael|date=April 14, 2015|title=Testimony Before the Subcommittee on Tactical Air and Land Forces, Committee on Armed Services, House of Representatives|url=https://www.gao.gov/assets/670/669605.pdf|journal=Government Accountability Office|volume=GAO-15-429T|pages=|via=}}</ref> In March, Air Force Secretary [[Heather Wilson]] had raised concerns<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.defensenews.com/air/2019/03/22/industrial-base-considerations-played-role-in-f-15x-decision/|title=Industrial base considerations played role in F-15X decision|last=Insinna|first=Valerie|date=March 22, 2019|website=Defense News|language=en-US|access-date=October 7, 2019}}</ref> about the soaring expense of the F-35 saying, “we just don’t think that there has been enough attention on the sustainment costs of the aircraft and driving them down.” This criticism added to the existing [[United States House Committee on Armed Services|House Armed Services Committee]] report<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rollcall.com/news/policy/f-35c-navy-stealth-range|title=Navy’s Top-Dollar Stealth Fighter May Not Go the Distance|last=Donnelly|first=John M.|date=May 21, 2018|access-date=October 7, 2019|last2=Donnelly|first2=John M.|language=en}}</ref> from 2018 stating that the F-35, “may not have the range it needs to strike enemy targets,” and that, “the Joint Strike Fighter initiative, the most expensive weapons program in history, may actually have been out of date years ago.”

title: Walter Isaacson
added: Born in [[New Orleans]], [[Louisiana]], he attended [[Harvard University]] and the [[University of Oxford]] as a [[Rhodes scholar]] at [[Pembroke College, Oxford|Pembroke College]]. After working for multiple years as a journalist, he branched out into authorship and co-wrote with [[Evan Thomas]] the work ''[[The Wise Men: Six Friends and the World They Made]]'' (1986). Over the years, he's written multiple [[Biography|biographical]] works including ''[[Steve Jobs (book)|Steve Jobs]]'' (2011), ''[[American Sketches]]'' (2009), ''[[Einstein: His Life and Universe]]'' (2007), ''[[Benjamin Franklin: An American Life]]'' (2003), and ''[[Kissinger: A Biography]]'' (1992). His books have received praise from a wide variety of reviewers, with ''Steve Jobs'' being adapted [[Steve Jobs (film)|into a film of the same name]] in 2015.

Isaacson has additionally served as a professor at [[Tulane University]].<ref name=MichaelNeibauer/> He has held different corporate positions as well. In terms of public service, he was appointed vice chairperson of the [[Louisiana Recovery Authority]], a board that oversaw spending on the recovery from [[Hurricane Katrina]]. He's also worked in various positions for the U.S. Departments of State and Defense.

title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
added: Ginsburg's death left eight Supreme Court justices split 4–4 between characteristically conservative and characteristically liberal, during a [[2020 United States presidential election|presidential election year]]. According to a [[National Public Radio]] report, prior to Ginsburg's death, she said to her granddaughter, "My most fervent wish is that I will not be replaced until a new president is installed."<ref>https://www.npr.org/2020/09/18/100306972/justice-ruth-bader-ginsburg-champion-of-gender-equality-dies-at-87</ref> U.S. Senate majority leader Mitch McConnell vowed to bring a Trump nominee to replace Ginsburg to a vote in the Senate, arguing in part that "Since the 1880s, no Senate has confirmed an opposite-party president's Supreme Court nominee in a presidential election year."<ref>https://www.republicanleader.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/mcconnell-statement-on-the-passing-of-justice-ruth-bader-ginsburg</ref>

title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
deleted: Following her appointment to the Supreme Court in 1993,{{cn|date=September 2020}} Ginsburg deviated from the traditional American [[court dress]] by wearing a French ''robe d'avocat'',<ref>{{Cite web|last=Rosemont|first=Sophie|date=September 19, 2020|title=Ruth Bader Ginsburg, l'icône|trans-title=Ruth Bader Ginsburg, the icon|url=https://www.rollingstone.fr/ruth-bader-ginsburg-la-femme-debout/|url-status=live|access-date=September 19, 2020|website=Rolling Stone|language=fr-FR}}</ref> as opposed to the typical judicial robe worn in the United States. The French robe differs from the American with its exposed buttons, open sleeves, standing collar, and white [[rabat]]. On the left shoulder of the robe are two buttons intended for the fastening of an [[epitoge]], traditionally worn by French lawyers. In later years, Ginsburg shifted from the traditionally uniform white French rabat and began wearing more varied and fanciful [[jabot (neckwear)|jabot]]s, necklaces, and other forms of neckwear. Some time later, fellow Supreme Court justice Sandra Day O'Connor and other women on the court followed Ginsburg's lead and began wearing the French ''robe d'avocat'' as well.{{cn|date=September 2020}}

title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg

title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
added: In light of the mounting backlog in the federal judiciary, Congress passed the [[Omnibus Judgeship Act of 1978]] increasing the number of federal judges by 117 in district courts and another 35 to be added to the circuit courts. The law placed an emphasis on ensuring that the judges included women and minority groups, a matter that was important to President [[Jimmy Carter]] who had been elected two years before. The bill also required that the nomination process consider the character and experience of the candidates.{{Sfn|De Hart|2020|p=277}} Ginsburg was considering a change in career as soon as Carter was elected. She was interviewed by the [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] to become [[Solicitor General of the United States|Solicitor General]], the position she most desired, but knew that she and the African-American candidate who was interviewed the same day had little chance of being appointed by Attorney General [[Griffin Bell]].{{Sfn|De Hart|2020|p=278}}

title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
added: Besides ''Grutter'', Ginsburg wrote in favor of affirmative action in her dissent in ''[[Gratz v. Bollinger]]'' (2003), in which the court ruled an affirmative action policy unconstitutional because it was not [[Strict scrutiny|narrowly tailored]] to the state's interest in diversity. She argued that "government decisionmakers may properly distinguish between policies of exclusion and inclusion...Actions designed to burden groups long denied full citizenship stature are not sensibly ranked with measures taken to hasten the day when entrenched discrimination and its after effects have been extirpated."<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Heriot |first1=Gail |title=Thoughts on Grutter v. Bollinger and Gratz v. Bollinger as Law and as Practical Politics |journal=[[Loyola University Chicago Law Journal]] |date=2004 |volume=36 |page=137 |url=https://lawecommons.luc.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1246&context=luclj |accessdate=September 26, 2020}}</ref>

title: TJ Cox
added: When Cox made an updated financial disclosure in 2019, it was discovered that he had failed to disclose business interests as a candidate in 2018.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last=Tavlian|first=Alex|last2=|first2=|date=2019-05-12|title=Ethics complaint filed against Cox citing failed reporting of business ties|url=http://sjvsun.com/news/politics/ethics-complaint-filed-against-cox-citing-failed-reporting-of-business-ties/|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-01|website=The San Joaquin Valley Sun|language=en-US}}</ref> It was also discovered that Cox failed to timely pay wages owed to three employees of Constellation Mines, a company where Cox was a director until early 2019.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|last=Irby|first=Kate|date=August 21, 2019|title=California congressman took 2 years to pay wages he owed to Canadian workers|url=https://www.fresnobee.com/news/local/article234047417.html|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=|website=}}</ref> These obligations were not disclosed when Cox ran for Congress in 2018.<ref name=":4" />

In March 2020, Cox voted against a bill that would require members of Congress to disclose tax liens.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Gligich|first=Daniel|date=2020-03-12|title=With $145k in unpaid taxes, Cox votes against bill to disclose liens, garnish wages|url=http://sjvsun.com/news/politics/facing-145k-in-unpaid-taxes-cox-votes-against-bill-to-disclose-liens-garnish-wages/|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-22|website=The San Joaquin Valley Sun|language=en-US}}</ref> In January 2020, the IRS placed a tax lien on Cox for approximately $87,000 in unpaid income tax for 2016 and approximately $57,000 in unpaid income tax for 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Gligich|first=Daniel|title=IRS hits Cox with lien over $145k in unpaid income taxes|url=http://sjvsun.com/news/politics/irs-hits-cox-with-145k-lien-over-unpaid-income-taxes/|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-22|website=The San Joaquin Valley Sun|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Yeager|first=Joshua|title=Cox, Valadao face questions in business dealings as race for 21st district heats up|url=https://www.visaliatimesdelta.com/story/news/2020/02/19/tj-cox-david-valadao-face-questions-business-dealings/4787198002/|access-date=2020-06-22|website=Visalia Times-Delta and Tulare Advance-Register|language=en}}</ref> Cox was also subject to a $50,000 IRS tax lien in 2017, which Cox claims was the result of his check being stuck to the back of someone else's payment.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Irby|first=Kate|date=April 16, 2019|title=California’s most vulnerable Democrat is still untangling his tax liens heading into 2020|url=https://www.sacbee.com/news/politics-government/capitol-alert/article229297509.html|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=|website=}}</ref>

title: TJ Cox
added: In June 2020, amid COVID-19 lockdowns, Cox pushed to gain preferential access into [[Yosemite National Park]] over the July 4 weekend. He requested two vehicle passes from the U.S. Department of Interior. At the time, Yosemite was only dispersing vehicle passes via a public lottery system. His initial request to circumvent the lottery system was denied due to government ethics rules. When he changed the stated purpose of his visit from personal to professional, saying he would be conducting official business while at the park, he was granted the passes. During his visit to the park, he filmed a short video of himself hiking that he shared with a group called Backcountry Hunters & Anglers, a group that supported the [[Great American Outdoors Act]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Tavlian |first1=Alex |title=Cox under fire for pushing for special access to Yosemite on July 4 |url=http://sjvsun.com/news/politics/cox-under-fire-for-pushing-for-special-access-to-yosemite-on-july-4/ |accessdate=21 October 2020 |work=The San Joaquin Valley Sun |date=3 August 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Tavlian |first1=Alex |title=Washington watchdog hits Cox with complaint over Yosemite trip |url=http://sjvsun.com/news/politics/washington-watchdog-hits-cox-with-complaint-over-yosemite-trip/ |accessdate=21 October 2020 |work=The San Joaquin Valley Sun |date=26 August 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=California congressman pulled rank to get Yosemite tickets, emails indicate |url=https://www.mercurynews.com/2020/08/06/california-congressman-pulled-rank-to-get-yosemite-tickets-emails-indicate/ |accessdate=21 October 2020 |work=The Mercury News |date=6 August 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Irby |first1=Kate |title=Fresno Congressman TJ Cox used his office to skirt Yosemite’s lottery for car passes, emails show |url=https://www.fresnobee.com/news/politics-government/article244710057.html |accessdate=21 October 2020 |publisher=Fresno Bee |date=August 4, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Moffitt |first1=Mike |title=Fresno congressman bypassed lottery to get July 4 Yosemite passes, emails show |url=https://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Fresno-congressman-bypassed-lottery-to-get-July-4-15464921.php |accessdate=21 October 2020 |work=SFGate |date=6 August 2020}}</ref>

added: In 2009, in response to the [[financial crisis of 2007–2008]] and the resulting decline in venture funding, Salesforce began investing in digital companies that used or integrated Salesforce platform.<ref name="Peterson, BI 8/18/2018">{{Cite web|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/how-salesforce-ventures-helped-fortify-salesforce-empire-2018-8|title=Inside Salesforce Ventures — the investment arm behind a $1 billion software ecosystem fueling growth|last1=Peterson|first1=Becky|date=August 18, 2018|website=BusinessInsider.com|publisher=Business Insider|access-date=4 February 2019}}</ref> This eventually became Salesforce Ventures, headed by John Somorjai<ref name="Peterson, BI 8/18/2018" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/09/08/embargoed-salesforce-com-to-set-up-a-venture-capital-fund/|title=Salesforce.com to Set Up a Venture Capital Fund|last1=De La Merced|first1=Michael J.|work=The New York Times|access-date=September 10, 2014}}</ref> Since then various funds have been created to focus on specific areas — in September 2014 SFV set up Salesforce1 Fund, aimed at start-ups creating applications primarily for mobile phones. In December 2018, Salesforce Ventures announced the launch of the Japan Trailblazer Fund, focused on Japanese startups.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/news/2018/12/04/salesforce-100-million-japan-vc-fund-startups.html|title=Salesforce Ventures launches $100 million fund for Japanese startups|last1=Kawamoto|first1=Dawn|date=December 5, 2018|website=San Francisco Business Times|publisher=American City Business Journals.}}</ref>

As of August 2018, Salesforce Ventures reported investments totaling $1.2 billion in 275 companies covering a wide range of business models, including e-commerce (CloudCraze),<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.chicagobusiness.com/article/20170105/BLOGS11/170109932/salesforce-software-maker-cloudcraze-lands-20-million-led-by-insight-venture|title=Salesforce software maker CloudCraze lands $20 million|last1=Pletz|first1=John|date=January 5, 2017|website=Crain's Chicago Business|publisher=Crain Communications|access-date=3 February 2019|quote=Salesforce's venture-capital arm also invested in the deal.}}</ref> [[artificial intelligence]] ([[Figure Eight (company)|Figure Eight]]), online fraud prevention ([[Forter]]),<ref>{{Cite title: 2004 United States presidential election
deleted: * Bush became the first president to be elected to two terms without carrying any of these states in either of his campaigns: California, Hawaii, Illinois, New Jersey, New York, Oregon, Washington and Wisconsin. He was also the first Republican to be elected without ever carrying Vermont in either of his campaigns.
* As of 2020, this election is the last time that the Republican nominee won Colorado, Nevada, New Mexico, or Virginia.
* This is the first time and the only time (as of 2017) New Mexico voted for a Republican since 1988.
* This was the last time that the Republican nominee won Florida, Ohio and Iowa until 2016.
* Due to increasing Democratic support in urban regions, this is the last presidential election the Republican candidate won any of the following urban counties/county equivalents:

** California: [[Fresno County, California|Fresno County]], [[Merced County, California|Merced County]], [[Riverside County, California|Riverside County]], [[San Bernardino County, California|San Bernardino County]], [[San Diego County, California|San Diego County]], [[San Joaquin County, California|San Joaquin County]], [[San Luis Obispo County, California|San Luis Obispo County]], [[Stanislaus County, California|Stanislaus County]], [[Ventura County, California|Ventura County]]
** Colorado: [[Arapahoe County, Colorado|Arapahoe County]], [[Broomfield, Colorado|Broomfield]], [[Jefferson County, Colorado|Jefferson County]]
** Florida: [[Hillsborough County, Florida|Hillsborough County]], [[Osceola County, Florida|Osceola County]]
** Georgia: [[Douglas County, Georgia|Douglas County]], [[Rockdale County, Georgia|Rockdale County]], [[Newton County, Georgia|Newton County]]

title: 1916 United States presidential election
added: The 1916 Republican National Convention was held in [[Chicago]] between June 7 and 10.

A major goal of the party bosses at the convention was to heal the bitter split within the party that had occurred in the 1912 presidential campaign. Although several candidates were openly competing for the 1916 nomination — most prominently Senator [[Elihu Root]] of [[New York (state)|New York]] and Senator [[John W. Weeks]] of [[Massachusetts]] — the party's bosses wanted a moderate who would be acceptable to both factions of the party.

They turned to Supreme Court Justice [[Charles Evans Hughes]], who had been serving on the court since 1910 and had the advantage of not having publicly spoken about political issues in six years. Although he had not actively sought the nomination, Hughes made it known that he would not turn it down. He won the nomination on the third ballot. Former Vice President [[Charles W. Fairbanks]] was nominated as his running mate. As of {{Currentyear}} Hughes remains the only active Supreme Court Justice to be nominated for president by a major political party.
! [[Robert M. La Follette, Sr.|Robert M. La Follette]]!!25 !! 25 !! 23

title: Nithya Raman
added: Raman came under fire for vitriolic behavior in her City Council campaign, after telling supporters "I want you to get angry" at a February campaign rally.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.losfelizledger.com/internet-vitriol-taints-local-city-council-race/|title=Internet Vitriol Taints Local City Council Race|date=October 15, 2020}}</ref> In March, an organization which endorsed Nithya Raman doxed opponent David Ryu by publishing his home address on Twitter, in violation of Twitter rules and California State cyberstalking laws. The tweets were removed, but not before threats were made against Ryu.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.losfelizledger.com/internet-vitriol-taints-local-city-council-race/|title=Internet Vitriol Taints Local City Council Race|date=October 15, 2020}}</ref>

Raman has said she envisions a "much smaller" armed police force in Los Angeles, but has declined to state specifics.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nithyaforthecity.com/transforming-public-safety|title=A NEW APPROACH TO PUBLIC SAFETY IN LA|}}</ref> On July 3, 2020, she signed a pledge<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/nithyavraman/status/1279153187677548544?s=20|}}</ref> to adopt a proposed budget that would reduce the Los Angeles Police Department budget by 98%, but has since clarified that pledge. Organizations which have endorsed Raman, including the Democratic Socialists of America, Los Angeles, have stated their goal is to abolish the police force in Los Angeles, telling the Los Angeles Times in an October 2020 article they support Raman and other "like-minded people" to achieve this goal.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-10-21/la-city-council-race-abolish-police-ryu-raman|title=L.A.'s Ryu-Raman council race reflects wider battle over policing among Democrats and the left Race|date=October 21, 2020}}</ref>

title: Nithya Raman
added: In the March 3, 2020 primary, Raman faced incumbent [[David Ryu]] and screenwriter Sarah Kate Levy.<ref>[https://www.losfelizledger.com/whos-running-against-david-ryu-profile-on-challenger-sarah-kate-levy/ Los Feliz Ledger - "Who's Running Against David Ryu? Profile on Challenger Sarah Kate Levy"]</ref> Ryu received 32,298 votes (44.4%), Raman received 31,502 votes (40.8%), and Sarah Kate Levy received 10,860 votes (14.1%).<ref>{{cite web |title=Official LA County vote tally |url=https://www.lavote.net/docs/rrcc/svc/4085_FINAL_SVC_Precinct_ZBC.pdf |website=Los Angeles County Registrar-Recorder / County Clerk |accessdate=29 October 2020}}</ref> Because no candidate received over fifty percent of the vote, Raman and Ryu advanced to the runoff election, scheduled for November 3, 2020.

title: 2008 United States presidential election in Arkansas
deleted: The 2008 election reflected as, arguably, the last chance Democrats had to be influential in Arkansas. Two years later, all but one Congressional seat was lost to the Republicans in the [[2010 United States elections|midterms]], and then that one was lost in the [[2014 United States elections|2014 midterms]]. Hillary Clinton remained popular in Arkansas less than a decade after her husband was president, and only four years prior to the state being out of reach for the party; her statewide popularity cratered over the next eight years, culminating in a dismal showing in the state in [[2016 United States presidential election|2016]] as the Democratic nominee. (Coincidentally, Clinton won every county Obama did in 2008, except for [[Woodruff County, Arkansas|Woodruff]].)

After this election, Arkansas became increasingly referred to as a "safe" Republican state, with the social liberalism of the Democratic Party failing to resonate in this highly conservative, [[Bible Belt]] state. One should recall that [[Mike Huckabee]], the former governor of the state who took office only three years after Bill Clinton, was a highly-favored contender in the GOP primary.

deleted: On March 15, 2018, the ''New York Times'' reported that Special Counsel [[Robert Mueller]], as part of his inquiry into [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections|Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election]], had previously issued a subpoena for documents from the Trump Organization. Alan S. Futerfas, a lawyer representing the Trump Organization, said: "Since July 2017, we have advised the public that the Trump Organization is fully cooperative with all investigations, including the special counsel, and is responding to their requests."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Schmidt|first1=Michael|last2=Haberman|first2=Maggie|title=Mueller Subpoenas Trump Organization, Demanding Documents About Russia|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/15/us/politics/trump-organization-subpoena-mueller-russia.html|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=21 March 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180315174949/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/15/us/politics/trump-organization-subpoena-mueller-russia.html|archive-date=March 15, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref>

title: The Trump Organization
added: In October 2018, ''The New York Times'' published an exposé arguing that the Trump family evaded over $500 million in [[Gift tax in the United States|gift taxes]] and [[Estate tax in the United States|estate taxes]] on the transfer of Fred Trump's wealth to his children. The alleged schemes involved siphoning money from Fred's companies to his children throughout their lives, and understating the value of transferred properties.<ref name=barstow /> The Trump family denied the allegations.<ref name=barstow /> New York tax authorities opened an investigation into the matter.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/04/us/politics/donald-trump-fred-trump-tax-schemes.html|title=New York Regulators Examine the Trump Family's Tax Schemes|publisher=|accessdate=October 9, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181008185445/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/04/us/politics/donald-trump-fred-trump-tax-schemes.html|archive-date=October 8, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref>

Crackhead Hunter even arranged meetings between Corrupt Joe and Ukrainian oligarchs, all with the goal of enriching his organized crime family. Just like a vacuum cleaner, Crackhead Hunter followed his father around the world, acting as a middleman to collect millions of dollars in illicit bribes. The most shocking part of the scandal, however, was the discovery that Corrupt Joe himself had received cash payouts from the Chinese Communist Party energy company [[CEFC China Energy]]. This meant that Corrupt Joe has not only lied to the American people, but also committed several crimes by hiding this payout from the IRS. This scandal ended Corrupt Joe's chances of being elected President, and he went on to lose the November 3 election in a landslide.

title: Timeline of Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections
added: * '''June 16''': Cassandra Ford of [[Defiance, Ohio]] renames her Twitter account "@Guccifer2" after hearing about Guccifer 2.0 in the news.  A few days later, the GRU registers "@Guccifer_2" for the Guccifer 2.0 persona because @Guccifer2 already existed.<ref name=ThisOhioWomanBuzzfeedNews20181003 />

title: Timeline of Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections
added: * '''November 24''': Perrine informs Butina that Brownell will be joining the NRA delegation in December.{{r|SenatIntelCommitReportVol5|p=599}}

title: Timeline of Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections
added: * '''October 6''': Butina sends Torshin a list of seven potential members for the NRA Moscow delegation, including Cors and his wife, Goldschlanger and his daughter, and Keene and is wife.{{r|SenatIntelCommitReportVol5|pp=600–601}}

title: Timeline of Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections
added: ** Erickson emails Brownell about a meeting with "Russia's highest leader." Brownell responds with interest and forwards the email to his Director of Compliance.{{r|SenatIntelCommitReportVol5|p=603}}

title: Timeline of Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections
added: * '''December 19''': Trump sends Putin a congratulatory letter for being named ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine's "[[Time Person of the Year|Man of the Year]]". He writes, "As you probably have heard, I am a big fan of yours!"{{r|SenatIntelCommitReportVol5|pp=417–418}}

title: Timeline of Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections
added: * '''March 26''': Papadopolous searches the Internet for Andrei Klimov and Ivan Timofeev. Mifsud introduces Papadopolous to Timofeev on April 18.{{r|SenatIntelCommitReportVol5|p=477}}

title: Timeline of Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections
deleted: In the end, it was determined that Russia had not interfered with the 2016 election, and [[Donald Trump]] was found innocent.

title: Timeline of Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections
added: * '''April 10''': Carter Page and Papadopoulos arrange a Skype call in which they discuss outreach to Russia and the [[Caucasus]].{{r|SenatIntelCommitReportVol5|p=479}}

title: Amy Coney Barrett

title: Amy Coney Barrett
added: Before her [[Amy Coney Barrett Supreme Court nomination|nomination]] to the [[Supreme Court]] in 2020, she served as an associate justice in the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit]], a [[U.S. federal court]] with [[appellate jurisdiction]] over federal [[United States district court|district courts]] in [[Wisconsin]], [[Illinois]], and [[Indiana]]. She was nominated to this position by President [[Donald Trump]] on May 8, 2017 after Judge [[John Daniel Tinder]] took [[senior status]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Presidential Nomination 369, 115th United States Congress |date=May 8, 2017 |url=https://www.congress.gov/nomination/115th-congress/369 |publisher=[[United States Congress]] |accessdate=June 30, 2018 |archive-date=June 30, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180630080737/https://www.congress.gov/nomination/115th-congress/369 |url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Staff |title=Trump Names 10 Conservatives It Plans to Nominate to Federal Courts |date=May 8, 2017 |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/politics/ct-trump-judges-federal-courts-20170508-story.html |access-date=September 29, 2017 |archive-date=September 30, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170930035930/http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/politics/ct-trump-judges-federal-courts-20170508-story.html |url-status=live}}</ref>

title: Amy Coney Barrett
added: The politicized nature of her appointment was criticized by numerous Democratic politicians, and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer called her appointment "the most illegitimate process I have ever witnessed in the Senate."<ref>{{cite web |title=After Boycotting Vote, Senate Democrats Continue To Protest ‘Illegitimate’ Amy Coney Barrett Confirmation |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jemimamcevoy/2020/10/22/after-boycotting-vote-senate-democrats-continue-to-protest-illegitimate-amy-coney-barrett-confirmation/ |accessdate=27 October 2020}}</ref>

title: Amy Coney Barrett
deleted: Barrett was on Trump's list of potential Supreme Court nominees since 2017, almost immediately after her court of appeals confirmation.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefings-statements/president-donald-j-trumps-supreme-court-list/ |title=President Donald J. Trump's Supreme Court List |website=The White House}}</ref> In July 2018, after Justice [[Anthony Kennedy]]'s retirement announcement, she was reportedly one of three finalists Trump considered, along with Kavanaugh and Judge [[Raymond Kethledge]].<ref name="WSJ-1">{{Cite news |last1=Nicholas |first1=Peter |last2=Radnofsky |first2=Louise |title=Trump Winnows Down Supreme Court Picks, Focusing on Three |date=July 5, 2018 |newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/trump-weighs-personal-chemistry-legal-record-in-picking-supreme-court-nominee-1530702001?wpisrc=nl_daily202&wpmm=1 |url-access=subscription |access-date=July 5, 2018 |archive-date=July 6, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180706022657/https://www.wsj.com/articles/trump-weighs-personal-chemistry-legal-record-in-picking-supreme-court-nominee-1530702001?wpisrc=nl_daily202&wpmm=1 |url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="Indianapolis Star">{{cite news |title=Indiana's Amy Coney Barrett on list of 25 likely Supreme Court candidates |first=Jessica |last=Estepa |date=June 28, 2018 |newspaper=[[Indianapolis Star]] |url=https://eu.indystar.com/story/news/politics/2018/06/28/supreme-court-nominee-25-likely-candidates-president-trump/741169002/ |access-date=June 29, 2018 |archive-date=September 11, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190911205705/https://www.indystar.com/story/news/politics/2018/06/28/supreme-court-nominee-25-likely-candidates-president-trump/741169002/ |url-status=live}}</ref><ref>Mark Landler & Maggie Haberman, [https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/09/us/politics/brett-kavanaugh-supreme-court.html Brett Kavanaugh to Supreme Court] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.today/20180710011707/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/09/us/politics/brett-kavanaugh-supreme-court.html |date=July 10, 2018 }}, ''The New York Times'' (July 9, 2018).</ref>

After Kavanaugh's selection in 2018, Barrett was viewed as a possible nominee for a future [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]] vacancy.<ref name="chicago.suntimes.com">{{cite web |url=https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/chicago-judge-amy-coney-barrett-passed-over-for-supreme-court-will-stay-in-spotlight/ |title=Judge Amy Coney Barrett passed over for Supreme Court will stay in spotlight |first1=Jon |last1=Seidel |first2=Lynn |last2=Sweet |date=July 18, 2018 |work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]] |accessdate=September 25, 2018}} {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180710034107/https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/chicago-judge-amy-coney-barrett-passed-over-for-supreme-court-will-stay-in-spotlight/ |date=July 10, 2018 }}</ref> Ginsburg died on September 18, 2020, and Barrett was widely mentioned as the front-runner to succeed her.<ref>{{cite web |first1=Geoff |last1=Bennett |first2=Shannon |last2=Pettypiece |first3=Monica |last3=Alba |title=Amy Coney Barrett emerging as a front-runner to fill Ginsburg's Supreme Court seat |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/supreme-court/amy-coney-barrett-emerging-front-runner-fill-ginsburg-s-supreme-n1240547|access-date=September 19, 2020 |publisher=NBC News |language=en|archive-date=September 19, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200919210344/https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/supreme-court/amy-coney-barrett-emerging-front-runner-fill-ginsburg-s-supreme-n1240547|url-status=live}}</ref> On September 26, 2020, Trump announced his intention to nominate Barrett to the Supreme Court.<ref name="official SCOTUS">{{cite news |first1=Steve |last1=Holland |first2=Lawrence |last2=Hurley |first3=Andrew |last3=Chung |title=Trump announces 'brilliant' conservative judge Barrett as Supreme Court pick |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-court-trump/trump-announces-brilliant-conservative-judge-barrett-as-supreme-court-pick-idUSKBN26H0GI |agency=[[Reuters]] |accessdate=September 26, 2020 |archive-date=September 26, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200926214309/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-court-trump/trump-announces-brilliant-conservative-judge-barrett-as-supreme-court-pick-idUSKBN26H0GI |url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/26/us/politics/amy-coney-barrett-supreme-court.html |last1=Baker |first1=Peter |last2=Fandos |first2=Nicholas |date=September 28, 2020 |title=Trump Announces Barrett as Supreme Court Nominee, Describing Her as Heir to Scalia |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=September 28, 2020}}</ref>

Barrett's nomination was generally supported by Republicans, who sought to confirm her before the [[2020 United States presidential election]].<ref name=FandosCochrane>Nicholas Fandos & Emily Cochrane, [https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/29/us/politics/barrett-senate-republicans.html With Friendly Visits to Republicans, Barrett Makes Her Capitol Debut], ''The New York Times'' (September 29, 2020).</ref> She was a favorite among the [[Christian right]] and social conservatives.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news |last=Wolfe |first=Jan |date=September 20, 2020 |title=Notable opinions of U.S. Supreme Court contender Amy Coney Barrett |language=en |agency=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-court-barrett-rulings-factbox-idUSKCN26B0XG|access-date=September 20, 2020|archive-date=September 21, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200921192720/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-court-barrett-rulings-factbox-idUSKCN26B0XG|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>Matthew Brown, [https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/factcheck/2020/09/24/fact-check-amy-coney-barrett-quote-missing-context-viral-meme/3496107001/ Fact check: 'Kingdom of God' comment by SCOTUS contender Amy Coney Barrett lacks context in meme], ''USA Today'' (September 27, 2020): "Barrett is a conservative and a favorite among the religious right"</ref><ref>Stephanie Kirchgaessner, [https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/sep/26/amy-coney-barrett-supreme-court-donald-trump-people-of-praise Amy Coney Barrett: spotlight falls on secretive Catholic group People of Praise], ''The Guardian'' (September 26, 2020): "the Louisiana native and Notre Dame Law graduate, a favorite among Trump's evangelical Christian base"</ref> Democrats generally opposed the nomination, and were opposed to filling the court vacancy while election voting was already underway in many states at the time of the nomination proceedings.<ref name=FandosCochrane/> Democrats were angered by the move to fill the vacancy in a [[List of people nominated to the Supreme Court of the United States in the last year of a presidency|presidential election year]] only 35 days prior to the election, as the Senate Republican majority had refused to consider President Barack Obama's nomination of [[Merrick Garland]] in 2016, more than nine months before the end of his presidency.<ref name=FandosCochrane/><ref>Adam Liptak & Sheryl Gay Stolberg, [https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/19/us/ginsburg-vacancy-garland.html Shadow of Merrick Garland Hangs Over the Next Supreme Court Fight], ''The New York Times'' (September 19, 2020).</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/mcconnell-signals-he-would-push-to-fill-a-supreme-court-vacancy-in-2020-despite-2016-example/2018/10/08/75ee6fce-cb2a-11e8-a360-85875bac0b1f_story.html|title=McConnell signals he would push to fill a Supreme Court vacancy in 2020 despite 2016 example|website=Washington Post|author=Viebeck, Elise|language=en|date=October 9, 2018|access-date=October 12, 2018}}</ref>

In October, the [[American Bar Association]] rated Barrett "well qualified" for the Supreme Court opening, its highest rating.<ref>Wise, Lindsay (October 15, 2020). [https://www.wsj.com/articles/amy-coney-barretts-character-qualifications-to-be-discussed-by-witnesses-11602754203 "Amy Coney Barrett's Character, Qualifications Discussed by Witnesses,"] ''Wall Street Journal''. Retrieved October 18, 2020.</ref> The ABA confined its evaluation to the qualities of "integrity, professional competence, and judicial temperament".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Noel |first1=Randall D. |title=Re: Nomination of Amy Coney Barrett to the Supreme Court of the United States |url=https://www.americanbar.org/content/dam/aba/administrative/government_affairs_office/2020-10-11-barrett-rating-letter.pdf |publisher=American Bar Association |accessdate=October 15, 2020 |date=October 11, 2020}}</ref> Barrett's Supreme Court nomination ceremony was notable for being a part of the [[White House COVID-19 outbreak]]. On October 5, Senator [[Lindsey Graham]] formally scheduled the confirmation hearing,<ref>{{cite web|last=Evans|first=Zachary|date=October 5, 2020|title=Senator Graham Schedules Judiciary Committee Hearings for Amy Coney Barrett|url=https://www.nationalreview.com/news/senator-graham-schedules-judiciary-comittee-hearings-for-amy-coney-barrett/|website=National Review}}</ref> which began on October 12 as planned and lasted four days.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Fandos|first=Nicholas|date=October 12, 2020|title='This is probably not about persuading each other.' Senators began four days of contentious hearings.|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/10/12/us/amy-coney-barrett-live|access-date=October 12, 2020|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Levine|first1=Marianne|last2=Desiderio|first2=Andrew|title=Barrett avoids Democrats' questions on Obamacare, abortion |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/10/13/amy-coney-barrett-confirmation-hearing-democrats-429172 |publisher=Politico |accessdate=October 13, 2020 |date=October 13, 2020}}</ref> On October 22, 2020, the Judiciary Committee reported her confirmation favorably by a 12–0 vote with all 10 Democrats boycotting the committee meeting.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Wise |first1=Lindsay |title=Democrats to Boycott Committee Vote on Amy Coney Barrett |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/democrats-to-boycott-committee-vote-on-amy-coney-barrett-11603324026 |newspaper=Wall Street Journal |accessdate=October 22, 2020 |date=October 21, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.foxnews.com/politics/barrett-hearing-democrats-republicans-nomination-judiciary-committee|title=Senate Judiciary Republicans advance Barrett nomination despite Democrats' boycott, committee rules|first=Tyler|last=Olsen|publisher=Fox News|date=October 22, 2020|accessdate=October 22, 2020}}</ref> On October 25, the Senate voted along almost exact party lines to end debate on the confirmation.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.rollcall.com/2020/10/25/senate-cuts-off-debate-on-barrett-nomination-moves-to-final-vote-on-monday|title=Senate votes to cut off debate on Barrett confirmation|publisher=Rollcall|access-date=October 25, 2020}}</ref> On October 26, the Senate confirmed Barrett to the Supreme Court by a vote of 52–48. Every Republican senator except [[Susan Collins]] voted in favor of the nomination, whereas every member of the [[Senate Democratic Caucus]]<ref>{{cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=Roll Call Vote 115th Congress - 1st Session|url=https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=115&session=1&vote=00255|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=|website=}}</ref> voted in opposition.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Fandos|first=Nicholas|date=October 26, 2020|title=Senate Confirms Barrett, Delivering for Trump and Reshaping the Court|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/26/us/politics/senate-confirms-barrett.html|access-date=October 26, 2020|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Barrett’s confirmation vote was the first since 1870 to succeed without receiving a single vote from the Senate minority party.<ref> "U.S. Senate: Supreme Court Nominations: 1789–Present". www.senate.gov. United States Senate. Retrieved October 27, 2020.</ref><ref name="auto2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/10/26/us/trump-biden-election|title=Amy Coney Barrett Sworn In as Supreme Court Justice, Cementing Conservative Majority|first=Richard|last=Fausset|date=October 27, 2020|accessdate=October 27, 2020|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> Straight party line votes have been called 'the new normal' in the current hyper-partisan Supreme Court confirmation process.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Yarvin |first1=Jessica |last2=Bush |first2=Daniel |title=Is the hyper-partisan Supreme Court confirmation process ‘the new normal’? |url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/nation/is-the-hyper-partisan-supreme-court-confirmation-process-the-new-normal |publisher=PBS NewsHour |accessdate=October 27, 2020 |date=September 13, 2018}}</ref>

The politicized nature of her appointment was criticized by numerous Democratic politicians, and Senate Minority Leader [[Chuck Schumer]] called her appointment "the most illegitimate process I have ever witnessed in the Senate."<ref name="Forbes-McEvoy">{{cite web |title=After Boycotting Vote, Senate Democrats Continue To Protest ‘Illegitimate’ Amy Coney Barrett Confirmation |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jemimamcevoy/2020/10/22/after-boycotting-vote-senate-democrats-continue-to-protest-illegitimate-amy-coney-barrett-confirmation/ |work=Forbes|accessdate=27 October 2020}}</ref> Republicans respond that they are merely exercising indisputable constitutional rights, and that accusations of hypocrisy are nothing more than a tantrum from the left.<ref name="Forbes-McEvoy"/>

title: Amy Coney Barrett
deleted: == Associate Justice of the Supreme Court ==

Barrett became the 103rd [[Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States]] on October 27, 2020. On the evening of the confirmation vote, President [[Donald Trump]] hosted a swearing-in ceremony at the White House. As Barrett requested, [[Justice Clarence Thomas]] administered the oath of office to her,<ref name="auto2"/><ref>{{cite web|author=Sam Dorman|title=Amy Coney Barrett sworn in as Supreme Court Associate Justice at White House ceremony|url=https://www.foxnews.com/politics/amy-coney-barrett-sworn-in-as-supreme-court-associated-justice-at-white-house-ceremony|website=foxnews.com|date=October 26, 2020|accessdate=October 26, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Meagan Vazquez|title=White House holds swearing-in ceremony for Amy Coney Barrett|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/10/26/politics/white-house-amy-coney-barrett-swearing-in/index.html|website=cnn.com|date=October 26, 2020|accessdate=October 26, 2020}}</ref> thus completing the first of two necessary oaths. She took the judicial oath from from Chief Justice [[John Roberts]] on October 27, 2020.<ref>{{Cite press release |title=Press Release Regarding The Honorable Amy Coney Barrett Oath Ceremony |date=October 26, 2020 |publisher=Press Office of the Supreme Court of the United States |location=[[Washington, D.C.]] |url=https://www.supremecourt.gov/publicinfo/press/pressreleases/pr_10-26-20}}</ref>

title: Jason Ravnsborg
added: On the evening on September 12, 2020, Ravnsborg's car fatally struck a 55-year old man on [[U.S. Highway 14]] west of [[Highmore, South Dakota|Highmore]]. The man was walking along the side of the highway. Ravnsborg was uninjured. Ravnsborg initially reported to the [[Hyde County, South Dakota|Hyde County Sheriff's Office]] that he thought he had [[Deer–vehicle collisions|hit a deer]]; the victim's body was discovered the next morning. The crash is being investigated.<ref name=CarCrash>

*Joe Sneve, [https://www.argusleader.com/story/news/2020/09/14/family-speaks-out-after-man-killed-accident-involving-attorney-general-jason-ravnsborg/5791660002/ Family speaks out after man killed in crash involving Attorney General Jason Ravnsborg], ''Sioux Falls Argus Leader'' (September 14, 2020).

*Arielle Zionts, [https://rapidcityjournal.com/news/state-and-regional/sd-attorney-general-involved-but-uninjured-in-fatal-east-river-crash/article_f4326d3f-2d09-5a14-837c-1dc9f6e3a670.html SD Attorney General involved but uninjured in fatal East River crash], ''Rapid City Journal'' (September 13, 2020).</ref>

title: Jason Ravnsborg
deleted: As Ravnsborg campaigned he found many people did not know what the Attorney General did or what services could be provided.  He stated in interviews that he would use social media and other campaign tools to be more transparent and explain to the public what the Attorney General's office does for the state.  He developed a weekly YouTube video series that was called "What's New at the Attorney General's office" where each week a new video told what was going on in the office or what a particular person does in and for the office.<ref name="youtube">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCQkq-5XIbttef_mk5i7iURQ |title=SD Attorney General|publisher=youtube.com|date=May 16, 2019|accessdate=May 16, 2019}}</ref> He then appeared on an episode of the [[South Dakota Public Broadcasting]] Television program "South Dakota Focus" with Stephanie Rissler where he took questions from citizens across the state.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/video/sdf-2415-attorney-general-jason-ravnsborg-uddykx/ |title=SDF 2415 Attorney General Jason Ravnsborg|publisher=pbs.org|date=March 20, 2019|accessdate=May 16, 2019}}</ref>  From that episode he developed another YouTube video series "5 on Fridays with South Dakota Attorney General Jason Ravnsborg" wherein he sought to address questions from the South Dakota Focus program and other topics around the office or through questions he received.<ref name="youtube" />

Joe Biden 2020 presidential campaign
added: Biden has said several times that he would be the first non-[[Ivy League]] president in U.S. history or, on other occasions, the first in 80 or 90 years. However, President [[Ronald Reagan]] went to [[Eureka College]]; [[Jimmy Carter]] graduated from the [[United States Naval Academy]]; and [[Richard Nixon]] graduated from [[Whittier College]] and [[Duke University Law School]].<ref>[[https://www.factcheck.org/2020/10/biden-on-the-stump/ Biden on the stump]]</ref>

title: Joe Biden 2020 presidential campaign
added: While at a fundraiser on June 18, 2019, Biden said one of his greatest strengths was "bringing people together" and pointed to his relationships with senators [[James Eastland]] and [[Herman Talmadge]], two [[racial segregation|segregationists]], as examples. While imitating a [[Southern drawl]], Biden remarked "I was in a caucus with James O. Eastland. He never called me 'boy,' he always called me 'son.'"<ref name="segregation1">{{cite news |last1=Detrow |first1=Scott |title=Democrats Blast Biden For Recalling 'Civil' Relationship With Segregationists |url=https://www.npr.org/2019/06/19/734103488/democrats-blast-biden-for-recalling-civil-relationship-with-segregationists |accessdate=June 19, 2019 |publisher=National Public Radio |date=June 19, 2019}}</ref><ref name="segregation2">{{cite news |last1=Cammarata |first1=Sarah |title=Biden faces backlash for citing his work with two segregationists as a sign of 'civility' |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2019/06/19/joe-biden-segregationist-senators-1370223 |accessdate=June 19, 2019 |work=Politico |date=June 19, 2019}}</ref> Biden's Democratic opponents criticized the remarks, specifically the use of the word "boy".<ref name="segregation2" /> In response, Biden said that he was not meaning to use the term "boy" in [[Boy#Race|its derogatory racial context]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Bradner |first1=Eric |last2=Saenz |first2=Arlette |title=Biden says he didn't intend to use term 'boy' in offensive context |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2019/06/22/politics/joe-biden-boy-segregationists-controversy-cory-booker/index.html |accessdate=August 28, 2019 |work=CNN |date=June 23, 2019}}</ref>

During the first Democratic presidential debate, [[Kamala Harris]] criticized Biden for his comments regarding his past work with segregationist senators and his past opposition to [[desegregation busing]], which had allowed black children like her to attend [[School integration in the United States|integrated schools]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Oliphant |first1=James |title=Harris challenges Biden in breakout U.S. debate performance |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-debate-biden-sanders/harris-goes-after-biden-on-race-in-u-s-presidential-debate-idUSKCN1TS1C5 |website=Reuters |date=June 27, 2019}}</ref> Biden was widely criticized for his debate performance and support for him dropped 10 points.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Flegenheimer |first1=Matt |last2=Burns |first2=Alexander |title=Kamala Harris Makes the Case That Joe Biden Should Pass That Torch to Her |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/06/27/us/politics/kamala-harris-busing-joe-biden.html |website=The New York Times |date=June 27, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Biden's Support Slipped 10 Points After Debates, Poll Shows |url=https://time.com/5617826/primary-debate-biden-harris-poll-slips-10/ |work=Time |date=June 29, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Morin |first1=Rebecca |title=Thursday Democratic debate: Who were the winners and losers |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2019/06/28/democratic-debate-2019-night-2-winners-and-losers/1590319001/ |website=USA Today |date=June 28, 2019}}</ref> President Trump defended Biden, saying Harris was given "too much credit" for her debate with Biden.<ref>{{cite news |title=Trump defends Biden after Democratic debate, says Harris got 'too much credit' |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2020-election/trump-defends-biden-after-democratic-debate-says-harris-got-too-n1024906 |publisher=NBC News |date=June 29, 2019}}</ref>

He never called me 'boy,' he always called me 'son.'"<ref name="segregation1">{{cite news |last1=Detrow |first1=Scott |title=Democrats Blast Biden For Recalling 'Civil' Relationship With Segregationists |url=https://www.npr.org/2019/06/19/734103488/democrats-blast-biden-for-recalling-civil-relationship-with-segregationists |accessdate=June 19, 2019 |publisher=National Public Radio |date=June 19, 2019}}</ref><ref name="segregation2">{{cite news |last1=Cammarata |first1=Sarah |title=Biden faces backlash for citing his work with two segregationists as a sign of 'civility' |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2019/06/19/joe-biden-segregationist-senators-1370223 |accessdate=June 19, 2019 |work=Politico |date=June 19, 2019}}</ref> Biden's Democratic opponents criticized the remarks, specifically the use of the word "boy".<ref name="segregation2" /> In response, Biden said that he was not meaning to use the term "boy" in [[Boy#Race|its derogatory racial context]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Bradner |first1=Eric |last2=Saenz |first2=Arlette |title=Biden says he didn't intend to use term 'boy' in offensive context |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2019/06/22/politics/joe-biden-boy-segregationists-controversy-cory-booker/index.html |accessdate=August 28, 2019 |work=CNN |date=June 23, 2019}}</ref>

added: In May 2020, during an interview on ''[[The Breakfast Club (radio show)|The Breakfast Club]]'' radio show that [[CBS News]] described as "contentious", Biden remarked "If you have a problem figuring out whether you're for me or Trump, then you ain't black".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/05/22/joe-biden-breakfast-club-interview-274490 |title=Biden: 'If you have a problem figuring out whether you're for me or Trump, then you ain't black' |date=May 22, 2020 |author=Quint Forgey |website=Politico|access-date=May 22, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200702014541/https://www.politico.com/news/2020/05/22/joe-biden-breakfast-club-interview-274490|archive-date=July 2, 2020|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/in-contentious-interview-biden-says-black-voters-considering-trump-over-him-aint-black/ |title=In contentious interview, Biden says black voters considering Trump over him "ain't black" |website=CBS News |date=May 22, 2020 |author=Grace Segers}}</ref><ref name="usatodaybc">{{cite web |url=https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2020/05/22/biden-you-aint-black-if-you-cant-decide-between-trump-and-biden/5242706002/ |title=Joe Biden, in testy interview, says 'you ain't black' if you're undecided over him vs. Trump |website=USA Today |author=Nicholas Wu |date=May 22, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/22/biden-you-aint-black-if-you-have-trouble-deciding-between-me-or-trump.html |website=CNBC |date=May 22, 2020 |title=Biden tells African-American radio host: 'You ain't black' if you have trouble deciding between Trump and me |author=Christina Wilkie}}</ref> He later apologized for his remarks.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://news.sky.com/story/joe-biden-tells-radio-host-you-aint-black-if-you-support-donald-trump-11993035 |date=May 22, 2020 |title=Joe Biden apologises after telling radio host 'you ain't black' if you support Donald Trump}}</ref>

deleted: In October of 2020, Corrupt Joe and his crooked son Crackhead Hunter were implicated in the largest scandal in political history. In this scandal, the great journalists at [[Fox News]] and the [[New York Post]] revealed that Crackhead Hunter had used his positions with Ukrainian and Chinese energy firms to sell access to to his father and use bribes to affect US policy. Crackhead Hunter even arranged meetings between Corrupt Joe and Ukrainian oligarchs, all with the goal of enriching his organized crime family. Just like a vacuum cleaner, Crackhead Hunter followed his father around the world, acting as a middleman to collect millions of dollars in illicit bribes. The most shocking part of the scandal, however, was the discovery that Corrupt Joe himself had received cash payouts from the Chinese Communist Party energy company [[CEFC China Energy]]. This meant that Corrupt Joe has not only lied to the American people, but also committed several crimes by hiding this payout from the IRS. This scandal ended Corrupt Joe's chances of being elected President, and he went on to lose the November 3 election in a landslide.

Fire and Fury
added: On January 7, Bannon issued a statement calling Trump Jr. a "patriot and a good man," saying that his comments were directed at [[Paul Manafort]], not Trump Jr.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/07/us/politics/stephen-miller-cnn-trump-bannon-apology.html |title=Bannon Tries Backing Away From Explosive Comments |first1=Jeremy W. |last1=Peters |first2=Michael |last2=Tackett |date=January 7, 2018 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=January 8, 2018 | url-status=live |archivedate=January 8, 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180108222407/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/07/us/politics/stephen-miller-cnn-trump-bannon-apology.html  }}</ref> The next day, on [[MSNBC]]'s ''[[Morning Joe]]'', Wolff denied that Bannon had been talking about Manafort.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cleveland.com/nation/index.ssf/2018/01/michael_wolff_author_of_fire_a.html |title=Michael Wolff, author of "Fire and Fury," contradicts Bannon's explanation |agency=Associated Press |work=The Plain Dealer |date=January 8, 2018 |accessdate=January 8, 2018 |url-status=live |archivedate=January 9, 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180109180854/http://www.cleveland.com/nation/index.ssf/2018/01/michael_wolff_author_of_fire_a.html }}</ref>

Also on January 7, White House senior policy adviser [[Stephen Miller (political advisor)|Stephen Miller]], speaking on CNN's ''[[State of the Union (American TV program)|State of the Union]],'' said: "The book is best understood as a work of very poorly written fiction, and I also will say that the author is a garbage author of a garbage book."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Daniella|first1=Silva|title=Stephen Miller slams 'Fire and Fury' as 'grotesque work of fiction' in tense interview |date=January 7, 2018 |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/stephen-miller-slams-fire-fury-grotesque-work-fiction-tense-interview-n835371|website=NBC News|accessdate=January 9, 2018 |url-status=live |archivedate=January 13, 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113060625/https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/stephen-miller-slams-fire-fury-grotesque-work-fiction-tense-interview-n835371}}</ref> In a January 8 interview with [[Dana Loesch]], [[Mike Pence|Vice President Mike Pence]] described ''Fire and Fury'' as a "book of fiction." He stated that he had not read it, and would not read it, but that reports concerning its contents did not accord with his experience of working with President Trump.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/mike-pence-dismisses-fire-and-fury-as-book-of-fiction/article/2645313 |first=Sarah |last=Westwood |title=Mike Pence dismisses 'Fire and Fury' as 'book of fiction'|date=January 8, 2017|work=[[Washington Examiner]]}}</ref> Over the weekend of January 6–7, [[Rebekah Mercer]], a conservative donor who worked with Bannon on Trump's 2016 campaign and as a part-owner of [[Breitbart News]], distanced herself from Bannon, saying she would no longer provide him with financial backing.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newsday.com/news/nation/bannon-trump-rebekah-mercer-1.15941844 |title=Bannon faces the loss of key backers: Trump and Rebekah Mercer|author=Ngo, Emily|work=Newsday|date=January 7, 2018|accessdate=January 9, 2018}}</ref> On January 9, Bannon announced that he would leave Breitbart News.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-42628201|title=Steve Bannon leaves Breitbart News amid Trump row|work=BBC News|date=January 9, 2018|accessdate=January 9, 2018}}</ref>

title: Susie Lee
deleted: An ethics watchdog group requested that Congress investigate Democratic Rep. Susie Lee after accusing her of a conflict of interest in asking the Small Business Administration (SBA) to expand its coronavirus loan eligibility in a way that they say benefited her husband's business.

Just weeks after Lee's reported request, SBA changed its criteria on April 28 to include the gaming industry. Two weeks later, Full House Resorts, of which both Lee and her husband own millions of dollars in stock and options, received a total of $5.6 million in loans -- a conflict of interest, the Foundation for Accountability and Civic Trust argued in a complaint that was filed.

"A conflict of interest exists," the FACT complaint reads, "when a Member's private affairs appear to, or actually do, conflict with their ability to officially act on behalf of the public interest ... Because the integrity of government action is at risk, the ethics rules require Members to refrain from official action where there is even an inference of a conflict, as well as where there is an actual conflict.” <ref> https://www.foxnews.com/politics/fact-susie-lee-complaint-casinos </ref>

title: Neil Gorsuch Supreme Court nomination
deleted: Scalia's death brought about an unusual situation in which a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] [[President of the United States|president]] had the opportunity to appoint a [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] justice while the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republicans]] controlled the [[United States Senate]], a situation had last arisen in 1895, when [[Grover Cleveland]] nominated [[Rufus Wheeler Peckham]] to the Court.<ref>{{cite web| last=Bomboy| first=Scott| date=August 13, 2014| title=The facts about Supreme Court nominations and Senate control| work=Constitution Daily| url=https://constitutioncenter.org/blog/the-facts-about-supreme-court-nominations-and-senate-control/| publisher=National Constitution Center| location=Philadelphia, Pennsylvania| accessdate=June 15, 2019| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190616230541/https://constitutioncenter.org/blog/the-facts-about-supreme-court-nominations-and-senate-control/| archive-date=June 16, 2019| url-status=live}}</ref> Also, the vacancy occurred during a [[United States presidential election|presidential election year]], the seventh time a seat has become vacant during one since 1900.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.scotusblog.com/2016/02/supreme-court-vacancies-in-presidential-election-years|title=Supreme Court vacancies in presidential election years|date=February 13, 2016|accessdate=February 18, 2016|first=Amy|last=Howe|work=SCOTUSblog|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160217225227/http://www.scotusblog.com/2016/02/supreme-court-vacancies-in-presidential-election-years/|archive-date=February 17, 2016|url-status=live}}</ref>

title: Stephanie Bice
added: In the 2020 5th Congressional District of Oklahoma election, in which Bice won the Republican nomination, her candidacy received heightened criticismfor her hesitant and fractional support of President Donal Trump, as well as her support of Black Lives Matter. Her public comments evidencing reluctant and only partial support of President Trump, and her public statements acknowledging that Black Lives Matter have contributed to her declining support from the Republican voters in the District and the State of Oklahoma. Oklahoma is a traditionally conservative state that was a Trump stronghold in 2016. Bice’s position on these topics and others puts her at odds with typical conservative positions.

title: Mike Lee
added: On October 28, 2020, Senator Lee compared President [[Donald Trump]] to Book of Mormon hero, Captain Moroni. Referring to Trump, Lee told rallygoers in Arizona: “To my Mormon friends, my Latter-day Saint friends, think of him as Captain Moroni.” Lee went on to say that the president “seeks not the praise of the world” and wants only “the well-being and peace of the American people.”<ref>{{cite web|last1=Riess|first1=Jana|title=Sen. Mike Lee is just one example. Latter-day Saint men still like Donald Trump|url=https://www.sltrib.com/religion/2020/10/29/jana-riess-sen-mike-lee/|website=Salt Lake Tribune|date = 29 October 2020|accessdate=30 October 2020}}</ref> Lee’s comparison was met with some backlash. The overwhelming majority of comments on Lee’s Facebook accounts found it to be “shameful” or “blasphemous.”<ref>{{cite web|last1=Romboy|first1=Dennis|title=Sen. Mike Lee explains comparing Donald Trump to Capt. Moroni from Book of Mormon|url=https://www.deseret.com/utah/2020/10/29/21540402/news-sen-mike-lee-compares-donald-trump-to-captain-moroni-from-book-of-mormon|website=Deseret News|date = 30 October 2020|accessdate=31 October 2020}}</ref> In a followup Facebook post, Lee defended the comparison, pointing out that he had praised Trump for his willingness to “threaten[] the established political order” in spite of the “constant ridicule and scorn” to which this has subjected him and his family.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Stauffer|first1=McKenzie|title=Mike Lee issues statement after Captain Moroni-Donald Trump comparison|url=https://kutv.com/news/local/mike-lee-issues-apology-for-captain-moroni-donald-trump-comparison|website=KUTV.com|date = 30 October 2020|accessdate=31 October 2020}}</ref>

At the time Lee chose to extol high praise upon the president, Trump had indeed become the subject of ridicule, scorn, and outrage for his blatant, relentless, and unfounded attacks upon the Republic’s ability to conduct free and fair elections and for his repeated assertion that the only way he would lose the upcoming election was if it was “rigged.”<ref>{{cite web|last1=Packer|first1=George|title=Trump Is Trying to Trick Americans Into Giving Up on Democracy|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2020/09/trump-trying-stoke-panic-about-election/616527/|website=The Atlantic|date = 29 September 2020|accessdate=30 October 2020}}{{cite web|last1=Liptak|first1=Kevin|title=Trump warns of ‘rigged election’ as he uses conspiracy and fear to counter Biden’s convention week|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/17/politics/donald-trump-campaign-swing/index.html|website=CNN.com|date = 18 August 2020|accessdate=31 October 2020}}{{cite web|last1=Nigam|first1=Aanchal|title=Donald Trump Warns Of ‘rigged Election’, Says ‘this Is The Only Way’ Democrats Can Win|url=https://www.republicworld.com/world-news/us-news/trump-indicates-of-rigged-election-at-rnc-2020.html|website=Republic World|date = 25 August 2020|accessdate=31 October 2020}}{{cite web|last1=Goodman|first1=Jack|title=US election 2020: ‘Rigged’ votes, body doubles and other false claims|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/54562611|website=BBC.com|date = 16 October 2020|accessdate=31 October 2020}}{{cite web|last1=Siders|first1=David|title=’Rigged election’ goes from Trump complaint to campaign strategy|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/07/31/trump-rigged-election-campaign-strategy-388884|website=Politico|date = 31 July 2020|accessdate=31 October 2020}}{{cite web|last1=Levine|first1=Sam|title=’Just like propaganda’: the three men enabling Trump’s voter fraud lies|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/oct/26/us-election-voter-fraud-mail-in-ballots|website=The Guardian|date = 26 October 2020|accessdate=31 October 2020}}{{cite web|last1=Huppke|first1=Rex|title=Republicans adopt ‘herd mentality’ to Trump’s dangerous rigged-election rhetoric by staying silent|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/columns/rex-huppke/ct-trump-rigged-election-ballots-mail-fraud-election-biden-huppke-20200916-c5la6itxnjcznekfznc3vwwl2q-story.html|website=Chicago Tribune|date = 16 September 2020|accessdate=31 October 2020}}{{cite web|last1=Wise|first1=Alana|title=Trump Declines To Promise Peaceful Transfer Of Power After Election|url=https://www.npr.org/2020/09/23/916221894/trump-says-he-expect-election-results-to-end-up-at-supreme-court|website=NPR.org|date = 23 September 2020|accessdate=31 October 2020}}</ref> Senator Lee has been careful not to subvert Trump’s attempts to undermine public confidence in the system as a whole and has limited his comments on the integrity of the electoral system to a concession that Utah’s system of mail-in voting appears to have been working well.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Romboy|first1=Dennis|title=Sen. Lee defends President Trump’s distrust of mail-in voting, but says it works in Utah|url=https://www.ksl.com/article/50022506/sen-lee-defends-president-trumps-distrust-of-mail-in-voting-but-says-it-works-in-utah|website=KSL.com|date = 28 September 2020|accessdate=31 October 2020}}</ref>

While Lee has had ample opportunity to distance himself from Trump’s relentless attacks upon the Republic’s ability to conduct free and fair elections, Lee’s supporters have been content to scour the internet in their attempts to remove, where they are able, any information calling attention to Senator Lee’s complicity in Trump’s attempts to undermine public confidence in the integrity of the very foundation of the Republic.
