title: 2020 Summer Olympics
added: On 29 April 2020, health experts expressed concern that the Tokyo Olympics might be cancelled if the pandemic should persist.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Rich|first=Motoko|last2=Keh|first2=Andrew|date=2020-04-28|title=Summer Olympics in 2021? 'Exceedingly Difficult' Without a Coronavirus Vaccine|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/28/sports/olympics/coronavirus-olympics-vaccine-tokyo.html|access-date=2020-05-03|issn=0362-4331|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200501210657/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/28/sports/olympics/coronavirus-olympics-vaccine-tokyo.html/|archive-date=1 May 2020|url-status=live}}</ref> In an interview with Japanese sports daily ''[[Nikkan Sports]]'', Organizing Committee president and former Japanese prime minister [[Yoshirō Mori]] asserted that the Games would be "scrapped" if they could not go ahead in 2021.<ref>{{cite web|date=2020-04-28|title=Next Olympics to be 'scrapped' if 2021 date is missed according to Tokyo 2020 president|url=https://www.rte.ie/sport/olympics/2020/0428/1135246-next-olympics-to-be-scrapped-if-2021-date-is-missed/|website=[[RTÉ.ie]]|access-date=2020-05-03|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200503203934/https://www.rte.ie/sport/olympics/2020/0428/1135246-next-olympics-to-be-scrapped-if-2021-date-is-missed/|archive-date=3 May 2020|url-status=live}}</ref> On 20 May 2020, Thomas Bach expressed in an interview with [[NBC Sports]] that the job of reorganising the Tokyo Games was "a mammoth task" and also admitted that the event would have to be cancelled altogether if it could not take place in the summer of 2021.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/olympics/52747797 |title=IOC's Thomas Bach accepts Tokyo Olympics would have to be cancelled if not held in 2021 |first=Dan |last=Roan |date=20 May 2020 |work=BBC Sport |access-date=21 May 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200521093705/https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/olympics/52747797 |archive-date=21 May 2020 |url-status=live }}</ref> Complete cancellation would cost Japan 4.52 trillion yen (US$41.5 billion), based on operating expenses and loss of tourism activity.<ref name="Costs" />

However, both Bach and Mori expressed optimism about the Games going ahead. [[Indian Olympic Association]] president Narinder Batra and [[World Health Organization]] director and general [[Tedros Adhanom]] also remained optimistic about the event being able to take place in 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|title=IOA President claims Tokyo 2020 Olympics will "definitely" take place|url=https://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1093853/batra-claims-tokyo-2020-definite|date=3 May 2020|website=www.insidethegames.biz|accessdate=2020-05-03|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200505133343/https://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1093853/batra-claims-tokyo-2020-definite|archive-date=5 May 2020|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Wade |first1=Stephen |title=Tokyo Olympics followed up by 3 mega-events -- all in China |url=https://www.hotsr.com/news/2020/may/23/tokyo-olympics-followed-up-by-3-mega-ev/ |accessdate=23 May 2020 |agency=Associated Press |publisher=The Sentinel-Record}}</ref>

title: Rage (Woodward book)
added: Trump wrote on Twitter that "Bob Woodward had my quotes for many months. If he thought they were so bad or dangerous, why didn't he immediately report them in an effort to save lives? Didn’t he have an obligation to do so? No, because he knew they were good and proper answers. Calm, no panic!".<ref name=Guard10Sep>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/sep/10/bob-woodward-trump-coronavirus-deadly|title=Bob Woodward rejects criticism that he sat on Trump 'deadly' virus remarks|author=Victoria Bekiempis|date=10 September|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=11 September 2020}}</ref>

Woodward was criticised for not revealing Trump's thoughts on the [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United States]] prior to the imminent release of the book. Woodward said in an interview that the book would have been able to provide more context than a news story and that "the biggest problem I had, which is always a problem with Trump, is I didn’t know if it was true" and that if he "had done the story at that time about what he knew in February, that's not telling us anything we didn't know".<ref name=Guard10Sep/>

title: COVID-19 pandemic in the United States
added: In October, [[Bain & Company]] reported on the tumultuous changes in consumer behavior before and during the COVID-19 pandemic.<ref name=Bain /> Potentially permanently, they found acceleration towards [[e-commerce]], [[telehealth|online primary healthcare]], livestreamed gym workouts, and moviegoing via subscription television.<ref name=Bain /> Concurrent searches for both low-cost and premium products, and a shift to safety over sustainability, occurred alongside rescinded bans and taxes on single-use plastics, and losses of three to seven years of gains in out-of-home foodservice.<ref name=Bain>{{cite web|url=https://www.bain.com/insights/shaping-the-consumer-of-the-future/|title=Shaping the Consumer of the Future|date= September 23, 2020|vauthors= Faelli F, Rovit S, Apps C, Johns L|publisher=Bain & Company|accessdate=October 3, 2020}}</ref>

title: Columbia University
added: In the early 2000s, professor [[Joseph Massad]], held an elective course called Palestinian and Israeli Politics and Societies at Columbia. Students felt the views he espoused in the course were anti-Israel and some of them tried to disrupt his class and get him fired.<ref name="jps">{{cite journal | title=Academic Freedom and the Teaching of Palestine-Israel: The Columbia Case, Part II | journal=Journal of Palestine Studies | volume=34 | issue=4 | date=January 1, 2005 | issn=0377-919X | doi=10.1525/jps.2005.34.4.75 | pages=75–107 | url=https://online.ucpress.edu/jps/article-abstract/34/4/75/53373/Academic-Freedom-and-the-Teaching-of-Palestine | access-date=September 24, 2020}}</ref> In 2004, students got together with the pro-Israel campus group the [[David Project]] and produced a film called ''Columbia Unbecoming'', accusing Massad and two other professors of intimidating or treating unfairly students with pro-Israel views. The film led to a committee being appointed by Bollinger which exonerated the professors in the spring of 2005.<ref name="report">{{cite web

}}</ref> However, the committee's report criticized Columbia's inadequate grievance procedures.<ref name="bdh05apr7">{{cite web | last=Doob | first=Gabriella | title=Columbia report addresses anti-Semitism charges | website=Brown Daily Herald | date=April 7, 2005 | url=https://www.browndailyherald.com/2005/04/07/columbia-report-addresses-antisemitism-charges/ | access-date=September 25, 2020}}</ref>

title: Geraldine W. Travis
added: Travis was elected to the [[Montana House of Representatives]] from the 43rd district becoming the first black woman to serve in the Montana House of Representatives. The 43rd district represented the Malmstrom Air Force Base and contained over 5,500 people, but only had 138 registered voters. In the general election Travis won with twenty votes against her opponent's five votes after spending $712 during the campaign.<ref name="life" /><ref>{{Cite news |date=November 6, 1974 |title=Montana Has First Black Officeholder |page=3 |work=[[Missoulian]] |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/60954405/the-missoulian/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.vn/1XUSk |archive-date=October 11, 2020 |via=[[Newspapers.com]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |date=November 27, 1974 |title=Votes costly |page=2 |work=[[The Montana Standard]] |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/60954604/the-montana-standard/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.vn/3rMK0 |archive-date=October 11, 2020 |via=[[Newspapers.com]]}}</ref> She lost reelection in 1976.<ref name="life" />

title: Sharice Davids
added: Kansas City [[NPR]] member station [[KCUR]] fact-checked the claims that Yoder and Davids made in separate interviews on their station, and gave Yoder an "F". Yoder said that immigrants were making false asylum claims, and would increase crime. Davids said that she supported single payer health care, but it could not be enacted with Republicans in the White House. Meanwhile she supports short-term goals like allowing Medicare to negotiate drug prices and getting generics to market faster. KCUR said that Davids' claim that teachers aren't paid enough, and can no longer take tax deductions for buying their own school supplies, was "partly true and partly false," since the tax deduction was reinstated.<ref>[https://www.kcur.org/post/we-fact-checked-two-candidates-kansas-3rd-district-and-one-got-f We Fact-Checked The Two Candidates In Kansas' 3rd District, And One Got An 'F'], By Celisa Calacal, KCUR, October 29, 2018</ref>

title: Steele dossier
deleted: A 25-second "pee tape" video of the purported occurrence has been in circulation since at least January 25, 2019. [[Ashley Feinberg]] has written extensively about it and all the reports and sources which have discussed and analyzed it. She describes it as believable but fake.<ref name="Feinberg_9/25/2019">{{cite web | last=Feinberg | first=Ashley | title=The Pee Tape Is Real, but It's Fake | website=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] | url=https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2019/09/inside-the-convincing-fake-trump-pee-tape.html | date=September 25, 2019 | access-date=September 27, 2019}}</ref>

While many people, including Russians, do not believe the "pee tape" incident happened, [[Stanislav Belkovsky]], Russian [[political analyst]] and a founder and director of the National Strategy Institute, disagrees: "Prostitutes around the city say the 'golden shower' orgy story is true".<ref name="Nemtsova_1/20/2017">{{cite web | last=Nemtsova | first=Anna | title=She Met Donald Trump at the Moscow Ritz (Not That Way!) | website=[[The Daily Beast]] | date=January 20, 2017 | url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2017/01/20/she-met-donald-trump-at-the-moscow-ritz-not-that-way | access-date=December 1, 2019}}</ref>

title: Steele dossier
deleted: A footnote in the Mueller Report suggests that Trump may have heard that Russia had incriminating tapes of his behavior.  On October 30, 2016, Michael Cohen exchanged a series of text messages with Giorgi Rtskhiladze, a businessman who had worked with Cohen on Trump's real estate projects. Rtskhiladze reported that he had successfully stopped the "flow of tapes from Russia but not sure if there's anything else. Just so you know … ." Rtskhiladze told investigators that these were compromising tapes of Trump. Cohen told investigators he spoke to Trump about the issue. Rtskhiladze later told investigators "he was told the tapes were fake, but he did not communicate that to Cohen."<ref name="Kessler_4/24/2019"/> ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' reported that "Rtskhiladze's description of the tapes' content tracks with the unverified information included in the Steele dossier".<ref name="Stuart_4/18/2019">{{cite web | last=Stuart | first=Tessa | title=Here's What the Mueller Report Says About the Pee Tape | website=[[Rolling Stone]] | date=April 18, 2019 | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/politics-news/pee-tape-trump-mueller-report-823755/ | access-date=November 6, 2019}}</ref>

Before the 2013 Miss Universe contest in Moscow, Trump was accompanied on his visit to the Las Vegas club "Act" by Crocus Group owner Aras Agalarov and his son Emin, who was involved in the invitation to share "dirt" on Clinton at the [[Trump Tower meeting]].<ref name="Sheth_3/14/2018">{{cite web | last=Sheth | first=Sonam | title=House Intelligence Democrats want to question the Ritz-Carlton in Moscow about the most salacious allegation in the Trump-Russia dossier | website=[[Business Insider]] | date=March 14, 2018 | url=http://www.businessinsider.com/house-democrats-want-to-question-ritz-carlton-moscow-trump-steele-dossier-2018-3 | access-date=April 11, 2020}}</ref> The Agalarovs were also linked to knowledge of Trump's alleged sexual activities in Russia, both in St. Petersburg and the Moscow Ritz Carlton. The dossier's sources reported that Aras Agalarov "would know most of the details of what the Republican presidential candidate had got up to" in St. Petersburg.<ref name="Bertrand_11/10/2017"/> In 2013, when Trump stayed at the Ritz Carlton hotel, "multiple sources", reported that the offer to "send five women to Trump's hotel room that night"<ref name="Corn_Isikoff_3/8/2018"/> came from a Russian who was accompanying Emin Agalarov".<ref name="Raju_Herb_11/10/2017"/> A footnote in the Mueller Report describes how Giorgi Rtskhiladze reported that he had successfully stopped the "flow of{{nbsp}}... compromising tapes of Trump rumored to be held by persons associated with the Russian real estate conglomerate Crocus Group" [owned by Agalarov].<ref name="Kessler_4/24/2019"/>

added: Hours after Supreme Court Justice [[Ruth Bader-Ginsburg]] died in September 2020, Collins wrote on [[Twitter]]: "RIP to the more than 30 million innocent babies that have been murdered during the decades that Ruth Bader Ginsburg defended pro-abortion laws. title: Social policy of the first Donald Trump administration
added: Trump's 2021 budget request included $716 million for the second year of HHS's initiative to end HIV in the United States (an increase of $450 million over the program's actual 2020 budget). At the same time, however, it would have cut the overall HHS budget by 9%.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Mayes|first=Brittany Renee|last2=Liberto|first2=Jennifer|last3=Paletta|first3=Damian|date=10 February 2020|title=Trump 2021 budget: Which department budgets would be cut|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2020/business/trump-budget-2021/|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-10-23|website=Washington Post|language=en}}</ref> Additionally, it would have cut the [[United States Department of Housing and Urban Development|Housing and Urban Development]] (HUD) budget by 15%, including cutting Housing Opportunities for People with AIDS (HOPWA) from $410 million in 2020 to $330 million in 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Analysis of President Trump’s FY 2021 Budget Request|url=https://nlihc.org/resource/analysis-president-trumps-fy-2021-budget-request|access-date=2020-10-23|website=National Low Income Housing Coalition|language=en}}</ref>

title: Ilhan Omar
deleted: In September 2020, a leaked video appeared to link Omar to a [[ballot harvesting]] scheme in [[Minneapolis]]. The incident is still being investigated after Omar was called out by members of both political parties, including [[Tulsi Gabbard]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Evans |first1=Zachary |title=Tulsi Gabbard Cites Project Veritas's Ilhan Omar Video in Call to End Ballot Harvesting |url=https://www.nationalreview.com/news/tulsi-gabbard-cites-project-veritass-ilhan-omar-video-in-call-to-end-ballot-harvesting/ |website=National Review |accessdate=29 September 2020}}</ref>

title: Ilhan Omar
added:
Omar does not self-identify as a socialist, though she has indicated support for socialist ideals.{{cite news |last1=Hasan |first1=Medhi |authorlink1=Mehdi Hasan |title=Is Ilhan Omar Trump's Worst Nightmare? |url=https://theintercept.com/2018/09/20/is-ilhan-omar-donald-trumps-worst-nightmare/ |accessdate=19 August 2019 |work=[[The Intercept#Deconstructed|Deconstructed]] |publisher=[[The Intercept]] |date=20 September 2018 |quote=MH: And just to be clear, and just out of interest, do you, like Alexandra Ocasio-Cortez, define yourself as a socialist, it has become very controversial in the Democratic Party — who is and who isn't willing to say the dreaded S-word?
IO: So for me, what I say to that is I believe in not having extra titles so I am a Democrat. But the ideals of socialism is one that is deep in my values and so I think as Democrats, we all share serious socialism ideals about providing for people and caring about our communities and making sure that government is held accountable in providing for its citizens.}}{{cite news |last1=Alberta |first1=Tim |authorlink1=Tim Alberta |title=The Democrats' Dilemma |url=https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2019/03/08/ilhan-omar-dean-phillips-minnesota-democratic-party-225696 |accessdate=19 August 2019 |work=[[Politico#Politico Magazine|Politico Magazine]] |publisher=[[Capitol News Company]] |date=8 March 2019 |quote=Omar does not openly identify as a democratic socialist like Tlaib and Ocasio-Cortez}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.refinery29.com/en-us/2018/09/207297/democratic-socialists-midwest-young-women-2018-elections|title=The Reds Are Coming—& They're Young, Female, & Determined To Win America's Heartland|last=Van Oot|first=Torey|date=September 10, 2018|work=Refinery29|access-date=February 7, 2018}} Unlike [[Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez]] and [[Rashida Tlaib]], who were also elected to Congress in 2018, Omar was neither a member of nor endorsed by the [[Democratic Socialists of America]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.axios.com/democratic-socialist-candidates-who-have-won-in-2018-midterms-6bf604a3-ee98-4ab3-9e63-349aec324c43.html|title=By the numbers: Democratic socialist victories in the 2018 midterms|last=McCammond|first=Alexi|date=September 14, 2018|work=Axios|access-date=February 7, 2019}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.ilhanomar.com/endorsements/|title=Endorsements - Ilhan Omar|last=Ilhan for Congress|date=2018|website=ilhanomar.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181107173529/https://www.ilhanomar.com/endorsements/|archive-date=November 7, 2018|url-status=|access-date=February 7, 2019}}

title: 2022 United States Senate elections in California
added: The '''2022 United States Senate election in California''' will be held on November 8, 2022, to elect a member of the [[United States Senate]] to represent the [[California|State of California]].

Incumbent one-term [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] U.S. senator [[Kamala Harris]] was [[2016 United States Senate election in California|first elected in 2016]]. She has been chosen as the Democratic vice presidential nominee for the [[2020 United States presidential election|2020 presidential election]] by nominee [[Joe Biden]]. If Biden and Harris win the election, she will vacate her Senate seat, allowing Governor [[Gavin Newsom]] to appoint a replacement. Per California election law, the appointee would serve until the 2022 election.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sfgate.com/politics/article/Kamala-Harris-Senate-seat-appoint-what-happens-VP-15476477.php|title=If Kamala Harris becomes vice president, what happens to her Senate seat?|date=August 11, 2020|website=SFGate}}</ref>

title: China–United States trade war
added: In November 2019, Jim Cramer said that unless China purchased a considerable amount of American goods as a way to prove the validity of the arguments proffered by the the free-trade contingent in the Trump administration, the U.S.-China trade war would continue on for a significant period of time.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Stankiewicz |first1=Kevin |title=Cramer: Ideological divides could make the US-China trade war ‘go on for years’ |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/11/14/jim-cramer-why-the-us-china-trade-war-could-go-on-for-years.html |agency=CNBC |publisher=CNBC |date=November 14 2019}}</ref>

Economist Paul Krugman said in September 2020 that if Democratic candidate Joe Biden won the U.S. presidential election, he should maintain a tough stance against China , but focus more on industrial policy than trade tariffs.<ref>{{cite news |title=U.S. must stand up to China if Biden wins, focus less on trade, Krugman says |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-latam-economy-krugman-idUSKBN26J2SH |agency=Reuters |publisher=Reuters |date=SEPTEMBER 28, 2020}}</ref>

[[Minxin Pei]], a scholar of Chinese politics at California’s Claremont McKenna College, argued that Mr. Xi’s ambition for China’s revival as a worldpower had been revealed as hollow through the continuing trade dispute.<ref name=globeandmailcriticism/>

title: China–United States trade war
added: Columnist [[Thomas Friedman]] explains that China was allowed to join the WTO as a "developing nation," therefore permitting it at the time to impose high tariffs on imports from developed countries as to help its rising industries grow with less competition. Its own exports, however, were subject to very low tariffs to make their exports more profitable.<ref name=Friedman>Friedman, Thomas. [https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/01/opinion/america-china-trump-trade.html?searchResultPosition=1 "The U.S. and China Are Finally Having It Out"], ''New York Times'', May 1, 2018</ref> In the case of autos, for example, China was permitted to set a 25 percent tariff on imports, while the U.S. imposed tariffs at only 2.5 percent. As China's industries matured, it was assumed that they would cut their tariffs, however they have refused to voluntarily lower them.<ref name=Friedman/>

Friedman also points out a number of implied WTO rules that China has ignored. Among those were its government's assistance to help boost many of its industries by providing land at below market prices or by granting loans to companies at very low interest.<ref name=Friedman/> Foreign companies wanting access to their market, however, had barriers placed to make that difficult if not impossible. Among the barriers were requirements by China that foreign companies take on a Chinese partner and give China access to their advanced technologies.<ref name=Friedman/> According to columnist Jeff Ferry, by still supporting and protecting its own industries with such government subsidies and preferential treatment, and ignoring its earlier promises, China's entry into the WTO is being used as an opportunity to "dominate global markets."<ref name=Ferry>Ferry, Jeff. [https://www.clarionledger.com/story/opinion/columnists/2018/10/04/china-tries-hide-illegal-trade-practices-face-tariffs/1520113002/ "China tries to hide illegal trade practices in the face of tariffs"], ''Clarion Ledger'', Oct. 4, 2018</ref>

title: China–United States trade war
deleted: He notes that as a condition for joining the WTO, China committed to lower trade barriers and to follow international rules that had been accepted for decades among most trading nations.<ref name=Lipton/>  President [[Bill Clinton]] in 2000 pushed Congress to approve China’s accession to the WTO, saying that more trade with China would advance America’s economic interests by helping American workers, consumers, and investors.<ref name=Lipton/> Clinton stated his hopes in a speech:

{{quote|For the first time, our companies will be able to sell and distribute products in China made by workers here in America without being forced to relocate manufacturing to China, sell through the Chinese government, or transfer valuable technology—for the first time. We’ll be able to export products without exporting jobs.<ref name=Clinton-speech>Clinton, Bill. [https://www.iatp.org/sites/default/files/Full_Text_of_Clintons_Speech_on_China_Trade_Bi.htm "Full Text of Clinton's Speech on China Trade Bill"], Federal News Service transcript, March 9, 2000</ref>}}

According to columnist Jeff Ferry, by still supporting and protecting its own industries with such government subsidies and preferential treatment, and ignoring its earlier promises, China's entry into the WTO is being used as an opportunity to "dominate global markets."<ref name=Ferry>Ferry, Jeff. [https://www.clarionledger.com/story/opinion/columnists/2018/10/04/china-tries-hide-illegal-trade-practices-face-tariffs/1520113002/ "China tries to hide illegal trade practices in the face of tariffs"], ''Clarion Ledger'', Oct. 4, 2018</ref> Such government subsidies, notes journalist [[John Ivison]], has allowed China to distort markets. He partly credits President Trump's winning the election in 2016 to his promise to fix China's "long-time abuse of the broken international system and unfair practices," which included the theft of intellectual property.<ref>Ivison, John. "PM's Chance as Power Broker," ''The Ottawa Citizen'', Nov. 17, 2018</ref>

Business columnist Betsy McCaughey adds that among the violations of WTO rules, China has turned a blind eye to manufacturing knock-off products and selling them as as real. She notes that 88 percent of [[Counterfeit consumer goods]] that are confiscated by [[Homeland Security]] (DHS) were made in China and Hong Kong.<ref name=McCaughey>[https://www.investors.com/politics/columnists/china-trade-war-tariffs-trump-intellectual-property-theft/ "In China, 'Free' Trade Means Steal What You Want"], ''Investor's Business Daily'', June 20, 2018</ref> Senators [[Chuck Schumer]] and [[Marco Rubio]] have both supported President Trump's tariffs on China. Sen. Rubio referred to the tariffs as a "theft tax," while Sen. Schumer stated that permitting the theft of intellectual property rights to continue would cause "long-term real damage to America."<ref name=McCaughey/>

As a result, Moody's economist [[Mark Zandi]] stated that the current trade conflict which President Trump initiated "has been building for almost 20 years."<ref name=Wiseman>[https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2019/may/15/us-china-trade-conflict-was-20-years-in-the-making/ "US, China trade conflict was 20 years in the making"], ''Washington Times'', May 15, 2019</ref> He adds that in his opinion, "The United States has legitimate grounds to be upset with the Chinese."<ref name=Wiseman/> According to one policy analyst, after joining the WTO, China has flooded other countries with exports while preventing easy access to its own market. Economist [[Eswar Prasad]], for example, stated that "China has effectively used the multilateral trading system to its own advantage, enjoying the benefits of those rules of engagement while not always following those rules in spirit."<ref name=Wiseman/> From 2001 when China joined the WTO, until 2018, factory employment in the U.S. has dropped by 3.1 million workers, although many of those lost jobs were due to robotics and other new technologies.<ref>[https://www.foxbusiness.com/markets/trumps-tariffs-what-they-are-and-how-they-will-work "Trump's tariffs: What they are and how they will work"], ''Fox Business'', July 9, 2018</ref>

title: China–United States trade war
added: However, two years after admission to the WTO, members of the [[Presidency of George W. Bush|Bush Administration]] began complaining publicly about the loss of American manufacturing jobs. In response, Commerce Secretary [[Donald Evans]] said the administration created an "unfair trade practices team" which would focus on apparent Chinese violations of their promises, including "product dumping and intellectual property piracy," along with forced technology transfers from businesses which wanted to launch joint ventures in China. He also noted that during the previous three years, 2.7 million workers had been laid off. [[Joseph Lieberman]] claimed that the Bush administration's attention to China's trade issues was "2.5 million jobs late."<ref>"Task Force to Combat Trading Violations," ''Los Angeles Times'', Sept. 16, 2003</ref>

title: China–United States trade war
added: However, two years after admission to the WTO, members of the [[Presidency of George W. Bush|Bush Administration]] began complaining publicly about the loss of American manufacturing jobs. In response, Commerce Secretary [[Donald Evans]] said the administration created an "unfair trade practices team" which would focus on apparent Chinese violations of their promises, including "product dumping and intellectual property piracy," along with forced technology transfers from businesses which wanted to launch joint ventures in China. He also noted that during the previous three years, 2.7 million workers had been laid off. [[Joseph Lieberman]] claimed that the Bush administration's attention to China's trade issues was "2.5 million jobs late."<ref>[https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-2003-sep-16-fi-trade16-story.html"Task Force to Combat Trading Violations"],''Los Angeles Times'', Sept. 16, 2003</ref>

title: China–United States trade war
added: The trade war reduced the United States' trade deficit with China in 2019, but this trend reversed itself in 2020, with the trade deficit increasing back to its pre–trade war level, while the United States' overall trade deficit has increased. The trade war did not succeed in increasing U.S. manufacturing growth. While it has led to higher employment in certain industries, tariffs led to a net loss of U.S. manufacturing jobs.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Davis |first1=Josh Zumbrun and Bob |title=China Trade War Didn’t Boost U.S. Manufacturing Might |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/china-trade-war-didnt-boost-u-s-manufacturing-might-11603618203 |accessdate=25 October 2020 |work=Wall Street Journal |date=25 October 2020}}</ref>

title: China–United States trade war
deleted: *October 26: A [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of China|Chinese Foreign Ministry]] spokesman, [[Zhao Lijian]] stated that the country was planning to impose sanctions on [[Lockheed Martin]], [[Boeing Defense, Space & Security|Boeing Defense]] and [[Raytheon]], along with some individuals and companies for their involvement in the [[arms sales]] to [[Taiwan]]. The [[US Department of State]] had approved sale of three weapons systems, including [[missiles]], [[sensors]] and [[artillery]], which had a total value of US$1.8 billion.<ref>{{cite_web|url=https://in.reuters.com/article/usa-china-taiwan/china-to-impose-sanctions-on-u-s-firms-over-taiwan-arms-sales-idINKBN27B0P0|title=China to impose sanctions on U.S. firms over Taiwan arms sales|accessdate=26 October 2020|website=Reuters}}</ref>

title: Trumpism
deleted: Some of descriptions and definitions for the term "Trumpism" include:
*An early definition from when he was still running for office comes from political scientist David Edward Tabachnick:
**celebrity, specifically celebrity from a television program where he played a "tough decision-maker",

**nativism and "[[Barack Obama citizenship conspiracy theories|birtherism]]" (the belief that [[Barack Obama]] is not a US citizen because he was not born in the United States, later disavowed by Trump),

**populism made up of a "mish-mash of overt patriotism, economic nationalism, along with a vague commitment to the middle class and an aggressive but indefinite foreign policy".<ref name=hill>{{cite news|first1=David Edward |last1=Tabachnick |date=5 January 2016 |title=The four characteristics of Trumpism|agency=The Hill |url=https://thehill.com/blogs/congress-blog/presidential-campaign/264746-the-four-characteristics-of-trumpism |accessdate=22 September 2020}}</ref>

* Shortly after his election [[Newt Gingrich]] gave a speech on "Understanding Trump and Trumpism",<ref name=gingrich>{{cite web |url=https://www.heritage.org/UnderstandingTrumpism |date=12 December 2017 |title=Understanding Trump and Trumpism |website=Heritage Foundation |last1=Gingrich |first1=Newt |accessdate=22 September 2020}}</ref> which he explained as "kicking over the table" (of establishment politics); "draining the swamp" of politically correct government; speaking directly to voters through twitter.<ref name=GODFREY-gingrich>{{cite journal |journal=The Atlantic |last1=GODFREY |first1=ELAINE |date=17 December 2016 |title=Newt Gingrich Tries to Explain How Trump Will Remake America |accessdate=22 September 2020}}</ref>
Later on during his administration other descriptions included:

* What President Trump "believes on any particular moment on any particular day about any particular subject", rather than a thought out, consistent ideology or point of view. (Republican analyst Ron Christie, who worked for the George W Bush administration);<ref name=bbc>{{cite news|first1=Jon |last1=Sopel |date=20 January 2018 |title=What is Trumpism? |agency=BBC News |accessdate=22 September 2020}}</ref>
*the undoing of "anything that seemed to be a signature Obama-era policy - health, climate change, the Iran nuclear deal, better relations with Cuba". (BBC editor Jon Sopel)<ref name=bbc/>

* "Political phenomenon" whose most important feature is the leaders (Trump's) efforts to escape from "the irksome constraints of values and norms and institutions" of American democracy, using the "generalized distraction and noise" of "disinformation" to wear out and disorient those keeping track of him or opposing him. (journalist Joshua Yaffa)<ref name="Yaffa-NYer-7-9-2020">{{cite journal |last1=Yaffa |first1=Joshua |title=Is Russian Meddling as Dangerous as We Think? |journal=The New Yorker |date=7 September 2020 |url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2020/09/14/is-russian-meddling-as-dangerous-as-we-think |accessdate=21 September 2020}}</ref>

**Cult expert [[Steven Hassan]] argues Trumpism resembles a cult since Trump “employs many of the same techniques as prominent cult leaders and displays many of the same personality traits”; namely a belief that he is "the only one with the answers, the only one who can fix things", a "deep need ... to be the center of attention ... to control others", a lack of empathy for them, and propensity to "lie without hesitation". Trump is supported in the conservative and religious media by a cult-like "black-and-white, all-or-nothing, good-versus-evil, authoritarian view of reality that is mostly fear-based", and by denial of facts that do not "protect the image of the leader."  Growing up Trump was influenced by the beliefs of his father and [[Norman Vincent Peale]]’s church "that the only sin is doubting yourself", but if you avoid that sin "magical things are going to happen".<ref name=vox-hassan>{{cite news|first1=Steve |last1=Hasan |date=26 January 2020 |title=The four characteristics of Trumpism |agency=Vox |url=https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2019/12/13/20992370/trump-republican-party-cult-steven-hassan |accessdate=22 September 2020}}</ref>

*Professor of journalism Peter Beinart, predicts that once Trump is out of office, Trumpism will become "a term of abuse", like [[McCarthyism]], rather than any sort of political philosophy.<ref name="Beinart-mccarthism">{{cite journal |last1=Beinart |first1=Peter |title=Trumpism Is the New McCarthyism |journal=The Atlantic |date=16 July 2020 |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2020/07/trumpism-will-be-new-mccarthyism/614254/ |accessdate=22 September 2020}}</ref>

title: Marc Elias
added: In 2020, Elias founded [http://DemocracyDocket.com Democracy Docket], the leading platform for progressive advocacy and information about voting rights, elections, redistricting and democracy. Democracydocket.com shines a spotlight on voter suppression and offers expert opinion on how to fight it in all of its forms. It also provides detailed information about important the many lawsuits that Elias leads.

title: Marc Elias
added: Ahead of the 2020 Election and amid the Coronavirus pandemic, Elias has filed dozens of lawsuits to expand voter access. <ref> https://www.npr.org/2020/09/22/914431067/step-aside-election-2000-this-years-election-may-be-the-most-litigated-yet</ref> <ref> https://newrepublic.com/article/159279/marc-elias-lawyer-democrat-stop-trump-rigging-2020-election</ref> He coined the term “four pillars” <ref>https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2020/05/27/real-nightmare-scenario-this-falls-elections/ </ref>, referring to four key components to protecting voting by mail: providing prepaid postage, counting mail-in ballots as long as they’re postmarked on or before Election Day; reformed signature matching laws; and allowing local groups to help collect and deliver voted, sealed ballots. <ref> https://www.democracydocket.com/2020/03/safeguard-voting-rights-with-vbm/</ref>

title: Biden–Ukraine conspiracy theory
added: [[David Folkenflik]] of [[NPR]] observed that the ''Post'' story asserted as facts things it presumed to be true. He also noted that the lead author of the ''Post'' story, deputy political editor Emma-Jo Morris, had virtually no previous bylines in reporting, and her most significant prior employment was a nearly four-year position as a producer on Sean Hannity’s Fox News program. Hannity, a close Trump advisor, has repeatedly suggested wrongdoing by Biden in Ukraine.<ref> https://www.npr.org/2020/10/17/924506867/analysis-questionable-n-y-post-scoop-driven-by-ex-hannity-producer-giuliani </ref>

title: Biden–Ukraine conspiracy theory
added: On October 19, a group of over 50 former senior intelligence officials, who had served in the Trump administration as well as the three previous, released an open letter stating that the release of the alleged emails "has all the classic earmarks of a Russian information operation."<ref>{{Cite web|last=Bertrand|first=Natasha|authorlink=Natasha Bertrand|date=October 19, 2020|title=Hunter Biden story is Russian disinfo, dozens of former intel officials say|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/10/19/hunter-biden-story-russian-disinfo-430276|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-10-20|website=[[Politico]]|language=en}}</ref>

title: Biden–Ukraine conspiracy theory
deleted: == Allegations of media bias in reporting ==

On October 29, 2020, award-winning journalist [[Glenn Greenwald]] claimed to have had an article draft censored from [[The Intercept]], a media outlet he co-founded in 2013 as editors allegedly called for the "removal of all sections critical of Joe Biden".<ref>https://greenwald.substack.com/p/my-resignation-from-the-intercept</ref><ref>https://greenwald.substack.com/p/emails-with-intercept-editors-showing</ref> Greenwald's article draft was called ''U.S. Media uses falsehoods to defend Joe Biden from Hunter's emails''.<ref>https://greenwald.substack.com/p/article-on-joe-and-hunter-biden-censored</ref> The incidence caused Greenwald to resign from The Intercept. Greenwald commented on his blog that the New York Post story and its aftermath "provoked extraordinary efforts by a ''de facto'' union of media outlets, Silicon Valley giants and the intelligence community to suppress these stories". Greenwald further complained that "modern media outlets do not air dissent; they quash it".<ref>https://greenwald.substack.com/p/my-resignation-from-the-intercept</ref>

[[Matt Taibbi]], another award-winning journalist, objected to the "suppression" of the New York Post story in an October 24 article called ''With the Hunter Biden Expose, Suppression is a Bigger Scandal Than The Actual Story''. Taibbi referred to "unprecedented efforts to squelch" information about the New York Post story, and a "confederation of press outlets whose loyalty to the Democratic Party now overshadows its obligations to inform".<ref>https://taibbi.substack.com/p/with-the-hunter-biden-expose-suppression-136</ref>

title: First presidency of Donald Trump
added: In September 2020, Brian Murphy — who until August 2020 was the [[Under Secretary of Homeland Security for Intelligence and Analysis]], asserted in a whistleblower complaint that during the shutdown senior [[DHS]] officials sought to inflate the number of known or suspected terrorists who had been apprehended at the border, in an effort to increase support for funding the wall. ''NBC News'' reported that at the time a DHS spokeswoman, [[Katie Waldman]], pushed the network to retract a story that correctly cited only six such apprehensions in the first half of 2018, compared to the nearly 4,000 a year the administration was publicly claiming. The story was not retracted, and Waldman later became the press secretary for vice president [[Mike Pence]] and husband of Trump advisor [[Stephen Miller (political advisor)|Stephen Miller]].<ref>https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/immigration/dhs-spokeswoman-pushed-nbc-news-retract-accurate-story-about-terrorists-n1239702</ref><ref>https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/national-security/whistleblower-says-top-dhs-officials-distorted-intel-match-trump-statements-n1239685</ref>

title: First presidency of Donald Trump
added: President Trump would later announce on October 2, via [[Twitter]] that both he and [[First Lady Melania Trump|Melania Trump]] tested positive for [[COVID-19]], and would begin quarantining at the White House. This came after an advisor to the president, [[Hope Hicks]], also tested positive for the virus herself, with that announcement coming just two hours before the President himself was confirmed to have COVID-19.

Racial views of Donald Trump
deleted: In June 2020, Facebook removed Trump campaign ads that included an upside down red triangle, a symbol which the Nazis had used to label opponents of their regime. The Trump campaign claimed that the symbol was used by [[Antifa (United States)|Antifa]], but experts contend that this is inaccurate and some critics viewed the symbol as a racist [[Dog-whistle politics|dog whistle]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Morrison|first=Sara|date=June 18, 2020|title=Facebook takes down another Trump campaign ad, this time for Nazi imagery|url=https://www.vox.com/recode/2020/6/18/21295226/facebook-trump-campaign-nazi-symbol-antifa|access-date=June 22, 2020|website=Vox|language=en}}</ref> Facebook stated that "We removed these posts and ads for violating our policy against organized hate."<ref>{{Cite news|last=Karni|first=Annie|date=June 18, 2020|title=Facebook Removes Trump Ads Displaying Symbol Used by Nazis|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/18/us/politics/facebook-trump-ads-antifa-red-triangle.html|access-date=June 21, 2020|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

title: Anthony Kennedy
added: On August 4, 2010, [[Dahlia Lithwick]] wrote about Judge [[Vaughn R. Walker]]'s ruling that overturned California's [[California Proposition 8|Proposition 8]] banning same-sex marriage, Walker "is not Anthony Kennedy. But when the chips are down, he certainly knows how to write like him. I count—in his opinion today—seven citations to Justice Kennedy's 1996 opinion in ''Romer v. Evans'' ... and eight citations to his 2003 decision in ''Lawrence v. Texas'' ... In a stunning decision this afternoon ... Walker trod heavily on the path Kennedy has blazed on gay rights."<ref>{{cite web|title=A Brilliant Ruling|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/jurisprudence/2010/08/a_brilliant_ruling.html|work=Slate|accessdate=March 23, 2012|author=Dahlia Lithwick|date=August 4, 2010}}</ref> The next day, Lithwick said on ABC's ''[[Good Morning America]]'', "Walker's ruling that California's ban on same-sex marriage is unconstitutional was aimed at one man: Justice Anthony Kennedy."<ref>{{cite news|title=Proposition 8 Ruling Takes Aim at Justice Kenedy|url=https://abcnews.go.com/blogs/politics/2010/08/proposition-8-ruling-takes-aim-at-justice-kennedy/|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=March 23, 2012}}</ref>

title: Postal voting in the 2020 United States elections
added: On October 18, 2020, a ballot drop-off box in [[Baldwin Park, California]] was set on fire, destroying up to 100 ballots. As of October 19, the case is being investigated as potential arson.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-10-19/ballot-box-fire-baldwin-park-may-be-arson|title=Ballot box fire in Baldwin Park may be arson, officials say|work=The Los Angeles Times|date=October 19, 2020|accessdate=October 19, 2020|first=Hayley|last=Smith}}</ref>

title: Postal voting in the 2020 United States elections
added: On October 28, the Supreme Court denied a request from Republicans and the Trump campaign to allow ballots to be received up to three days after election day, rather than the nine day limit that had been set by the State Board of Elections amidst the pandemic.<ref>https://www.cnn.com/2020/10/28/politics/north-carolina-supreme-court-nine-days/index.html</ref>

title: Postal voting in the 2020 United States elections
added: On October 28, the Supreme Court denied a request from Republicans and the Trump campaign to allow ballots to be received up to three days after election dayin North Carolina, rather than the nine day limit that had been set by the State Board of Elections amidst the pandemic.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/10/28/politics/north-carolina-supreme-court-nine-days/index.html|title=North Carolina can count votes received 9 days after Election Day, Supreme Court rules|first=Ariane de Vogue, CNN Supreme Court|last=Reporter|website=CNN}}</ref>

title: 2020 United States presidential debates
deleted: Entering into the debate, Biden had a significant and persistent lead in the polls. Biden's lead was compounded by a cash crunch in Trump's campaign, with Biden's campaign donations improving significantly.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Goldmacher |first1=Shane |last2=Haberman |first2=Maggie |title=How Trump’s Billion-Dollar Campaign Lost Its Cash Advantage |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/07/us/politics/trump-election-campaign-fundraising.html |accessdate=October 2, 2020 |work=The New York Times |date=September 7, 2020}}</ref> With five weeks to go before election day, the debate was seen as one of Trump's last opportunities to turn his campaign around.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Goldmacher |first1=Shane |last2=Nagourney |first2=Adam |title=Biden and Trump’s First Debate: Full Guide |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/29/us/politics/debate-guide-presidential.html |work=The New York Times |date=September 30, 2020}}</ref> For Biden, the debate presented little opportunity to improve his situation, while posing a risk of damaging his lead should he make a mistake or perform poorly.{{cn|date=October 2020}}

**Be a [[Natural-born-citizen_clause|natural-born citizen]] of the United States and have been a resident of the United States for fourteen years as of [[United States presidential inauguration|taking office]].

*** [[Article One of the United States Constitution#Clause 7: Judgment in cases of impeachment; Punishment on conviction|Article I, Section 3, Clause 7]], gives the U.S. Senate the option of forever disqualifying anyone convicted in an impeachment case from holding any federal office.<ref>{{cite web| title=Article I| url=https://system.uslegal.com/u-s-constitution/article-i/| work=US Legal System| publisher=USLegal| accessdate=June 15, 2018}}</ref>

*** [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution#Participants in rebellion|Section 3 of the 14th Amendment]] prohibits anyone who swore an oath to support the Constitution, and later rebelled against the United States, from becoming president. However, this disqualification can be lifted by a two-thirds vote of each house of Congress.<ref>{{cite web| last=Moreno| first=Paul| title=Articles on Amendment XIV: Disqualification for Rebellion| url=https://www.heritage.org/constitution/#!/amendments/14/essays/173/disqualification-for-rebellion| work=The Heritage Guide to the Constitution| publisher=The Heritage Foundation| accessdate=June 15, 2018}}</ref>

*** The [[Twenty-second Amendment to the United States Constitution|22nd Amendment]] prohibits anyone from being elected to the presidency more than twice (or once if the person serves as president or acting president for more than two years of a presidential term to which someone else was originally elected).<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Peabody |first1=Bruce G. |last2=Gant |first2=Scott E. |date=February 1999 |title=The Twice and Future President: Constitutional Interstices and the Twenty-Second Amendment |url=http://alpha.fdu.edu/~peabody/Twice_and_Future_President.html |journal=Minnesota Law Review |publisher=University of Minnesota Law School |location=Minneapolis |volume=83 |issue=3 |pages=565–635 |access-date=June 12, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115121046/http://alpha.fdu.edu/~peabody/Twice_and_Future_President.html |archive-date=January 15, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Albert|first=Richard|title=The Evolving Vice Presidency|journal=Temple Law Review|volume=78|issue=4|pages=812–893|publisher=Temple University of the [[Commonwealth System of Higher Education]]|location=Philadelphia|date=Winter 2005|url=https://heinonline.org/HOL/LandingPage?handle=hein.journals/temple78&div=33&page=}}</ref>

title: 2020 United States presidential debates
added: On the subject of national security, both candidates were asked to speak about the newly found report about Iranian and [[Russian interference in the 2020 United States elections|Russian interference in the ongoing election]]. In his response, Biden stated that both countries would "pay a price", and expressed his concerns over Russian misinformation sent to [[Rudy Giuliani]], who he called a "Russian pawn".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.sky.com/story/us-election-2020-biden-renews-attack-on-trumps-covid-19-record-in-final-debate-12111814|title=US Election 2020: Biden and Trump argue over COVID-19, race and Russian interference in final debate|date=October 23, 2020|author=Wil Longbottom|website=Sky News|access-date=October 23, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2020/10/us-presidential-debate-trump-biden-iran-emails.html|title=Trump, Biden talk reported Iranian election interference at final debate|date=October 23, 2020|author=Adam Lucente|website=Al-Monitor|access-date=October 23, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.foxnews.com/politics/biden-debate-giuliani-russian-pawn-hunter-biden-story|title=Biden slams Trump ally Rudy Giuliani as ‘Russian pawn’ in 2nd debate|date=October 23, 2020|author=Vandana Rambaran|website=FOX News|access-date=October 23, 2020}}</ref> Dodging the question, Trump responded by bringing up a false claim of Biden receiving money from Russia, which Biden later denied.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/10/22/politics/fact-check-final-presidential-election-debate/index.html|title=Fact check: Toned-down Trump continues his onslaught of falsehoods|date=October 23, 2020|website=CNN|access-date=October 23, 2020}}</ref>

After Biden brought up Trump's newly released [[Tax returns of Donald Trump|tax returns]], along with Trump's secret bank account in China, Trump claimed that he paid millions in taxes.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thehill.com/policy/finance/522391-biden-presses-trump-to-release-tax-returns-after-report-on-china-bank-account|title=Biden presses Trump to release tax returns after report on China bank account|date=October 22, 2020|author=Naomi Jagoda|website=The Hill|access-date=October 23, 2020}}</ref> Biden replied by stating: "Release your tax returns, or stop talking about corruption."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nowthisnews.com/politics/biden-confronts-trump-at-final-debate-release-your-tax-returns-or-stop-talking-about|title=Biden Confronts Trump At Final Debate: "Release Your Tax Returns, Or Stop Talking About Corruption"|date=October 22, 2020|author=Johanna Silver|website=Now This|access-date=October 23, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2020/10/23/926844747/trump-and-biden-had-a-real-debate-and-4-other-takeaways|title=Trump And Biden Had A Real Debate, And 4 Other Takeaways|date=October 23, 2020|author=Deirdre Walsh|website=NPR|access-date=October 23, 2020}}</ref>

title: Ed Markey
added: On October 10, 2002, Markey voted in favor of the [[Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Iraq Resolution of 2002]], authorizing the use of the [[United States Armed Forces]] against [[Saddam Hussein]]'s Iraq government in what would be known as [[Operation Iraqi Freedom]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Iraq War Resolution, Roll Call Vote - House|url=http://clerk.house.gov/cgi-bin/vote.asp?year=2002&rollnumber=455|website=clerk.house.gov|date=October 10, 2002|access-date=September 1, 2020}}</ref>  As of March, 2020, Markey has stated that voting for the War in Iraq was a "mistake," and has claimed that he voted for the war because "George Bush lied, Donald Rumsfeld lied, Dick Cheney lied to the American people about the presence of nuclear weapons in Iraq. I’m still angry about that lie to the American people."<ref>{{cite-web|url=https://www.bostonherald.com/2020/03/02/old-iraq-syria-votes-come-back-to-haunt-markey/|title=Old Iraq, Syria votes come back to haunt Markey|author=Peter Lucas|publisher=Boston Herald|date=March 2, 2020|access-date=September 1, 2020}}</ref>

title: Conspiracy theories related to the Trump–Ukraine scandal
Conspiracy theories related to the Trump–Ukraine scandal
deleted: On October 14, 2020, The ''[[New York Post]]'' reports that newly uncovered emails suggest [[Hunter Biden]] introduced his father, then [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Joe Biden]] to a top executive at [[Ukrainian]] natural gas firm [[Burisma|Burisma Holdings]]. <ref>{{cite web |title=Smoking-gun email reveals how Hunter Biden introduced Ukrainian businessman to VP dad |url=https://nypost.com/2020/10/14/email-reveals-how-hunter-biden-introduced-ukrainian-biz-man-to-dad/ |website=New York Post |publisher=New York Post |accessdate=14 October 2020}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web |title=Biden camp hits back at Hunter Biden email report suggesting then-VP met with Burisma exec |url=https://www.foxnews.com/politics/biden-camp-hits-back-at-hunter-biden-email-report-suggesting-then-vp-met-with-burisma-exec |website=Fox News |publisher=Fox News |accessdate=14 October 2020}}</ref>  [[Joe Biden 2020 presidential campaign|Joe Biden's presidential campaign]] denies such a meeting. <ref>{{cite web |title=BREAKING NEWS: Joe Biden's campaign DENIES he met Hunter's Ukrainian business partner despite email showing him thanking VP's son for 'opportunity to meet' - as pictures surface of him with a 'crack pipe' |url=https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-8838939/Joe-Biden-met-son-Hunters-Ukrainian-energy-contacts.html |website=Daily Mail UK |publisher=Daily Mail |accessdate=14 October 2020}}</ref>

title: Conspiracy theories related to the Trump–Ukraine scandal
Conspiracy theories related to the Trump–Ukraine scandal
Conspiracy theories related to the Trump–Ukraine scandal
deleted: Trump and his allies have also promoted a conspiracy theory that Joe Biden and his son, Hunter, were engaged in corrupt activities in Ukraine. Trump's defense team promoted this conspiracy theory during his impeachment trial, and Trump has said he planned to make it a major issue during the 2020 campaign, while a Republican-controlled Senate committee ramped up an investigation in spring 2020. Trump's personal attorney, [[Rudy Giuliani]], spearheaded an effort to gather information in Ukraine to advance the conspiracy theory, and attorney general Barr confirmed that the Justice Department created an "intake process" to review Giuliani's findings.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/02/10/politics/justice-department-rudy-giuliani-ukraine/index.html|title=Barr confirms Justice Department is receiving Giuliani information about Ukraine|first=David Shortell|last=CNN|website=CNN}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/trump-impeachment-inquiry/trump-impeachment-defense-team-turns-attention-bidens-burisma-n1124231|title=Trump impeachment defense team turns attention to Bidens, Burisma|website=NBC News}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/486054-trump-says-biden-ukraine-dealings-will-be-a-major-campaign-issue|title=Trump says Biden Ukraine dealings will be a 'major' campaign issue|first=Lisa|last=Conley|date=March 4, 2020|website=TheHill}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/20/us/politics/trump-biden-subpoena.html|title=Senate Panel, Urged On by Trump, Subpoenas Biden-Related Material|first=Nicholas|last=Fandos|date=May 20, 2020|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> The conspiracy theory asserts that Hunter Biden was paid a large sum of money by a Ukrainian firm, [[Burisma Holdings]], to take a job for which he was unqualified, as a means for Burisma to influence then-vice president Joe Biden, who then extorted Ukraine for $1 billion to fire a prosecutor so as to prevent Hunter Biden from being investigated for corruption. This narrative has been found to be false.{{refn|<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/in-depth/news/world/2019/10/10/trumps-biden-ukraine-natural-gas-conspiracy-theory-false-but-alive/3851728002/|title=Trump's Biden-Ukraine natural gas conspiracy theory: False, but alive|website=USA Today |access-date=December 17, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2019/sep/30/trump-impeachment-five-conspiracy-theories-ukraine-dilemma|title=Five fantasies Trump is pushing about the Ukraine scandal – and the truth |website=The Guardian |access-date=December 17, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/trump-impeachment-inquiry/trump-pushing-baseless-conspiracy-about-bidens-china-here-s-what-n1062551|title=Trump is pushing a baseless conspiracy about the Bidens and China. Here's what we know. |publisher=NBC News |access-date=December 17, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2020-election/there-s-no-evidence-trump-s-biden-ukraine-accusations-what-n1057851|title=There's no evidence for Trump's Biden-Ukraine accusations. What really happened?|publisher=NBC News |access-date=December 17, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2019/9/23/20879611/joe-biden-hunter-biden-ukraine-corruption-prosecutor-burisma-donald-trump-whistleblower-complaint|title=The facts behind Trump's bogus accusations about Biden and Ukraine|website=Vox |access-date=December 17, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/the-invention-of-the-conspiracy-theory-on-biden-and-ukraine|title=The Invention of the Conspiracy Theory on Biden and Ukraine|website=The New Yorker |access-date=December 9, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/internet/sondland-testified-misleading-ukraine-story-spread-among-conservatives-social-media-n1087511|title=As Sondland testified, a misleading Ukraine story spread among conservatives on social media|publisher=NBC News |access-date=November 21, 2019}}</ref>}} Hunter Biden did take a high-paying job with Burisma, but involving matters for which he was qualified, and there is no evidence he was peddling influence with his father. Vice president Biden did withhold $1 billion in government aid to Ukraine, but for the opposite reason the conspiracy theory asserts: as a matter of American and international policy to induce Ukraine to remove a corrupt and ineffective prosecutor who was not assertively investigating Burisma. Trump defended the fired prosecutor, [[Viktor Shokin]], “who a lot of people said was a great prosecutor and they took him off.”<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/trump-continues-push-debunked-ukraine-conspiracy-theory/story?id=67228100|title=Trump continues to push debunked Ukraine conspiracy theory|first=A. B. C.|last=News|website=ABC News}}</ref> In a widely-circulated 2018 video, a portion of which was included in a Trump campaign ad, Joe Biden is seen taking credit for Shokin's firing, but not for the reason the conspiracy theory and Trump ad contend.<ref name="auto2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.factcheck.org/2019/10/fact-trump-tv-ad-misleads-on-biden-and-ukraine/|title=Fact: Trump TV Ad Misleads on Biden and Ukraine|first1=Eugene|last1=Kiely|first2=Robert|last2=Farley|date=October 9, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2019/oct/11/donald-trump/trump-ad-misleads-about-biden-ukraine-and-prosecut/|title=PolitiFact - Donald Trump ad misleads about Joe Biden, Ukraine and the prosecutor|website=@politifact}}</ref>

In September 2019, Shokin signed an affidavit asserting his beliefs — rather than assertions of facts — that Joe Biden engineered his removal from office to prevent an investigation into Burisma and Hunter Biden. Giuliani promoted the affidavit in television appearances, asserting that Shokin "says under oath" that he was investigating Hunter Biden when he was fired.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.politifact.com/article/2019/oct/02/fact-checking-rudy-giulianis-claims-about-joe-bide/|title=PolitiFact - The inaccurate or unproven things Rudy Giuliani said about Ukraine on 'This Week'|website=@politifact}}</ref> The affidavit notes that it was provided "at the request of lawyers acting for [[Dmitry Firtash]]...for use in legal proceedings in Austria."<ref name="auto2"/> Firtash, a Ukrainian oligarch, had for five years been living in Austria, figthing extradition to the United States where he was under indictment for a bribery scheme.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/fighting-extradition-ukrainian-tycoon-aligns-legal-strategy-with-trump-camp-11571736603|title=Fighting Extradition, Ukrainian Tycoon Aligns Legal Strategy With Trump Camp|first=Warren P. Strobel and James|last=Marson|date=October 22, 2019|via=www.wsj.com}}</ref> Since July 2019, Fitrash's lawyers included [[Joseph diGenova]] and his wife [[Victoria Toensing]], close Trump and Giuliani associates who are regular guests on [[Sean Hannity]]'s Fox News program.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/trump-impeachment-inquiry/ukrainian-oligarch-firtash-linked-giuliani-pals-gas-deals-biden-dirt-n1067516|title=Oligarch Firtash linked to Giuliani pals' gas deals and Biden research|website=NBC News}}</ref> ''The New York Times'' reported that Giuliani had directed [[Lev Parnas]] to recommend to Firtash that he hire diGenova and Toensing, with the proposition that Firtash could help to provide compromising information on Biden, which Parnas's attorney described was "part of any potential resolution to [Firtash's] extradition matter".<ref name="auto1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/25/us/giuliani-ukraine-oligarchs.html|title=Why Giuliani Singled Out 2 Ukrainian Oligarchs to Help Look for Dirt|first1=Jo|last1=Becker|first2=Walt|last2=Bogdanich|first3=Maggie|last3=Haberman|first4=Ben|last4=Protess|date=November 25, 2019|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> ''The Washington Post'' reported that in mid-August 2019, Toensing and diGenova secured a rare face-to-face meeting with attorney general [[Bill Barr]] to argue the Firtash charges should be dropped.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/prosecutors-flagged-possible-ties-between-ukrainian-gas-tycoon-and-giuliani-associates/2019/10/22/4ee22e7c-f020-11e9-b648-76bcf86eb67e_story.html |date=October 22, 2019 |title=Prosecutors flagged possible ties between Ukrainian gas tycoon and Giuliani associates |first1=Matt |last1=Zapotosky |last2=Helderman |first2=Rosalind S. Helderman |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=October 25, 2019 }}</ref> Prior to that meeting, Barr had been briefed in detail on the initial whistleblower complaint within the CIA that had been forwarded to the Justice Department, as well as on Giuliani's activities in Ukraine. Barr declined to intervene in the Firtash case.<ref name="auto1"/> ''Bloomberg News'' reported that its sources told them that Giuliani's high-profile publicity of the Shokin affidavit had greatly reduced the chances of the Justice Department dropping the charges against Firtash, as it would appear to be a political ''quid pro quo''.<ref>{{Cite news | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-10-18/to-win-giuliani-s-help-oligarch-s-allies-pursued-biden-dirt |work=Bloomberg News |title=To Win Giuliani's Help, Oligarch's Allies Pursued Biden Dirt |date=October 18, 2019 |first1=Stephanie |last1=Baker |first2=Irina |last2=Reznik |accessdate=October 19, 2019 }}</ref> diGenova has said he has known Barr for decades, as they both worked in the Reagan/Bush Justice Department.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/11/01/politics/parnas-firtash-giuliani-ties/index.html |accessdate=January 7, 2020 |title='I'm the best-paid interpreter in the world': Indicted Giuliani associate touted windfall from Ukrainian oligarch|first1=Vicky |last1=Ward |first2=Marshall |last2=Cohen |date=November 1, 2019 |website=CNN}}</ref>

Firtash made his fortune brokering Ukrainian imports of natural gas from the Russian firm [[Gazprom]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/01/us/paul-manafort-ukraine-donald-trump.html |title=How Paul Manafort Wielded Power in Ukraine Before Advising Donald Trump |first1=Steven Lee |last1=Myers|first2=Andrew E.|last2=Kramer |date=July 31, 2016|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=January 7, 2020 }}</ref> As vice president, Joe Biden had urged the Ukrainian government to eliminate middlemen such as Firtash from the country's natural gas industry, and to reduce the country's reliance on imports of Russian natural gas. Firtash denied involvement in collecting or financing damaging information on the Bidens.<ref name="auto1"/> In 2017, the Justice Department characterized him as an "upper echelon (associate) of Russian organized crime".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2017/07/26/feds-call-ex-manafort-associate-dmytro-firtash-top-tier-player-russian-organized-crime/514131001/ |title=Feds call ex-Manafort associate Dmytro Firtash a top-tier player in Russian organized crime|first=Doug|last=Stanglin|newspaper=USA Today |date=July 26, 2017 |accessdate=November 19, 2019 }}</ref>

In May 2020, Ukrainian lawmaker [[Andrii Derkach]], an associate of Rudy Giuliani with links to Russian intelligence, released snippets of recordings of Joe Biden speaking with [[Petro Poroshenko]], the Ukrainian president during the years Hunter Biden worked for Burisma.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/ukrainian-lawmaker-releases-leaked-phone-calls-of-biden-and-poroshenko/2020/05/19/cc1e6030-9a26-11ea-b60c-3be060a4f8e1_story.html|title=Ukrainian lawmaker releases leaked phone calls of Biden and Poroshenko|first1=Paul|last1=Sonne|first2=Rosalind S. |last2=Helderman |website=Washington Post}}</ref> The recordings, which were not verified as authentic and appeared heavily edited, showed Biden linking loan guarantees for Ukraine to the ouster of the country’s prosecutor general. The recordings did not provide evidence to support the ongoing conspiracy theory that Biden wanted the prosecutor fired to protect his son.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Sonne|first1=Paul|last2=Helderman|first2=Rosalind S.|last3=Dawsey|first3=Josh|last4=Stern|first4=David L.|date=June 30, 2020|title=Hunt for Biden tapes in Ukraine by Trump allies revives prospect of foreign interference|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/for-months-trump-allies-hunted-for-tapes-of-biden-in-ukraine-now-theyre-turning-up/2020/06/30/f3aeaba8-a67b-11ea-8681-7d471bf20207_story.html|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-30|website=[[The Washington Post]]|language=en}}</ref> Poroshenko denied In June 2020 that Joe Biden ever approached him about Burisma and characterized the recordings as fake.<ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=June 26, 2020|title=Senate panel demands testimony from ex-Obama officials in revived Biden probe|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/06/26/senate-hunter-biden-documents-341817|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-29|website=[[Politico]]|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Seddiq|first=Oma|date=June 21, 2020|title=Former Ukrainian president says Biden never pressed him on Burisma|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/06/21/ukraine-president-hunter-joe-biden-burisma-331779|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-29|website=[[Politico]]|language=en}}</ref> [[One America News]], a favorite news outlet of Trump's that features conspiracy theories, heavily promoted the recordings.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/for-months-trump-allies-hunted-for-tapes-of-biden-in-ukraine-now-theyre-turning-up/2020/06/30/f3aeaba8-a67b-11ea-8681-7d471bf20207_story.html|title=Hunt for Biden tapes in Ukraine by Trump allies revives prospect of foreign interference|first1=Paul|last1=Sonne|first2=Rosalind S.|last2=Helderman|last3=Dawsey|first3=Josh |first4=David L.|last4=Stern|website=Washington Post}}</ref> In September 2020, the US [[Treasury Department]] sanctioned Derkach, stating he "has been an active Russian agent for over a decade, maintaining close connections with the Russian Intelligence Services." The Treasury Department added Derkach "waged a covert influence campaign centered on cultivating false and unsubstantiated narratives concerning U.S. officials in the upcoming 2020 Presidential Election," including by the release of "edited audio tapes and other unsupported information with the intent to discredit U.S. officials."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/09/10/politics/treasury-sanctions-derkach-ukraine-election-interference/index.html|title=Vowing crackdown on Russian meddling, US sanctions Ukrainian lawmaker who worked with Giuliani to smear Biden|first=Zachary Cohen, Kylie Atwood and Marshall Cohen|last=CNN|website=CNN}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/sm1118|title=Treasury Sanctions Russia-Linked Election Interference Actors|date= September 10, 2020|website=[[United States Department of the Treasury]]}}</ref>

In some cases, Giuliani and his associates worked with individuals linked to Russian organized crime and intelligence, including Firtash and Derkach.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/06/26/senate-hunter-biden-documents-341817|title=Senate panel demands testimony from ex-Obama officials in revived Biden probe|website=POLITICO}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-10-18/to-win-giuliani-s-help-oligarch-s-allies-pursued-biden-dirt|title=To Win Giuliani's Help, Oligarch's Allies Pursued Biden Dirt|date=October 18, 2019|via=www.bloomberg.com}}</ref> In late 2019, multiple sources reported that the [[United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York]], which Giuliani had once led, was investigating him for multiple felonies relating to his activities in Ukraine.<ref>{{Cite
