On October 14, 2020, the ''[[New York Post]]'' reported newly uncovered emails suggesting [[Hunter Biden]] introduced his father, then [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Joe Biden]] to a top executive at [[Ukrainian]] natural gas firm [[Burisma|Burisma Holdings]].<ref>{{cite web |title=N.Y. Post Says It Obtained Hunter Biden Emails on Ukraine |url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/weather/ny-post-says-it-obtained-hunter-biden-emails-on-ukraine/vi-BB1a1clr |website=MSN |publisher=MSN |accessdate=14 October 2020}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web |title=Biden camp hits back at Hunter Biden email report suggesting then-VP met with Burisma exec |url=https://www.foxnews.com/politics/biden-camp-hits-back-at-hunter-biden-email-report-suggesting-then-vp-met-with-burisma-exec |website=Fox News |publisher=Fox News |accessdate=14 October 2020}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web |title=Rudy Found Hunter Biden Emails That Totally Weren’t Stolen by Russia |url=https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/10/biden-emails-burisma-rudy-giulliani-russian-hackers-ukraine-new-york-post.html |website=New York Magazine |publisher=New York Mag |accessdate=14 October 2020}}</ref> [[Joe Biden 2020 presidential campaign|Joe Biden's presidential campaign]] denied such a meeting took place.

title: Conspiracy theories related to the Trump–Ukraine scandal
Conspiracy theories related to the Trump–Ukraine scandal
deleted: Trump and his allies have also promoted a conspiracy theory that Joe Biden and his son, Hunter, were engaged in corrupt activities in Ukraine. Trump's defense team promoted this conspiracy theory during his impeachment trial, and Trump has said he planned to make it a major issue during the 2020 campaign, while a Republican-controlled Senate committee ramped up an investigation in spring 2020. Trump's personal attorney, [[Rudy Giuliani]], spearheaded an effort to gather information in Ukraine to advance the conspiracy theory, and attorney general Barr confirmed that the Justice Department created an "intake process" to review Giuliani's findings.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/02/10/politics/justice-department-rudy-giuliani-ukraine/index.html|title=Barr confirms Justice Department is receiving Giuliani information about Ukraine|first=David Shortell|last=CNN|website=CNN}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/trump-impeachment-inquiry/trump-impeachment-defense-team-turns-attention-bidens-burisma-n1124231|title=Trump impeachment defense team turns attention to Bidens, Burisma|website=NBC News}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/486054-trump-says-biden-ukraine-dealings-will-be-a-major-campaign-issue|title=Trump says Biden Ukraine dealings will be a 'major' campaign issue|first=Lisa|last=Conley|date=March 4, 2020|website=TheHill}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/20/us/politics/trump-biden-subpoena.html|title=Senate Panel, Urged On by Trump, Subpoenas Biden-Related Material|first=Nicholas|last=Fandos|date=May 20, 2020|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> The conspiracy theory asserts that Hunter Biden was paid a large sum of money by a Ukrainian firm, [[Burisma Holdings]], to take a job for which he was unqualified, as a means for Burisma to influence then-vice president Joe Biden, who then extorted Ukraine for $1 billion to fire a prosecutor so as to prevent Hunter Biden from being investigated for corruption. This narrative has been found to be false.{{refn|<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/in-depth/news/world/2019/10/10/trumps-biden-ukraine-natural-gas-conspiracy-theory-false-but-alive/3851728002/|title=Trump's Biden-Ukraine natural gas conspiracy theory: False, but alive|website=USA Today |access-date=December 17, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2019/sep/30/trump-impeachment-five-conspiracy-theories-ukraine-dilemma|title=Five fantasies Trump is pushing about the Ukraine scandal – and the truth |website=The Guardian |access-date=December 17, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/trump-impeachment-inquiry/trump-pushing-baseless-conspiracy-about-bidens-china-here-s-what-n1062551|title=Trump is pushing a baseless conspiracy about the Bidens and China. Here's what we know. |publisher=NBC News |access-date=December 17, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2020-election/there-s-no-evidence-trump-s-biden-ukraine-accusations-what-n1057851|title=There's no evidence for Trump's Biden-Ukraine accusations. What really happened?|publisher=NBC News |access-date=December 17, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2019/9/23/20879611/joe-biden-hunter-biden-ukraine-corruption-prosecutor-burisma-donald-trump-whistleblower-complaint|title=The facts behind Trump's bogus accusations about Biden and Ukraine|website=Vox |access-date=December 17, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/the-invention-of-the-conspiracy-theory-on-biden-and-ukraine|title=The Invention of the Conspiracy Theory on Biden and Ukraine|website=The New Yorker |access-date=December 9, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/internet/sondland-testified-misleading-ukraine-story-spread-among-conservatives-social-media-n1087511|title=As Sondland testified, a misleading Ukraine story spread among conservatives on social media|publisher=NBC News |access-date=November 21, 2019}}</ref>}} Hunter Biden did take a high-paying job with Burisma, but involving matters for which he was qualified, and there is no evidence he was peddling influence with his father. Vice president Biden did withhold $1 billion in government aid to Ukraine, but for the opposite reason the conspiracy theory asserts: as a matter of American and international policy to induce Ukraine to remove a corrupt and ineffective prosecutor who was not assertively investigating Burisma. Trump defended the fired prosecutor, [[Viktor Shokin]], “who a lot of people said was a great prosecutor and they took him off.”<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/trump-continues-push-debunked-ukraine-conspiracy-theory/story?id=67228100|title=Trump continues to push debunked Ukraine conspiracy theory|first=A. B. C.|last=News|website=ABC News}}</ref> In a widely-circulated 2018 video, a portion of which was included in a Trump campaign ad, Joe Biden is seen taking credit for Shokin's firing, but not for the reason the conspiracy theory and Trump ad contend.<ref name="auto2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.factcheck.org/2019/10/fact-trump-tv-ad-misleads-on-biden-and-ukraine/|title=Fact: Trump TV Ad Misleads on Biden and Ukraine|first1=Eugene|last1=Kiely|first2=Robert|last2=Farley|date=October 9, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2019/oct/11/donald-trump/trump-ad-misleads-about-biden-ukraine-and-prosecut/|title=PolitiFact - Donald Trump ad misleads about Joe Biden, Ukraine and the prosecutor|website=@politifact}}</ref>

In September 2019, Shokin signed an affidavit asserting his beliefs — rather than assertions of facts — that Joe Biden engineered his removal from office to prevent an investigation into Burisma and Hunter Biden. Giuliani promoted the affidavit in television appearances, asserting that Shokin "says under oath" that he was investigating Hunter Biden when he was fired.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.politifact.com/article/2019/oct/02/fact-checking-rudy-giulianis-claims-about-joe-bide/|title=PolitiFact - The inaccurate or unproven things Rudy Giuliani said about Ukraine on 'This Week'|website=@politifact}}</ref> The affidavit notes that it was provided "at the request of lawyers acting for [[Dmitry Firtash]]...for use in legal proceedings in Austria."<ref name="auto2"/> Firtash, a Ukrainian oligarch, had for five years been living in Austria, figthing extradition to the United States where he was under indictment for a bribery scheme.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/fighting-extradition-ukrainian-tycoon-aligns-legal-strategy-with-trump-camp-11571736603|title=Fighting Extradition, Ukrainian Tycoon Aligns Legal Strategy With Trump Camp|first=Warren P. Strobel and James|last=Marson|date=October 22, 2019|via=www.wsj.com}}</ref> Since July 2019, Fitrash's lawyers included [[Joseph diGenova]] and his wife [[Victoria Toensing]], close Trump and Giuliani associates who are regular guests on [[Sean Hannity]]'s Fox News program.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/trump-impeachment-inquiry/ukrainian-oligarch-firtash-linked-giuliani-pals-gas-deals-biden-dirt-n1067516|title=Oligarch Firtash linked to Giuliani pals' gas deals and Biden research|website=NBC News}}</ref> ''The New York Times'' reported that Giuliani had directed [[Lev Parnas]] to recommend to Firtash that he hire diGenova and Toensing, with the proposition that Firtash could help to provide compromising information on Biden, which Parnas's attorney described was "part of any potential resolution to [Firtash's] extradition matter".<ref name="auto1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/25/us/giuliani-ukraine-oligarchs.html|title=Why Giuliani Singled Out 2 Ukrainian Oligarchs to Help Look for Dirt|first1=Jo|last1=Becker|first2=Walt|last2=Bogdanich|first3=Maggie|last3=Haberman|first4=Ben|last4=Protess|date=November 25, 2019|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> ''The Washington Post'' reported that in mid-August 2019, Toensing and diGenova secured a rare face-to-face meeting with attorney general [[Bill Barr]] to argue the Firtash charges should be dropped.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/prosecutors-flagged-possible-ties-between-ukrainian-gas-tycoon-and-giuliani-associates/2019/10/22/4ee22e7c-f020-11e9-b648-76bcf86eb67e_story.html |date=October 22, 2019 |title=Prosecutors flagged possible ties between Ukrainian gas tycoon and Giuliani associates |first1=Matt |last1=Zapotosky |last2=Helderman |first2=Rosalind S. Helderman |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=October 25, 2019 }}</ref> Prior to that meeting, Barr had been briefed in detail on the initial whistleblower complaint within the CIA that had been forwarded to the Justice Department, as well as on Giuliani's activities in Ukraine. Barr declined to intervene in the Firtash case.<ref name="auto1"/> ''Bloomberg News'' reported that its sources told them that Giuliani's high-profile publicity of the Shokin affidavit had greatly reduced the chances of the Justice Department dropping the charges against Firtash, as it would appear to be a political ''quid pro quo''.<ref>{{Cite news | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-10-18/to-win-giuliani-s-help-oligarch-s-allies-pursued-biden-dirt |work=Bloomberg News |title=To Win Giuliani's Help, Oligarch's Allies Pursued Biden Dirt |date=October 18, 2019 |first1=Stephanie |last1=Baker |first2=Irina |last2=Reznik |accessdate=October 19, 2019 }}</ref> diGenova has said he has known Barr for decades, as they both worked in the Reagan/Bush Justice Department.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/11/01/politics/parnas-firtash-giuliani-ties/index.html |accessdate=January 7, 2020 |title='I'm the best-paid interpreter in the world': Indicted Giuliani associate touted windfall from Ukrainian oligarch|first1=Vicky |last1=Ward |first2=Marshall |last2=Cohen |date=November 1, 2019 |website=CNN}}</ref>

Firtash made his fortune brokering Ukrainian imports of natural gas from the Russian firm [[Gazprom]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/01/us/paul-manafort-ukraine-donald-trump.html |title=How Paul Manafort Wielded Power in Ukraine Before Advising Donald Trump |first1=Steven Lee |last1=Myers|first2=Andrew E.|last2=Kramer |date=July 31, 2016|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=January 7, 2020 }}</ref> As vice president, Joe Biden had urged the Ukrainian government to eliminate middlemen such as Firtash from the country's natural gas industry, and to reduce the country's reliance on imports of Russian natural gas. Firtash denied involvement in collecting or financing damaging information on the Bidens.<ref name="auto1"/> In 2017, the Justice Department characterized him as an "upper echelon (associate) of Russian organized crime".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2017/07/26/feds-call-ex-manafort-associate-dmytro-firtash-top-tier-player-russian-organized-crime/514131001/ |title=Feds call ex-Manafort associate Dmytro Firtash a top-tier player in Russian organized crime|first=Doug|last=Stanglin|newspaper=USA Today |date=July 26, 2017 |accessdate=November 19, 2019 }}</ref>

In May 2020, Ukrainian lawmaker [[Andrii Derkach]], an associate of Rudy Giuliani with links to Russian intelligence, released snippets of recordings of Joe Biden speaking with [[Petro Poroshenko]], the Ukrainian president during the years Hunter Biden worked for Burisma.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/ukrainian-lawmaker-releases-leaked-phone-calls-of-biden-and-poroshenko/2020/05/19/cc1e6030-9a26-11ea-b60c-3be060a4f8e1_story.html|title=Ukrainian lawmaker releases leaked phone calls of Biden and Poroshenko|first1=Paul|last1=Sonne|first2=Rosalind S. |last2=Helderman |website=Washington Post}}</ref> The recordings, which were not verified as authentic and appeared heavily edited, showed Biden linking loan guarantees for Ukraine to the ouster of the country’s prosecutor general. The recordings did not provide evidence to support the ongoing conspiracy theory that Biden wanted the prosecutor fired to protect his son.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Sonne|first1=Paul|last2=Helderman|first2=Rosalind S.|last3=Dawsey|first3=Josh|last4=Stern|first4=David L.|date=June 30, 2020|title=Hunt for Biden tapes in Ukraine by Trump allies revives prospect of foreign interference|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/for-months-trump-allies-hunted-for-tapes-of-biden-in-ukraine-now-theyre-turning-up/2020/06/30/f3aeaba8-a67b-11ea-8681-7d471bf20207_story.html|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-30|website=[[The Washington Post]]|language=en}}</ref> Poroshenko denied In June 2020 that Joe Biden ever approached him about Burisma and characterized the recordings as fake.<ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=June 26, 2020|title=Senate panel demands testimony from ex-Obama officials in revived Biden probe|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/06/26/senate-hunter-biden-documents-341817|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-29|website=[[Politico]]|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite Burisma|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/06/21/ukraine-president-hunter-joe-biden-burisma-331779|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-29|website=[[Politico]]|language=en}}</ref> [[One America News]], a favorite news outlet of Trump's that features conspiracy theories, heavily promoted the recordings.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/for-months-trump-allies-hunted-for-tapes-of-biden-in-ukraine-now-theyre-turning-up/2020/06/30/f3aeaba8-a67b-11ea-8681-7d471bf20207_story.html|title=Hunt for Biden tapes in Ukraine by Trump allies revives prospect of foreign interference|first1=Paul|last1=Sonne|first2=Rosalind S.|last2=Helderman|last3=Dawsey|first3=Josh |first4=David L.|last4=Stern|website=Washington Post}}</ref> In September 2020, the US [[Treasury Department]] sanctioned Derkach, stating he "has been an active Russian agent for over a decade, maintaining close connections with the Russian Intelligence Services." The Treasury Department added Derkach "waged a covert influence campaign centered on cultivating false and unsubstantiated narratives concerning U.S. officials in the upcoming 2020 Presidential Election," including by the release of "edited audio tapes and other unsupported information with the intent to discredit U.S. officials."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/09/10/politics/treasury-sanctions-derkach-ukraine-election-interference/index.html|title=Vowing crackdown on Russian meddling, US sanctions Ukrainian lawmaker who worked with Giuliani to smear Biden|first=Zachary Cohen, Kylie Atwood and Marshall Cohen|last=CNN|website=CNN}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/sm1118|title=Treasury Sanctions Russia-Linked Election Interference Actors|date= September 10, 2020|website=[[United States Department of the Treasury]]}}</ref>

In some cases, Giuliani and his associates worked with individuals linked to Russian organized crime and intelligence, including Firtash and Derkach.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/06/26/senate-hunter-biden-documents-341817|title=Senate panel demands testimony from ex-Obama officials in revived Biden probe|website=POLITICO}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-10-18/to-win-giuliani-s-help-oligarch-s-allies-pursued-biden-dirt|title=To Win Giuliani's Help, Oligarch's Allies Pursued Biden Dirt|date=October 18, 2019|via=www.bloomberg.com}}</ref> In late 2019, multiple sources reported that the [[United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York]], which Giuliani had once led, was investigating him for multiple felonies relating to his activities in Ukraine.<ref>{{Cite title: Conspiracy theories related to the Trump–Ukraine scandal

Trump's defense team promoted this conspiracy theory during his impeachment trial, and Trump has said he planned to make it a major issue during the 2020 campaign, while a Republican-controlled Senate committee ramped up an investigation in spring 2020. Trump's personal attorney, [[Rudy Giuliani]], spearheaded an effort to gather information in Ukraine to advance the conspiracy theory, and attorney general Barr confirmed that the Justice Department created an "intake process" to review Giuliani's findings.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/02/10/politics/justice-department-rudy-giuliani-ukraine/index.html|title=Barr confirms Justice Department is receiving Giuliani information about Ukraine|first=David Shortell|last=CNN|website=CNN}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/trump-impeachment-inquiry/trump-impeachment-defense-team-turns-attention-bidens-burisma-n1124231|title=Trump impeachment defense team turns attention to Bidens, Burisma|website=NBC News}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/486054-trump-says-biden-ukraine-dealings-will-be-a-major-campaign-issue|title=Trump says Biden Ukraine dealings will be a 'major' campaign issue|first=Lisa|last=Conley|date=March 4, 2020|website=TheHill}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/20/us/politics/trump-biden-subpoena.html|title=Senate Panel, Urged On by Trump, Subpoenas Biden-Related Material|first=Nicholas|last=Fandos|date=May 20, 2020|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> The conspiracy theory asserts that Hunter Biden was paid a large sum of money by a Ukrainian firm, [[Burisma Holdings]], to take a job for which he was unqualified, as a means for Burisma to influence then-vice president Joe Biden, who then extorted Ukraine for $1 billion to fire a prosecutor so as to prevent Hunter Biden from being investigated for corruption. What really happened?|publisher=NBC News |access-date=December 17, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2019/9/23/20879611/joe-biden-hunter-biden-ukraine-corruption-prosecutor-burisma-donald-trump-whistleblower-complaint|title=The facts behind Trump's bogus accusations about Biden and Ukraine|website=Vox |access-date=December 17, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/the-invention-of-the-conspiracy-theory-on-biden-and-ukraine|title=The Invention of the Conspiracy Theory on Biden and Ukraine|website=The New Yorker |access-date=December 9, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/internet/sondland-testified-misleading-ukraine-story-spread-among-conservatives-social-media-n1087511|title=As Sondland testified, a misleading Ukraine story spread among conservatives on social media|publisher=NBC News |access-date=November 21, 2019}}</ref>}} Hunter Biden did take a high-paying job with Burisma, but involving matters for which he was qualified, and there is no evidence he was peddling influence with his father. Trump defended the fired prosecutor, [[Viktor Shokin]], “who a lot of people said was a great prosecutor and they took him off.”<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/trump-continues-push-debunked-ukraine-conspiracy-theory/story?id=67228100|title=Trump continues to push debunked Ukraine conspiracy theory|first=A. B. C.|last=News|website=ABC News}}</ref> In a widely-circulated 2018 video, a portion of which was included in a Trump campaign ad, Joe Biden is seen taking credit for Shokin's firing, but not for the reason the conspiracy theory and Trump ad contend.<ref name="auto2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.factcheck.org/2019/10/fact-trump-tv-ad-misleads-on-biden-and-ukraine/|title=Fact: Trump TV Ad Misleads on Biden and Ukraine|first1=Eugene|last1=Kiely|first2=Robert|last2=Farley|date=October 9, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2019/oct/11/donald-trump/trump-ad-misleads-about-biden-ukraine-and-prosecut/|title=PolitiFact - Donald Trump ad misleads about Joe Biden, Ukraine and the prosecutor|website=@politifact}}</ref>

In September 2019, Shokin signed an affidavit asserting his beliefs — rather than assertions of facts — that Joe Biden engineered his removal from office to prevent an investigation into Burisma and Hunter Biden. Giuliani promoted the affidavit in television appearances, asserting that Shokin "says under oath" that he was investigating Hunter Biden when he was fired.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.politifact.com/article/2019/oct/02/fact-checking-rudy-giulianis-claims-about-joe-bide/|title=PolitiFact - The inaccurate or unproven things Rudy Giuliani said about Ukraine on 'This Week'|website=@politifact}}</ref> The affidavit notes that it was provided "at the request of lawyers acting for [[Dmitry Firtash]]...for use in legal proceedings in Austria."<ref name="auto2"/> Firtash, a Ukrainian oligarch, had for five years been living in Austria, figthing extradition to the United States where he was under indictment for a bribery scheme.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/fighting-extradition-ukrainian-tycoon-aligns-legal-strategy-with-trump-camp-11571736603|title=Fighting Extradition, Ukrainian Tycoon Aligns Legal Strategy With Trump Camp|first=Warren P. Strobel and James|last=Marson|date=October 22, 2019|via=www.wsj.com}}</ref> Since July 2019, Fitrash's lawyers included [[Joseph diGenova]] and his wife [[Victoria Toensing]], close Trump and Giuliani associates who are regular guests on [[Sean Hannity]]'s Fox News program.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/trump-impeachment-inquiry/ukrainian-oligarch-firtash-linked-giuliani-pals-gas-deals-biden-dirt-n1067516|title=Oligarch Firtash linked to Giuliani pals' gas deals and Biden research|website=NBC News}}</ref> ''The New York Times'' reported that Giuliani had directed [[Lev Parnas]] to recommend to Firtash that he hire diGenova and Toensing, with the proposition that Firtash could help to provide compromising information on Biden, which Parnas's attorney described was "part of any potential resolution to [Firtash's] extradition matter".<ref name="auto1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/25/us/giuliani-ukraine-oligarchs.html|title=Why Giuliani Singled Out 2 Ukrainian Oligarchs to Help Look for Dirt|first1=Jo|last1=Becker|first2=Walt|last2=Bogdanich|first3=Maggie|last3=Haberman|first4=Ben|last4=Protess|date=November 25, 2019|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> ''The Washington Post'' reported that in mid-August 2019, Toensing and diGenova secured a rare face-to-face meeting with attorney general [[Bill Barr]] to argue the Firtash charges should be dropped.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/prosecutors-flagged-possible-ties-between-ukrainian-gas-tycoon-and-giuliani-associates/2019/10/22/4ee22e7c-f020-11e9-b648-76bcf86eb67e_story.html |date=October 22, 2019 |title=Prosecutors flagged possible ties between Ukrainian gas tycoon and Giuliani associates |first1=Matt |last1=Zapotosky |last2=Helderman |first2=Rosalind S. Helderman |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=October 25, 2019 }}</ref> Prior to that meeting, Barr had been briefed in detail on the initial whistleblower complaint within the CIA that had been forwarded to the Justice Department, as well as on Giuliani's activities in Ukraine. Barr declined to intervene in the Firtash case.<ref name="auto1"/> ''Bloomberg News'' reported that its sources told them that Giuliani's high-profile publicity of the Shokin affidavit had greatly reduced the chances of the Justice Department dropping the charges against Firtash, as it would appear to be a political ''quid pro quo''.<ref>{{Cite news | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-10-18/to-win-giuliani-s-help-oligarch-s-allies-pursued-biden-dirt |work=Bloomberg News |title=To Win Giuliani's Help, Oligarch's Allies Pursued Biden Dirt |date=October 18, 2019 |first1=Stephanie |last1=Baker |first2=Irina |last2=Reznik |accessdate=October 19, 2019 }}</ref> diGenova has said he has known Barr for decades, as they both worked in the Reagan/Bush Justice Department.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/11/01/politics/parnas-firtash-giuliani-ties/index.html |accessdate=January 7, 2020 |title='I'm the best-paid interpreter in the world': Indicted Giuliani associate touted windfall from Ukrainian oligarch|first1=Vicky |last1=Ward |first2=Marshall |last2=Cohen |date=November 1, 2019 |website=CNN}}</ref>

Firtash made his fortune brokering Ukrainian imports of natural gas from the Russian firm [[Gazprom]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/01/us/paul-manafort-ukraine-donald-trump.html |title=How Paul Manafort Wielded Power in Ukraine Before Advising Donald Trump |first1=Steven Lee |last1=Myers|first2=Andrew E.|last2=Kramer |date=July 31, 2016|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=January 7, 2020 }}</ref> As vice president, Joe Biden had urged the Ukrainian government to eliminate middlemen such as Firtash from the country's natural gas industry, and to reduce the country's reliance on imports of Russian natural gas. Firtash denied involvement in collecting or financing damaging information on the Bidens.<ref name="auto1"/> In 2017, the Justice Department characterized him as an "upper echelon (associate) of Russian organized crime".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2017/07/26/feds-call-ex-manafort-associate-dmytro-firtash-top-tier-player-russian-organized-crime/514131001/ |title=Feds call ex-Manafort associate Dmytro Firtash a top-tier player in Russian organized crime|first=Doug|last=Stanglin|newspaper=USA Today |date=July 26, 2017 |accessdate=November 19, 2019 }}</ref>

In May 2020, Ukrainian lawmaker [[Andrii Derkach]], an associate of Rudy Giuliani with links to Russian intelligence, released snippets of recordings of Joe Biden speaking with [[Petro Poroshenko]], the Ukrainian president during the years Hunter Biden worked for Burisma.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/ukrainian-lawmaker-releases-leaked-phone-calls-of-biden-and-poroshenko/2020/05/19/cc1e6030-9a26-11ea-b60c-3be060a4f8e1_story.html|title=Ukrainian lawmaker releases leaked phone calls of Biden and Poroshenko|first1=Paul|last1=Sonne|first2=Rosalind S. |last2=Helderman |website=Washington Post}}</ref> The recordings, which were not verified as authentic and appeared heavily edited, showed Biden linking loan guarantees for Ukraine to the ouster of the country’s prosecutor general. The recordings did not provide evidence to support the ongoing conspiracy theory that Biden wanted the prosecutor fired to protect his son.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Sonne|first1=Paul|last2=Helderman|first2=Rosalind S.|last3=Dawsey|first3=Josh|last4=Stern|first4=David L.|date=June 30, 2020|title=Hunt for Biden tapes in Ukraine by Trump allies revives prospect of foreign interference|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/for-months-trump-allies-hunted-for-tapes-of-biden-in-ukraine-now-theyre-turning-up/2020/06/30/f3aeaba8-a67b-11ea-8681-7d471bf20207_story.html|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-30|website=[[The Washington Post]]|language=en}}</ref> Poroshenko denied In June 2020 that Joe Biden ever approached him about Burisma and characterized the recordings as fake.<ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=June 26, 2020|title=Senate panel demands testimony from ex-Obama officials in revived Biden probe|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/06/26/senate-hunter-biden-documents-341817|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-29|website=[[Politico]]|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Seddiq|first=Oma|date=June 21, 2020|title=Former Ukrainian president says Biden never pressed him on Burisma|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/06/21/ukraine-president-hunter-joe-biden-burisma-331779|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-29|website=[[Politico]]|language=en}}</ref> [[One America News]], a favorite news outlet of Trump's that features conspiracy theories, heavily promoted the recordings.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/for-months-trump-allies-hunted-for-tapes-of-biden-in-ukraine-now-theyre-turning-up/2020/06/30/f3aeaba8-a67b-11ea-8681-7d471bf20207_story.html|title=Hunt for Biden tapes in Ukraine by Trump allies revives prospect of foreign interference|first1=Paul|last1=Sonne|first2=Rosalind S.|last2=Helderman|last3=Dawsey|first3=Josh |first4=David L.|last4=Stern|website=Washington Post}}</ref> In September 2020, the US [[Treasury Department]] sanctioned Derkach, stating he "has been an active Russian agent for over a decade, maintaining close connections with the Russian Intelligence Services." The Treasury Department added Derkach "waged a covert influence campaign centered on cultivating false and unsubstantiated narratives concerning U.S. officials in the upcoming 2020 Presidential Election," including by the release of "edited audio tapes and other unsupported information with the intent to discredit U.S. officials."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/09/10/politics/treasury-sanctions-derkach-ukraine-election-interference/index.html|title=Vowing crackdown on Russian meddling, US sanctions Ukrainian lawmaker who worked with Giuliani to smear Biden|first=Zachary Cohen, Kylie Atwood and Marshall Cohen|last=CNN|website=CNN}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/sm1118|title=Treasury Sanctions Russia-Linked Election Interference Actors|date= September 10, 2020|website=[[United States Department of the Treasury]]}}</ref>

In some cases, Giuliani and his associates worked with individuals linked to Russian organized crime and intelligence, including Firtash and Derkach.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/06/26/senate-hunter-biden-documents-341817|title=Senate panel demands testimony from ex-Obama officials in revived Biden probe|website=POLITICO}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-10-18/to-win-giuliani-s-help-oligarch-s-allies-pursued-biden-dirt|title=To Win Giuliani's Help, Oligarch's Allies Pursued Biden Dirt|date=October 18, 2019|via=www.bloomberg.com}}</ref> In late 2019, multiple sources reported that the [[United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York]], which Giuliani had once led, was investigating him for multiple felonies relating to his activities in Ukraine.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/11/us/politics/rudy-giuliani-investigation.html|title=Giuliani Is Said to Be Under Investigation for Ukraine Work|first1=Michael S.|last1=Schmidt|first2=Ben|last2=Protess|first3=Kenneth P.|last3=Vogel|first4=William K.|last4=Rashbaum|date=October 11, 2019|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-11-15/giuliani-faces-u-s-probe-on-campaign-finance-lobbying-breaches|title=Giuliani Faces U.S. Probe on Campaign Finance, Lobbying Breaches|date=November 15, 2019|via=www.bloomberg.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mediaite.com/news/just-in-subpoenas-reportedly-issued-seeking-information-on-giulianis-consulting-work/|title=Subpoenas Issued Related to Rudy Giuliani Consulting Work|date=November 25, 2019}}</ref> The chairman of the Senate committee investigating the matter, [[Ron Johnson (Wisconsin politician)|Ron Johnson]], was warned by American intelligence officials of a risk he could be playing into the hands of Russian intelligence to spread disinformation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/11/us/politics/senate-subpoena-ron-johnson-ukraine.html|title=Senate Panel Delays Subpoena Vote Over Concerns About Ukraine Witness|first1=Kenneth P.|last1=Vogel|first2=Nicholas|last2=Fandos|date=March 11, 2020|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref>

On October 14, 2020, the ''[[New York Post]]'' reported newly uncovered emails suggesting [[Hunter Biden]] introduced his father, then [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Joe Biden]] to a top executive at [[Ukrainian]] natural gas firm [[Burisma|Burisma Holdings]].<ref>{{cite web |title=N.Y. Post Says It Obtained Hunter Biden Emails on Ukraine |url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/weather/ny-post-says-it-obtained-hunter-biden-emails-on-ukraine/vi-BB1a1clr |website=MSN |publisher=MSN |accessdate=14 October 2020}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web |title=Biden camp hits back at Hunter Biden email report suggesting then-VP met with Burisma exec |url=https://www.foxnews.com/politics/biden-camp-hits-back-at-hunter-biden-email-report-suggesting-then-vp-met-with-burisma-exec |website=Fox News |publisher=Fox News |accessdate=14 October 2020}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web |title=Rudy Found Hunter Biden Emails That Totally Weren’t Stolen by Russia |url=https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/10/biden-emails-burisma-rudy-giulliani-russian-hackers-ukraine-new-york-post.html |website=New York Magazine |publisher=New York Mag |accessdate=14 October 2020}}</ref> [[Joe Biden 2020 presidential campaign|Joe Biden's presidential campaign]] denied such a meeting took place.

title: Nicole Galloway
deleted: A lifelong Missourian, Nicole has committed herself to improving her state. She was Secretary/Treasurer of the Missouri Technology Corporation, investing in entrepreneurs here in Missouri to help create jobs. Additionally, she served as Secretary/Treasurer of the Missouri County Employees’ Retirement Fund, protecting the retirement benefits of nearly 16,000 participants in 111 counties. While on the retirement fund’s board, she led the effort to ensure equal protection for the retirement benefits of county employees in same-sex marriages.

deleted: Just like in 2016, the Democrat campaign collapsed in the final days of the election because of its own arrogance and stupidity. [[Jen O'Malley Dillon]] and the rest of the campaign were so overconfident that they refused to engage in normal campaign and outreach operations, somehow assuming that the worst candidate in the history of presidential politics would single-handedly inspire record turnout with the groups they needed to win. This strategy was an enormous failure. Despite being a heavy favorite, the campaign squandered their lead in the final days of the race and lost the election in shocking fashion. Consequently, O'Malley Dillon became known as one of the worst campaign managers in political history, on par with [[Robby Mook]].

title: Thom Tillis
added: Tillis was announced the winner of the Senate race at approximately 11:30 PM on November 4. He received 48.82% of the vote, the lowest winning total in North Carolina history for a U.S. Senate candidate.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.news-record.com/blogs/clark_off_the_record/tillis-percent-is-lowest-winning-total-in-north-carolina-history/article_44b5a328-64f9-11e4-b28c-001a4bcf6878.html|title=Tillis' 48.87 percent is lowest winning total in North Carolina history|accessdate=November 5, 2014|publisher=News and Record|date=December 12, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://enr.ncsbe.gov/ElectionResults/?election_dt=11/04/2014|title=11/04/2014 Official General Election Results – Statewide|date=November 4, 2014|work=NC Board of Elections|accessdate=December 2, 2014|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150127130653/http://enr.ncsbe.gov/ElectionResults/?election_dt=11%2F04%2F2014|archivedate=January 27, 2015}}</ref>

In the 2014 election, Tillis received $22,888,975 in "[[dark money]]", which constituted 81% of nonparty outside spending in support.<ref>{{cite web |title=Outside Spending and Dark Money in Toss-Up Senate Races: Post-Election Update {{!}} Brennan Center for Justice |url=https://www.brennancenter.org/our-work/research-reports/outside-spending-and-dark-money-toss-senate-races-post-election-update |website=www.brennancenter.org |accessdate=21 August 2020 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/politics-government/article9138026.html | title=Outside spending, 'dark' money fuel N.C. Senate race | newspaper=[[The Charlotte Observer]] | date=July 4, 2014 | accessdate=September 3, 2014 }}</ref>

title: Thom Tillis
deleted: Tillis opposes [[same-sex marriage]], the [[Affordable Care Act]], [[net neutrality]], the [[Minimum wage in the United States|federal minimum wage]], and access to [[abortion]] in most cases. He holds an "A+" rating from the [[National Rifle Association]] (NRA) and as of 2018 was the third largest congressional recipient of funding from the organisation at $4.4 million. He has expressed ambivalent views on the causes of [[climate change]], and supported the United States' [[United States withdrawal from the Paris Agreement|withdrawal]] from the [[Paris Agreement]].

Once seen as an establishment candidate, he was initially willing to defy [[Donald Trump]] on certain issues, most notably on immigration, but has increasingly aligned himself with the President due to pressure from his party, voting with him 93% of the time as of May 2020.

title: Thom Tillis
deleted: On May 17, 2017, while participating in a three-mile race at [[Anacostia Park]] in Washington, D.C., Tillis collapsed and was taken to a hospital by ambulance.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/north-carolina-sen-thom-tillis-collapses-during-race-bystanders-perform-n760711|title=North Carolina Sen. Thom Tillis collapses during race|work=NBC News|access-date=2017-07-25|language=en}}</ref> Later that day, he was released from the hospital.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newsobserver.com/news/politics-government/state-politics/article151088802.html|title=Thom Tillis gets ‘clean bill of health,’ leaves D.C. hospital after road race collapse|last=Cioffi|first=Chris|date=17 May 2017|website=The News & Observer|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref>

title: Thom Tillis
added: In 2014, 14 people [[Moral Mondays|protesting]] cuts to the [[earned income tax credit]]s and Tillis’s refusal to expand [[Medicaid]] were arrested after staging a [[sit-in]] in his office.<ref>{{cite web |title=14 arrested after sit-in at legislative building |url=https://abc11.com/moral-monday-protest-north-carolina-general-assembly/79538/ |website=[[WTVD|ABC11 Raleigh-Durham]] |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |language=en |date=May 28, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Blythe |first1=Anne |title=14 Moral Monday demonstrators arrested during sit-in at Thom Tillis' office |url=https://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/local/article9125510.html |website=[[Charlotte Observer]] |date=May 27, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Maguire |first1=Marti |title=Moral Monday protesters arrested at North Carolina legislative offices |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-northcarolina-protests/moral-monday-protesters-arrested-at-north-carolina-legislative-offices-idUSKBN0E82AQ20140528 |website=[[Reuters]] |language=en |date=28 May 2014}}</ref>

title: Thom Tillis
added: As speaker of the state House of Representatives, Tillis supported restrictions on [[abortion]] and a constitutional amendment banning [[same-sex marriage]]. He led the Republican effort to block the expansion of [[Medicaid]] in North Carolina and, in the Senate, has repeatedly voted to repeal the [[Affordable Care Act]]. He initially opposed Trump's [[National Emergency Concerning the Southern Border of the United States|national emergency declaration]] to divert funding to a [[Trump wall|border wall]], but ultimately voted for it following pressure from his party.

title: Thom Tillis
deleted: In July 2020, Tillis claimed Cunningham had been "silent" on the issue of [[Defund the Police|defunding the police]], saying, "I assume his silence is consent". [[PolitiFact]] rated the claim "False", as Cunningham had spoken publicly about the issue and written an [[op-ed]] a month earlier stating his opposition to defunding the police, advocating [[police reform]] instead.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Specht |first1=Paul |title=No, Cunningham has not been 'silent' on defunding police |url=https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/aug/19/thom-tillis/no-cunningham-has-not-been-silent-defunding-police/ |website=[[PolitiFact]] |date=August 19, 2020|accessdate=September 24, 2020}}</ref>

title: Thom Tillis
added: As speaker of the state House of Representatives, Tillis worked to introduce restrictions on [[abortion]], stringent [[Voter ID laws in the United States|voting requirements]], and a constitutional amendment banning [[same-sex marriage]]. He led the Republican effort to block the expansion of [[Medicaid]] in North Carolina and has repeatedly voted in the Senate to repeal the [[Affordable Care Act]]. While occasionally criticizing [[Donald Trump]], he has generally voted in line with his stated positions. He initially opposed Trump's [[National Emergency Concerning the Southern Border of the United States|national emergency declaration]] to divert funding to a [[Trump wall|border wall]], but voted for it following pressure from his party.

title: 1828 United States presidential election
added: While Andrew Jackson won a plurality of electoral votes and the popular vote in the [[1824 United States presidential election|election of 1824]], he lost to John Quincy Adams as the election was deferred to the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] (by the terms of the [[Twelfth Amendment to the United States Constitution]], a presidential election in which no candidate wins a majority of the electoral vote is decided by a contingent election in the House of Representatives). [[Henry Clay]], unsuccessful candidate and [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker of the House]] at the time, despised Jackson, in part due to their fight for Western votes during the election, and he chose to support Adams, which led to Adams being elected president on the first ballot.

A few days after the election, Adams appointed Clay his Secretary of State, a position was held by Adams and his three immediate predecessors prior to becoming president. Jackson and his followers promptly accused Clay and Adams of striking a "[[Corrupt Bargain|corrupt bargain]]," and continued to lambaste the president until the 1828 election.

In the aftermath of the 1824 election, the national [[Democratic-Republican Party]] collapsed as national politics became increasingly polarized between supporters of Adams and supporters of Jackson. In a prelude to the presidential election, the Jacksonians bolstered their numbers in Congress in the [[1826 United States House of Representatives elections|1826 Congressional elections]], with Jackson ally [[Andrew Stevenson]] chosen as the new [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker of the House of Representatives]] in 1827 over Adams ally Speaker [[John W. Taylor (politician)|John W. Taylor]].

added: With many states easing rules on early voting in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, the 2020 election saw an unprecedented rate of early voting.<ref name="bmayes1"/> By October 26, with eight days remaining until the election, the total early vote throughout the United States had eclipsed that of 2016.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Smith |first1=Allan |title=Early voting could hit record-smashing 100 million by Election Day |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2020-election/early-voting-could-hit-100-million-election-day-n1244764 |publisher=NBC News |date=October 26, 2020}}</ref> Democrats disproportionately indicated their intention to vote by mail, while Republicans disproportionately indicated their intent to vote in person.<ref name="bmayes1">{{cite news |last1=Mayes |first1=Brittany Renee |last2=Rabinowitz |first2=Kate |title=Early-voting numbers: U.S. has hit record early turnout |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2020/elections/early-voting-numbers-so-far/ |publisher=Washington Post |date=October 22, 2020}}</ref>

title: Jeff Flake
added: Flake was first elected to Congress in 2000 from what was then the 1st District, after Republican incumbent [[Matt Salmon]] stepped down to honor a self-imposed [[term limit]]. The district, which included most of the [[East Valley (Phoenix metropolitan area)|East Valley]], was then renumbered as the 6th district as Arizona gained two Congressional seats because of the results of the [[2000 United States Census|2000 census]]. Flake easily defeated his primary challenger.<ref>Arizona Secretary of State website: {{cite web |url=http://www.azsos.gov/results/2004/primary/REP-1006.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-02-09 |url-status=dead |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20041122031853/http://www.azsos.gov/results/2004/primary/REP-1006.htm|archivedate=November 22, 2004}}</ref>

In his campaign in 2000, Flake had pledged to serve no more than three terms in Congress which would see him serve no later than January 2007. Shortly after being elected for a third time, Flake announced in early 2005 that he had changed his mind on pledging term limits and was planning to run for reelection in 2006. "It was a mistake to limit my own terms," Flake said.<ref>Stone, Andrea (April 12, 2006). [https://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2006-04-12-term-limits_x.htm "Term-limit pledges get left behind"]. ''USA Today''.</ref>

In that same election, three out of five mayors in his home district opposed his reelection because, according to Flake, he did not "bring [[pork barrel spending]]" to the mayors' cities.<ref name="60minutes" /> In 2006, several Democrats had announced their intention to run for the seat but only one met the June filing deadline, and that particular filing was rejected due to an insufficient number of nominating signatures. "I did expect to have a primary opponent. I deserve one," Flake said, referring to the term-limit pledge which he had broken. "By all rights, I ought to have an opponent. I just got lucky, I guess."<ref>Giblin, Paul. [http://www.eastvalleytribune.com/news/flake-faces-solo-race-after-judge-removes-hopeful/article_517cfb47-cd85-53a3-8429-7e6de94c94e8.html "Flake faces solo race after judge removes hopeful"], ''East Valley Tribune'', July 12, 2006. Retrieved 4 September 2018.</ref>

In the [[United States general elections, 2006|2006 mid-term elections]], Flake had no [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] opponent and easily defeated the [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian Party]] candidate, Jason Blair, with 74% of the vote.<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/ELECTION/2006//pages/results/states/AZ/H/06/index.html U.S. House of Representatives / Arizona 06]. CNN. Retrieved on November 5, 2012.</ref>

Flake was a member of the [[Liberty Caucus]], a group of [[Libertarianism|libertarian]]-leaning Republican congressmen.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.thelibertycommittee.org/|title= The Liberty Committee|accessdate=June 24, 2007}}</ref> He was also a member of the [[Republican Study Committee]].
* '''[[United States House Committee on Appropriations|Committee on Appropriations]]'''

** [[United States House Appropriations Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies|Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies]]
** [[United States House Appropriations Subcommittee on Military Construction, Veterans Affairs, and Related Agencies|Subcommittee on Military Construction, Veterans Affairs, and Related Agencies]]
** [[United States House Appropriations Subcommittee on Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies|Subcommittee on Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies]]

{{Main|2012 United States Senate election in Arizona}}In February 2011, Flake announced that he was running for the U.S. Senate seat being vacated by the retiring [[Assistant party leaders of the United States Senate|Senate Minority Whip]] [[Jon Kyl]] in [[United States Senate election in Arizona, 2012|2012]].<ref>Tang, Layla (February 14, 2011) [https://web.archive.org/web/20170828014741/http://www.kgun9.com/Global/story.asp?S=14025521 "U.S. Rep. Flake announces Senate bid"], KGUN9-TV. Retrieved 2011-02-14.</ref> Flake easily won the Republican nomination against real estate businessman Wil Cardon.<ref name="primary">{{cite news|last1=Zapler|first1=Mike|last2=Isenstadt|first2=Alex|title=Arizona House primary results: Ben Quayle booted from Congress|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0812/80331.html|newspaper=Politico|date=August 29, 2012}}</ref> He faced former United States' [[Surgeon General of the United States|surgeon general]] [[Richard Carmona]], who sought office for the first time in the general election. In May 2012, Flake led Carmona by 13 points in the polls. In an October 2012 poll by [[Public Policy Polling]], Flake was trailing Carmona by two points.<ref>{{cite news|last=Finley|first=Allysia|title=Arizona's Flake Out|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10000872396390444223104578036583358398120 |accessdate=October 24, 2012|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|date=October 5, 2012}}</ref> After the race tightened, the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' criticized a controversial Flake ad that accused Carmona of having "issues with anger, with ethics, and with women."<ref>{{cite news|last=Finley|first=Allysia|title=Flake's Flip-Out|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10000872396390443675404578057433202686920 |accessdate=October 24, 2012|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|date=October 15, 2012}}</ref> Flake was endorsed by the ''[[Casa Grande Dispatch]]'',<ref>{{cite news|title=Editorials: Paton in 1st District|url=http://www.trivalleycentral.com/opinion/our_view/editorials-paton-in-st-district/article_e6b6c9da-1164-11e2-b6bc-001a4bcf887a.html|accessdate=October 24, 2012|newspaper=Casa Grande Dispatch|date=October 8, 2012}}</ref> the [[United States Chamber of Commerce]],<ref>{{cite news|title=U.S., Arizona Chambers of Commerce Endorse Jeff Flake for U.S. Senate|url=http://www.westernfreepress.com/2012/10/10/u-s-arizona-chambers-of-commerce-endorse-jeff-flake-for-u-s-senate/|accessdate=October 24, 2012|newspaper=Western Free Press|date=October 10, 2012}}</ref> the [[Senate Conservatives Fund]],<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.senateconservatives.com/post/1431|title= Jeff Flake for U.S. Senate|author=U.S. Senator Jim DeMint, SCF Chairman |date= April 20, 2012|website=senateconservatives.com |publisher= |access-date= October 24, 2017|quote=}}</ref> and the [[Club for Growth]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Club for Growth PAC Endorses Jeff Flake for Senate|url=http://www.clubforgrowth.org/perm/?postID=14758|accessdate=October 24, 2012|newspaper=Club For Growth|date=February 14, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121122191148/http://www.clubforgrowth.org/perm/?postID=14758|archive-date=November 22, 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref>
Flake succeeded retiring Republican U.S. Senator [[Jon Kyl]] on January 3, 2013.

Flake used his experience surviving in the wild for six days with a Democratic Senator to develop an idea to end partisan gridlock in Washington. In 2014, Flake and U.S. Senator [[Martin Heinrich]] (D-[[New Mexico|NM]]) were featured on a [[Discovery Channel]] reality TV show, ''Rival Survival'', where the two stayed on a small [[Micronesia]]n island for six days. Flake later joked during a speech at the [[National Press Club (United States)|National Press Club]] that sending both Senate leaders (Majority Leader Senator Harry Reid [D-[[Nevada|NV]]] and Minority Leader Mitch McConnell [R-[[Kentucky|KY]]]) to a remote island together might reduce partisanship and allow more legislation to move forward.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.politico.com/story/2014/09/jeff-flake-harry-reid-mitch-mcconnell-111102.html|title = Jeff Flake: Send Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell to island|last = Ray|first = Jordan|date = September 18, 2014|work = Politico|accessdate = October 16, 2014}}</ref>

Flake was on the field during practice for the annual [[Congressional Baseball Game]] when the [[2017 Congressional baseball shooting|Congressional baseball shooting]] happened on June 14, 2017. He said the attendees were like "sitting ducks" and that it was likely that the Capitol Police saved their lives:<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.fox10phoenix.com/news/arizona-news/261416113-story|title=Senator Jeff Flake recounts baseball practice shooting|last=Martinez|first=Marc|date=2017-06-14|work=KSAZ Fox-10|access-date=2017-06-15|language=en-US}}</ref>

All of a sudden, we heard a very loud shot. Everybody thought 'sounds like a gun'. The gunman was over by the third base dugout, with a clear view of the field and everybody on it. A lot of us dove into the dugout and tried to get as many as we could, but at that point, there was firing behind us from the security detail, the Capitol Police, and I started yelling back, 'are you friendly?' – making sure that it was our guy, because we didn't know if there were other shooters that had us surrounded, and were coming into the dugout.

Former President Obama called Flake that morning to extend his best wishes and prayers for the victims. Flake had flown with Obama from Washington, D.C., to Arizona in 2011 after the shooting of then-Congresswoman [[Gabrielle Giffords]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/06/14/barack-obama-jeff-flake-congress-baseball-shooting-239559|title=Obama reaches out to Sen. Flake after shooting|last=Schor|first=Elana|date=2017-06-14|work=Politico|access-date=2017-06-15}}</ref>

On October 24, 2017, Flake announced in a speech that he would not seek a second term in the Senate.<ref name="azcentral.com">{{cite web|last1=Nowicki|first1=Dan|title=Arizona's Jeff Flake announces he will not seek reelection to the U.S. Senate|url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/2017/10/24/republican-senator-jeff-flake-announces-not-running-senate-reelection-gop-primary-ward-trump/793952001/|website=AZCentral|accessdate=24 October 2017}}</ref> Flake's speech, which was described by [[McKay Coppins]] as a "thundering indictment of his party, his president, and his country's political culture," was called "the most important speech of 2017" by [[Chris Cillizza]].<ref name="The Tragedy of Jeff Flake">{{cite news|last1=Coppins|first1=McKay|title=The Tragedy of Jeff Flake|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/10/jeff-flake-interview/543912/|accessdate=25 October 2017|work=[[The Atlantic]]|date=October 25, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Cillizza|first1=Chris|title=Jeff Flake gave the most important speech of 2017|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/10/25/politics/flake-speech-trump-gop/index.html|accessdate=25 October 2017|work=[[CNN]]|date=October 25, 2017}}</ref>

In May 2018, Flake stated that he would donate to Democratic Senator [[Joe Manchin]]'s campaign if [[Don Blankenship]] (who had served time in prison) won the West Virginia Republican Senate primary. Blankenship was defeated by [[Patrick Morrisey]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=CARNEY|first1=JORDAIN|title=Flake says he'll donate to Manchin if Blankenship wins primary|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/floor-action/senate/386599-flake-says-hell-donate-to-manchin-if-blankenship-wins-primary|website=The Hill|accessdate=15 May 2018|date=2018-05-07}}</ref>

Presidency of Richard Nixon
added: === Committee for the Re-Election of the President ===
{{Main|White House Plumbers|Committee for the Re-Election of the President}}

After the Supreme Court denied the Nixon administration's request to prevent the publication of the Pentagon Papers, Nixon and Ehrlichman established the White House Special Investigations Unit, also known as the "Plumbers." The Plumbers were charged with preventing future [[news leak]]s and retaliating against [[Daniel Ellsberg]], who had been behind the leaking of the Pentagon Papers. Among those who joined the Plumbers were [[G. Gordon Liddy]], E. Howard Hunt, and Charles Colson. Shortly after the establishment of the Plumbers, the organization broke into the office of Ellsberg's psychiatrist.{{sfn|Patterson|pp=756–757}} Rather than relying on the [[Republican National Committee]], Nixon's re-election campaign was primarily waged through the [[Committee for the Re-Election of the President]] (CRP), whose top leadership was composed of former White House personnel.{{sfn|Leuchtenberg|pp=514-515}} Liddy and Hunt became involved with the CRP, conducting espionage on Democrats.{{sfn|Patterson|pp=772–773}}

During the 1972 Democratic primaries, Nixon and his allies believed that Senator McGovern would be the weakest plausible Democratic nominee in the general election, and the CRP worked to bolster McGovern's strength. Nixon was not informed about the details of each CRP undertaking, but he approved of the overall operation.{{Sfn|Small|1999|pp=253–254}} The CRP especially targeted Muskie, secretly employing Muskie's driver as a spy. The CRP also established fake organizations that nominally supported Muskie, and used those organizations to attack other Democratic candidates; Senator Henry Jackson was accused of having been arrested for homosexual activities, while Humphrey was alleged to have been involved in a drunk driving incident.{{Sfn|Small|1999|pp=254–255}} In June 1972, Hunt and Liddy led a break-in of the [[Democratic National Committee]]'s headquarters at the [[Watergate complex]]. The break-in was foiled by the police, and the Nixon administration denied any involvement in the incident.{{Sfn|Small|1999|pp=255–256}} The break-in perpetrators were indicted on in September 1972, but federal judge [[John Sirica]] ordered a gag order on the case until after the election. Though Watergate remained in the news during the 1972 campaign, it had relatively little effect on the election.{{Sfn|Small|1999|pp=260–261}} The motivation for the Watergate break-in remains a matter of dispute.{{sfn|Patterson|p=772}}

title: Mark Milley
added: On June 1, 2020, during [[George Floyd protests in Washington, D.C.|protests in Washington, D.C.]], in the wake of the [[killing of George Floyd]], Milley joined National Guardsmen and various police forces assembling in [[Lafayette Square, Washington, D.C.|Lafayette Square]], across the street from the [[White House]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=The crackdown before Trump's photo op: How law enforcement cleared protesters outside the White House|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/investigations/2020/06/08/timeline-trump-church-photo-op/|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-11|website=Washington Post|language=en}}</ref> Minutes later, the troops and police used [[tear gas]] and other [[riot control]] tactics to disperse peaceable protestors so Trump could stage a [[Donald Trump photo-op at St. John's Church|photo-op]] at nearby [[St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square|St. John's Episcopal Church]]. About half an hour after that, Milley, in combat uniform, walked alongside the president from the White House to the church, drawing sharp criticism from former military officers and others.<ref>{{Cite news|last=|first=|date=2020|title=Pentagon Distances Leaders From Trump Photo Op|work=US News|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/national-news/articles/2020-06-02/pentagon-distances-esper-milley-from-trumps-church-photo-op|url-status=live|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last1=Schmitt|first1=Eric|last2=Cooper|first2=Helene|last3=Gibbons-Neff|first3=Thomas|last4=Haberman|first4=Maggie|date=June 3, 2020|title=Esper Breaks With Trump on Using Troops Against Protesters|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/03/us/politics/esper-milley-trump-protest.html|access-date=June 4, 2020|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Trump's church photo-op took Esper, Milley by surprise|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/trump-s-church-photo-op-took-defense-secretary-esper-gen-n1222391|access-date=June 2, 2020|website=NBC News|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Spinelli|first=Dan|title=Top general defends his actions after appearing in Trump photo op|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2020/06/top-general-defends-his-actions-after-appearing-in-trump-photo-op/|access-date=June 2, 2020|website=Mother Jones|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Trump Finally Gets the War He Wanted|url=https://www.defenseone.com/ideas/2020/06/trump-finally-gets-war-he-wanted/165825/|access-date=June 2, 2020|website=Defense One}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=The Battle of Lafayette Square and the undermining of American democracy|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/why-mark-milley-striding-behind-trump-through-lafayette-square-was-so-troubling/2020/06/02/81ef5388-a503-11ea-b473-04905b1af82b_story.html|author=[[Robert Kagan]]|date=June 2, 2020|newspaper=Washington Post}}</ref> Milley subsequently refused to testify in front of Congress regarding the military's role in the response to the protests.<ref>{{Cite web|first=Zachary |last=Cohen|title=Esper and Milley refuse to testify about military's role in policing protests, source says|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/06/05/politics/esper-milley-refuse-to-testify-house-armed-services-committee/index.html|access-date=June 6, 2020|website=CNN}}</ref> He reportedly considered resigning over the incident<ref>{{Cite web|title=Milley discussed resigning over role in Trump's church photo op|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/joint-chiefs-chairman-milley-discussed-resigning-over-role-trump-s-n1230116|access-date=2020-06-17|website=NBC News|language=en}}</ref>, but chose instead to address it in a video recorded as his commencement address to the National Defense University. In that speech, streamed on June 11, Milley said he should not have been at the event because his presence created a perception of military involvement in domestic politics.<ref> ''[https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/11/us/george-floyd-protests.html Live Updates on George Floyd Protests: Top General Apologizes for Role in Trump Photo Op]'', The New York Times, June 11, 2020</ref>

deleted: {{main|Planned presidential transition of Mitt Romney|Mitt Romney presidential campaign, 2012#"Readiness Project"}}

Every major presidential nominee has a transition team in place well before the actual election. "President-elect" [[Mitt Romney]]'s transition website went live for a brief time the day after the election before being taken down. title: United States presidential transition
added: {{main|Planned presidential transition of Mitt Romney|Mitt Romney presidential campaign, 2012#"Readiness Project"}}

Every major presidential nominee has a transition team in place well before the actual election. "President-elect" [[Mitt Romney]]'s transition website went live for a brief time the day after the election before being taken down. However, it was preserved by members of the media and provides an interesting look into "what if?"
Former HHS Secretary and Utah Governor [[Mike Leavitt]] chaired a team that was have coordinated the aborted transition.

The following year, Leavitt published a 138-page study of what was called the ""Readiness Project"" entitled ''Romney Readiness Project 2012: Retrospectives and Lessons Learned''.<ref name="KeaneTransition"/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Hicken|first1=Jackie|title=Blueprint outlines work former Utah Gov. Mike Leavitt, others did to prepare for President Romney|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/765630884/Blueprint-outlines-work-former-Utah-Gov-Mike-Leavitt-others-did-to-prepare-for-President-Romney.html?pg=all|accessdate=January 22, 2016|work=[[Deseret News]]|date=May 29, 2013}}</ref> In the foreword, the former Massachussetts governor wrote, "My campaign was not successful but our Readiness Project team was."<ref name="ClarkReadiness">{{cite news|last1=Clark|first1=Charles|title=Romney Readiness Team Reunites to Review Lessons Learned|url=http://www.govexec.com/management/2013/05/romney-readiness-team-reunites-review-lessons-learned/63917/|accessdate=May 13, 2016|work=[[Government Executive]]|date=May 29, 2013}}</ref>

title: Electoral history of Joe Biden
deleted: In 2020, for most of the cycle Biden appeared to be on track to victory, but on October 7, his chances of winning were ended in the vice presidential debate. His running mate, Phony Kamala Harris, self-destructed in incredible fashion, appearing unprepared and blatantly lying in response to each question. Both Vice President Mike Pence and moderator Susan Page called out Harris for her lies, and Pence went on to demonstrate the many radial far-left positions that Phony Kamala, and therefore the Biden-Harris ticket, supported. These included gun confiscation by force, a socialistic healthcare takeover, abolishing all police departments, and eliminating energy. Once the American people saw this, the false image of Biden as a respectable moderate was shattered, and his true nature was revealed. As a result of Phony Kamala's debate meltdown, the Biden-Harris ticket's polling lead disappeared and they went on to lose in a landslide to President Donald J. Trump.

title: Barry Goldwater
deleted: Remaining in the Arizona [[Air National Guard]] and [[Air Force Reserve]] after the war, he eventually retired as a [[Command Pilot]] with the rank of [[Major general (United States)|major general]].<ref>{{cite web| publisher=U.S. Air Force |title=Major General Barry M Goldwater |url=http://www.af.mil/information/bios/bio.asp?bioID=5574|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130331211943/http://www.af.mil/information/bios/bio.asp?bioID=5574|archivedate=March 31, 2013}}</ref> By that time, he had flown 165 different types of aircraft. As an Air Force Reserve major general, he continued piloting aircraft, to include the [[Boeing B-52 Stratofortress|B-52 Stratofortress]], until late in his military career.

As a U.S. Senator, Goldwater had a sign in his office that referenced his military career and mindset: "There are old pilots and there are bold pilots, but there are no old, bold pilots."<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=The Gold Standard: Barry Goldwater's 30-year U.S. Senate career made him an icon in Arizona politics|last=Harris|first=Don|date=12 Mar 2012|work=Arizona Capital Times|access-date=}}</ref>

title: Joe Biden
deleted: In retrospect, Biden's family came to believe the early end to his presidential campaign had been a blessing in disguise, for had he still been campaigning in 1988, he might well not have stopped to seek medical attention and the condition might have become unsurvivable.<ref>Biden, ''Promises to Keep'', p. 225</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/05/04/us/biden-resting-after-surgery-for-second-brain-aneurysm.html|title=Biden Resting After Surgery For Second Brain Aneurysm|date=May 4, 1988|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> In 2013, Biden said, "they take a saw and they cut your head off", and "they literally had to take the top of my head off." He also said he was told he would have less than a 50% chance of full recovery.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/campaigns/surgeon-who-operated-on-joe-biden-hes-better-now-than-before-brain-surgery|title=Surgeon who operated on Biden: He's better now than before brain surgery|date=April 26, 2019|website=Washington Examiner}}</ref>

Dionne}}</ref> He repeated the course and passed with high marks.<ref>{{cite news | author=Lee May | title=Biden Admits Plagiarism in Writing Law School Brief | newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] | date=September 18, 1987 |url=http://articles.latimes.com/print/1987-09-18/news/mn-5748_1_law-school}}</ref> In 1987, the Delaware Supreme Court's Board of Professional Responsibility reviewed the incident at Biden's request, and concluded that he had violated no rules.<ref name="nyt-cleared">{{cite news | title=Professional Board Clears Biden In Two Allegations of Plagiarism | url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=950DE1DD1230F93AA15756C0A96F948260 | agency=[[Associated Press]] |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] | date=May 29, 1989}}</ref> Biden graduated with a [[Juris Doctor|law degree]] in 1968, ranked 76th in his class of 85,<ref name=wpbclina/><ref name=ctbadmerr/> and was [[Admission to the bar in the United States|admitted]] to the [[Delaware State Bar Association|Delaware bar]] in 1969.<ref name="cong-bio">{{cite dictionary |dictionary=[[Biographical Directory of the United States Congress]]|url=http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=B000444 |title=Biden, Joseph Robinette, Jr.|accessdate=August 19, 2008}}</ref>

title: Mike Feuer
deleted: In 2014, Feuer targeted medical marijuana dispensaries in the city of Los Angeles.<ref name=mj>{{cite web|author=Rick Orlov |url=http://www.dailynews.com/government-and-politics/20141202/400-los-angeles-marijuana-shops-closed-home-delivery-under-fire |title=400 Los Angeles marijuana shops closed, home delivery under fire – Daily News |publisher=Dailynews.com |date= |accessdate=2020-03-10}}</ref> He announced that he was targeting medical marijuana dispensaries and a medical marijuana home-delivery service Nestdrop run by smartphone app.<ref name=mj/> Feuer believed there was a voter mandate from Proposition D, saying: “At the same time, they [voters] felt there were too many dispensaries — and there are too many, too close together and too close to sensitive sites like schools, playgrounds and child care centers."<ref name=mj/> Feuer closed half of the City's marijuana dispensaries and filed a complaint against Nestdrop seeking to prevent them from providing home-delivery of medical marijuana.<ref name=mj/>

Some, at the time, criticized Feuer for his actions. Kris Hermes, spokesman for Americans for Safe Access, said: “He [Feuer] should be figuring out ways to improve access instead of figuring out how to shut down dispensaries. Delivery services have developed because of local officials who are trying to shut down dispensaries. Also, delivery services are a way that people with mobility problems can get their medicine.”<ref name=mj/>

title: Mike Feuer
added: Feuer was among many politicians in the City of Los Angeles who took money from campaign donor Justin Kim.<ref>[https://www.lamag.com/citythinkblog/city-hall-corruption/ Los Angeles Magazine - "The Investigation into City Hall Corruption May Soon Take A New, Bigger Step"]</ref> When Kim plead guilty to bribing city councilmembers to the tune of hundreds of thousands of dollars, Feuer was disclosed as a recipient of these donations. Feuer's campaign has said there was nothing suspicious in his conduct, and he has returned the more than $13,000 raised by Kim. Nonetheless, it has been stated that this citywide scandal could play a role in the 2022 election.<ref>[https://news.yahoo.com/l-politicians-took-campaign-donations-120025992.html The Los Angeles Times (on Yahoo News) - "L.A.'s politicians took his campaign donations. Then he admitted arranging a bribe"]</ref>

=== FBI raid of City Attorney's Office ===

In July of 2019, FBI agents raided the offices of Mike Feuer and the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power. The raid stemmed from the City Attorney’s handling of the DWP overbilling scandal that dates back to 2013. There were reports that Feuer’s own outside defense counsel recruited a plaintiff to sue the city over the DWP billing errors.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.scpr.org/news/2019/07/22/90372/fbi-raids-offices-of-la-city-attorney-and-dwp-in-c/|title=FBI Searches City Attorney, LADWP Records|last=Radio|first=Southern California Public|date=2019-07-22|website=Southern California Public Radio|access-date=2020-04-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2019-07-22/fbi-searches-dwp-headquarters-in-downtown-l-a|title=FBI raids at DWP, L.A. City Hall related to fallout from billing debacle|date=2019-07-23|website=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US|access-date=2020-04-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-city-attorney-feuer-mayor-dwp-case-threaten-20190715-story.html|title=FBI raids and DWP scandal pose a political threat to L.A.'s ambitious city attorney|date=2019-07-25|website=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US|access-date=2020-04-30}}</ref>

title: United States Electoral College
deleted: '''Voting During a Pandemic: the Absentee Ballot vs Voting in Person'''

The [[absentee ballot]] is a voting method in which a ballot for an election is filled out, notarized, and mailed before the election date. This method is optional and was utilized by about 1 out of 4 Americans in the 2018 Presidential election. If a pandemic occurs, the absentee ballot is seen as an essential service because it entails limited human to human interaction, if any at all. While the United States is enduring the pandemic of 2020, known as the Coronavirus or [[COVID-19 pandemic|COVID-19]], some citizens criticize the service of voting by absentee ballot in comparison to voting in person.

Those who do not favor the encouraged voting method by absentee ballot are opposed to the idea for many reasons. A few reasons being that 13 out of 50 states cannot count absentee ballots until election day, while another three states cannot count ballots until polls are closed. This poses an issue because it is anticipated to prolong voting reports that many follow live every election. It will extend the time it takes to announce America's elected president. Another common issue that voters conclude is that the absentee ballot is an opportunity for political parties to cause [[voter suppression]] and influence votes. In the last 2018 presidential election, it was reported that in states such as Georgia, Florida, and many more states that thousands of absentee ballots were thrown out due to errors. The discrepancies that can make a ballot insufficient can vary from stating the incorrect address, not checking or signing in a signatory box, and misstating or not at all reporting a person's date of birth. Due to these errors and other possible errors, voters are not confident in using an absentee ballot.

Those in support of this method view it as an opportunity to avoid the possibility of contracting Coronavirus. This option makes it possible for persons to vote from a remote location no matter their physical circumstances if they are eligible. All 50 states currently offer an absentee ballot option, but only five states initiate mailing absentee ballots without a person having to request one. Washington, Utah, Hawaii, Oregon, and Colorado mail their residents absentee ballots automatically. In all other states, residents can apply for an absentee ballot online, by mail, over the phone, or in person.

<ref>{{cite web |last1=Povich |first1=Elaine |title=Fearing Delays and Chaos, Swing States Weight Early Counting of Mailed-In Ballots |url=https://www.pewtrusts.org/en/research-and-analysis/blogs/stateline/2020/08/28/fearing-delays-and-chaos-swing-states-weigh-early-counting-of-mail-in-ballots |website=pewtrust.org |publisher=Pew |accessdate=25 October 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Root |first1=Danielle |title=Voter Suppression During the 2018 Midterm Elections |url=https://www.americanprogress.org/issues/democracy/reports/2018/11/20/461296/voter-suppression-2018-midterm-elections/ |website=americanprogress.org |publisher=Center for American Progress |accessdate=25 October 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Young |first1=Jay |title=Commentary: Sorry, but not all of us can vote from home |url=https://search-proquest-com.mctproxy.mnpals.net/docview/2400722871/citation/AFC72D116BEB4FD6PQ/1?accountid=28000 |website=mnpals.net |publisher=Tribune Publishing Company, LLC |accessdate=25 October 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Treene |first1=Alayna |title=Axios: Congressmen Reintroduce bill to vote from home districts amid coronavirus outbreak |url=https://search-proquest-com.mctproxy.mnpals.net/docview/2428514466/citation/D90310BCA5DA4B83PQ/1?accountid=28000 |accessdate=25 October 2020 |publisher=Newstex |date=March 9, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Ward |first1=Leah |title=Simon says: Vote from home |url=https://search-proquest-com.mctproxy.mnpals.net/docview/2417888349?pq-origsite=summon |website=mnpals.net |publisher=The Daily Globe |accessdate=25 October 2020}}</ref>
