title: Political interference with science agencies by the first Trump administration
deleted: The position of chief scientist in the [[United States Department of Agriculture|Department of Agriculture]] was not filled. The administration nominated [[Sam Clovis]] to be chief scientist, but he had no scientific background and the White House later withdrew the nomination.<ref name=":03">{{Cite news|date=June 9, 2018|title=In the Trump Administration, Science Is Unwelcome. So Is Advice.|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/09/climate/trump-administration-science.html|access-date=June 9, 2018|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

title: Political interference with science agencies by the first Trump administration
Political interference with science agencies by the first Trump administration
added: In a 2020 editorial, the ''[[New England Journal of Medicine]]'', in an editorial signed by 34 editors, denounced the Trump administration's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic. The article marked the first time in the prominent medical journal's history that it had condemned or supported any political candidate.<ref name=NYTNEJM>[https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/07/health/new-england-journal-trump.html]</ref><ref name=NEJMEditorial>https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMe2029812</ref> In the editorial, the journal strongly criticized the Trump administration's rejection of scientific expertise; its attempts to politicize and undermine the FDA, NIH, and CDC, and its decision "to ignore and even denigrate experts" within government institutions.<ref name=NYTNEJM/><ref name=NEJMEditorial/>

title: Political interference with science agencies by the first Trump administration
added: Inan October2020 editorial, the ''[[New England Journal of Medicine]]'', in an editorial signed by 34 editors, denounced the Trump administration's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic. The article marked the first time in the prominent medical journal's history that it had condemned or supported any political candidate.<ref name=NYTNEJM>Gina Kolata,[https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/07/health/new-england-journal-trump.htmlIn a First, New England Journal of Medicine Joins Never-Trumpers], ''New York Times'' (October 7, 2020).</ref><ref name=NEJMEditorial>[https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMe2029812Editorial: Dying in a Leadership Vacuum], ''New England Journal of Medicine'' (October 8, 2020).</ref> In the editorial, the journal strongly criticized the Trump administration's rejection of scientific expertise; its attempts to politicize and undermine the FDA, NIH, and CDC, and its decision "to ignore and even denigrate experts" within government institutions.<ref name=NYTNEJM/><ref name=NEJMEditorial/>

title: Political interference with science agencies by the first Trump administration
deleted: During the [[2016 United States presidential election|2016 United States presidential campaign]], Trump stated his intention to strip [[National Aeronautics and Space Administration|NASA]]'s Earth Science division of its funding, a move that "would mean the elimination of NASA's world-renowned research into temperature, ice, clouds and other climate phenomena".<ref name="milman-2016">{{cite news|last=Milman|first=Oliver|date=23 November 2016|title=Trump to scrap NASA climate research in crackdown on 'politicized science'|work=The Guardian|location=London, United Kingdom|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/nov/22/nasa-earth-donald-trump-eliminate-climate-change-research|access-date=2017-02-27|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> Subsequently, the Trump administration successfully nominated [[Jim Bridenstine]], who had no background in science and rejected the scientific consensus on climate change, to lead NASA.<ref name=":03"/>

title: Political interference with science agencies by the first Trump administration
Political interference with science agencies by the first Trump administration
deleted: In October 2020, the [[Associated Press]] reported that the Trump administration had installed two political operatives with no public-health background at the CDC's Atlanta headquarters. Their responsibilities, according to CDC and administration officials, were to monitor CDC scientists and director Redfield as part of an effort to control the organization's public messaging.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://apnews.com/article/election-2020-virus-outbreak-pandemics-public-health-new-york-e321f4c9098b4db4dd6b1eda76a5179e |title=White House puts 'politicals' at CDC to try to control info |first1=Jason |last1=Dearen |first2=Mike |last2=Stobbe |first3=Richard |last3=Lardner |website=[[Associated Press]] |date=October 16, 2020 |accessdate=October 16, 2020}}</ref>

title: Political interference with science agencies by the first Trump administration
Political interference with science agencies by the first Trump administration
Political interference with science agencies by the first Trump administration
deleted: President [[Donald Trump]], inaugurated on January 20, 2017, did not name a [[Science Advisor to the President]] until July 2018, when he appointed meteorologist [[Kelvin Droegemeier]] to the position.<ref name=":03"/><ref>{{cite news |last1=Reardon |first1=Sara |last2=Witze |first2=Alexandra |title=The wait is over: Trump taps meteorologist as White House science adviser |url=https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-018-05862-y |publisher=Nature |date=31 July 2018}}</ref> Science advisory committees at multiple agencies including the [[Department of the Interior]], the [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]], and the [[Food and Drug Administration]] have been disbanded.<ref name=":03">{{Cite news|date=June 9, 2018|title=In the Trump Administration, Science Is Unwelcome. So Is Advice|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/09/climate/trump-administration-science.html|last=Davenport|first=Coral||access-date=June 9, 2018|issn=0362-4331}}{{subscription}}</ref> Many of Trump's first cabinet picks were people with a history of opposition to the agency they were named to head, including [[Rick Perry]] as [[Secretary of Energy]], [[Betsey DeVos]] as [[United States Secretary of Education|Secretary of Education]] and [[Ben Carson]] as [[Secretary of Housing and Urban Development]].<ref name = conflict/> In the science area the head of the [[Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA), [[Scott Pruitt]], had repeatedly sued the EPA when he was Oklahoma attorney general, and described himself as a "leading advocate against the EPA’s activist agenda".<ref name = conflict/>

title: Political interference with science agencies by the first Trump administration
added: The administration of President [[Donald Trump]] has repeatedly [[Politicization of science|politicized science]] by pressuring health and science agencies to change their reporting and recommendations to conform to his policies and public comments.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/28/climate/trump-administration-war-on-science.html|title=Science Under Attack: How Trump Is Sidelining Researchers and Their Work|last1=Plumer|first1=Brad|last2=Cavenport|first2=Coral|date=December 28, 2019|work=The New York Times|accessdate=September 23, 2020}}</ref> This has particularly been true with regard to the [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United States]].<ref name=":2"/>

Trump and his appointees have pressured federal health and science agencies to take particular actions that Trump favors and to support his public pronouncements.<ref name=CNN-testing-pressure>{{cite news |url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/26/politics/cdc-coronavirus-testing-guidance/index.html |title=CDC was pressured 'from the top down' to change coronavirus testing guidance, official says |date=August 26, 2020 |publisher=CNN |first1=Nick |last1=Valencia |first2=Sara |last2=Murray |author2link=Sara Murray (journalist) |first3=Kristen |last3=Holmes |accessdate=August 26, 2020}}</ref> He has sometimes claimed that there is a "[[deep state in the United States|deep state]]" conspiracy among federal scientists, whose members delay approval of vaccines and treatments because they want to hurt him politically or prevent his re-election.<ref name = pressed>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/12/us/politics/trump-coronavirus-treatment-vaccine.html|title=Trump Pressed for Plasma Therapy. Officials Worry, Is an Unvetted Vaccine Next?|date=September 12, 2020|work=The New York Times|accessdate=September 13, 2020}}</ref>

President [[Donald Trump]], inaugurated on January 20, 2017, did not name a [[Science Advisor to the President]] until July 2018, when he appointed meteorologist [[Kelvin Droegemeier]] to the position.<ref name=":03"/><ref>{{cite news |last1=Reardon |first1=Sara |last2=Witze |first2=Alexandra |title=The wait is over: Trump taps meteorologist as White House science adviser |url=https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-018-05862-y |publisher=Nature |date=31 July 2018}}</ref> Science advisory committees at multiple agencies including the [[Department of the Interior]], the [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]], and the [[Food and Drug Administration]] have been disbanded.<ref name=":03">{{Cite news|date=June 9, 2018|title=In the Trump Administration, Science Is Unwelcome. So Is Advice|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/09/climate/trump-administration-science.html|last=Davenport|first=Coral||access-date=June 9, 2018|issn=0362-4331}}{{subscription}}</ref> Many of Trump's first cabinet picks were people with a history of opposition to the agency they were named to head, including [[Rick Perry]] as [[Secretary of Energy]], [[Betsey DeVos]] as [[United States Secretary of Education|Secretary of Education]] and [[Ben Carson]] as [[Secretary of Housing and Urban Development]].<ref name = conflict/> In the science area the head of the [[Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA), [[Scott Pruitt]], had repeatedly sued the EPA when he was Oklahoma attorney general, and described himself as a "leading advocate against the EPA’s activist agenda".<ref name = conflict/>
===Suppressing and altering communications from health agencies===

In April 2020, political strategist and lobbyist [[Michael Caputo]] was appointed by the White House as assistant secretary for public affairs of the [[United States Department of Health and Human Services|Department of Health and Human Services]] (HHS), in control of the department's communications strategy.<ref name="MajorPostHHS">{{cite web | last1=McCarthy | first1=Robert J. | title=Michael Caputo, Trump loyalist, gains major post in Health and Human Services | url=https://buffalonews.com/2020/04/16/caputo-trump-loyalist-gains-major-post-in-hhs/ | date=April 16, 2020 | work=[[The Buffalo News]] | accessdate=April 19, 2020}}</ref><ref name="Diamond & Lippman">{{cite web | last1=Diamond | first1=Dan | last2=Lippman | first2=Daniel | title=White House snubs Azar, installs Trump loyalist Michael Caputo as HHS spokesperson | url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/04/15/michael-caputo-azar-hhs-189046 | date=April 15, 2020 | work=[[Politico]] | accessdate=April 19, 2020}}</ref> He appointed [[Paul Elias Alexander|Paul Alexander]], a Ph.D. health researcher, as his top advisor.<ref name = Diamond/> They and other HHS officials attempted to control the content of information coming from the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|Centers for Disease Control]] (CDC) whenever it was deemed to contradict or undermine what Trump was saying publicly.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|first=Dan|last=Diamond|title=Trump officials interfered with CDC reports on Covid-19|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/09/11/exclusive-trump-officials-interfered-with-cdc-reports-on-covid-19-412809|date=September 11, 2020|access-date=September 12, 2020|website=Politico|publisher=[[Capitol News Company]]|location=Washington, D.C.|language=en}}</ref><ref name = Diamond/> In June 2020 the White House installed two political operatives with no public-health background at the CDC's Atlanta headquarters. Their responsibilities, according to CDC and administration officials, were to monitor CDC scientists and CDC Director [[Robert Redfield]], as part of the ongoing effort to control the organization's public messaging. At first their role at CDC was undefined; one was later named Redfield's acting chief of staff and the other as her deputy. Although officially reporting to Redfield, they communicated regularly with Caputo and Alexander at HHS.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://apnews.com/article/election-2020-virus-outbreak-pandemics-public-health-new-york-e321f4c9098b4db4dd6b1eda76a5179e |title=White House puts 'politicals' at CDC to try to control info |first1=Jason |last1=Dearen |first2=Mike |last2=Stobbe |first3=Richard |last3=Lardner |website=[[Associated Press]] |date=October 16, 2020 |accessdate=October 16, 2020}}</ref>

Caputo in June was trying to gain control of the ''[[Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report]] (MMWR)'', a weekly publication issued by the CDC; it is the CDC's main vehicle for imparting current information and recommendations about public health to physicians, researchers, and the general public. In September 2020 it was reported that political appointees at HHS had tried repeatedly to change, delay, or remove reports about COVID-19 from ''MMWR'' if they undermined Trump's claims that the outbreak was under control.<ref name = Diamond/> Caputo confirmed the September report, saying that attempts to influence the content of ''MMWR'' had been going on for 3 1/2 months. He said it was because the ''MMWR'' reporting contained "political content" as well as scientific information, adding that the changes suggested by his office were "infrequently" accepted by CDC.<ref name = Sun>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2020/09/12/trump-control-over-cdc-reports/|title=Trump officials seek greater control over CDC reports on coronavirus|last=Sun|first=Lena H.|date=September 12, 2020|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=September 14, 2020}}</ref> A ''MMWR'' report downplaying the benefit of hydroxychloroquine as a COVID-19 treatment was delayed for almost a month as Alexander questioned the political leanings of the authors.<ref name = Diamond>{{cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/09/11/exclusive-trump-officials-interfered-with-cdc-reports-on-covid-19-412809|title=Trump officials interfered with CDC reports on Covid-19|last=Diamond|first=Dan|date=September 11, 2020|work=Politico|accessdate=September 14, 2020}}</ref> A report on the susceptibility of schoolchildren to the virus was also held up.<ref name = Sun/> Alexander demanded, unsuccessfully, that he be allowed to review and edit all issues of ''MMWR'' before they were published.<ref name = Sun/>  On August 8, Alexander wrote to Redfield saying that "CDC to me appears to be writing hit pieces on the administration". He asked Redfield to change some reports that had already been published.<ref name=Diamond/> Alexander later said that the CDC had written "pseudoscientific reports" and that he was in a better position to "make the judgment whether this is crap".<ref name = Weiland/> CDC resisted many of the changes, but increasingly allowed HHS personnel to review articles and suggest changes before publication.<ref name = Sun/>

In August and early September 2020, Alexander sent several messages to press officers at the NIH attempting to direct [[Anthony Fauci]]'s media comments. Among his demands were that Fauci should refrain from promoting the wearing of [[Face masks during the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States|masks]] by children in school and [[COVID-19 testing]] of children. Fauci later said that he had not received the messages and would not have been influenced by them if he had.<ref name=fauci>{{Cite news| last = Owermohle| first = Sarah| title = Emails show HHS official trying to muzzle Fauci| work = Politico| date = September 9, 2020| url = https://www.politico.com/news/2020/09/09/emails-show-hhs-muzzle-fauci-410861}}</ref>

On September 16 [[Robert Redfield]], head of the CDC, told a Senate hearing that HHS and the White House [[Office of Management and Budget]] had ordered him to transfer $300 million from his agency's budget to HHS, to be spent on a public relations campaign directed by Caputo. He added that CDC had not been consulted about the proposed public relations campaign, which was intended to "bring America back".<ref name = leave/> Caputo stated on Facebook that the program "was demanded of me by the president of the United States, personally."<ref name = leave>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/16/us/politics/michael-caputo-hhs-leave-of-absence.html|title=Health Official to Take Leave of Absence After He Attacked Federal Scientists|last1=Weiland|first1=Noah|last2=LaFraniere|first2=Sharon|date=September 16, 2020|work=The New York Times|accessdate=September 20, 2020}}</ref> The goal was to get at least 20 celebrities to record messages to "restore hope" and "defeat despair" that would be broadcast before the November election. However, weeks before the election the program was reported to be "sputtering," because most of the targeted celebrities refused to participate and because the video firm hired to carry out the project, headed by a business partner of Caputo, had no prior experience with public health campaigns.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/09/29/hhs-ad-blitz-sputters-as-celebrities-back-away-423274|title=HHS ad blitz sputters as celebrities back away|last=Diamond|first=Dan|date=September 29, 2020|work=Politico|accessdate=15 October 2020}}</ref> HHS Secretary [[Alex Azar]] told Congress that he had begun a review of the program to ensure that it would serve a public health purpose.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/10/06/house-democrats-block-funds-covid-ad-campaign-426876|title=House Democrats seek to block funds for 'defeat despair' Covid ads|last=Diamond|first=Dan|date=October 6, 2020|work=Politico|accessdate=17 October 2020}}</ref>

In emails to Redfield, Alexander and Caputo repeatedly accused CDC scientists of attempting to "hurt the president" and writing "hit pieces on the administration". CDC employees described the period as a five-month-long campaign of bullying and intimidation.<ref name = Weiland>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/18/us/politics/trump-cdc-coronavirus.html|title=Emails Detail Effort to Silence C.D.C. and Question Its Science|last=Weiland|first=Noah|date=September 18, 2020|work=The New York Times|accessdate=September 20, 2020}}</ref> On June 30 Alexander strongly criticized an interview by [[Anne Schuchat]], principal deputy director of the CDC, in which she described the extent of the pandemic and urged Americans to wear masks. Alexander accused her of lying and attempting to embarrass the president, and may have tried to get her fired.<ref name = Weiland/> In another incident, Caputo repeatedly demanded to know who in the CDC press office had approved a series of interviews between a CDC epidemiologist and [[NPR]], saying that he needed to manage department communications and "If you disobey my directions, you will be held accountable". He similarly threatened a CDC press official who had told CNN about an upcoming vaccine public relations campaign.<ref name = Weiland/> On June 20, 2020, Alexander sent a message to CDC Director [[Robert R. Redfield]], criticizing a CDC report about risks to pregnant women from  [[Coronavirus disease 2019|COVID-19]]. Alexander said that the report, whose limitations the CDC had acknowledged, would "frighten women" and give the impression that "the President and his administration can't fix this and it is getting worse". He said that in his "opinion and sense" the CDC was "undermining the president by what they put out".<ref name=postjuly>{{Cite news| last1 = Sun| first1 = Lena H.| last2 = Dawsey| first2 = Josh| title = CDC feels pressure from Trump as rift grows over coronavirus response| url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/trump-sidelines-public-health-advisers-in-growing-rift-over-coronavirus-response/2020/07/09/ad803218-c12a-11ea-9fdd-b7ac6b051dc8_story.html | work = The Washington Post| location = Washington, D.C.| date = July 9, 2020}}</ref>

After the political influence over the CDC was reported, Caputo took a 60-day medical leave of absence and Alexander was fired.<ref name=TakingLeave>{{Cite news|title=Top Trump health appointee taking medical leave after incendiary remarks|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2020/09/16/caputo-departure-hhs/|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=September 16, 2020|authors=Yasmeen Abutaleb, Josh Dawsey & Lena H. Sun}}</ref> In an interview with the ''[[The Globe and Mail|Toronto Globe and Mail]]'' after his departure from HHS, Alexander defended his actions, stating that he had wanted the CDC to make their reports "more upbeat so that people would feel more confident going out and spending money", and that he "did not think agencies should contradict any president's policy".<ref name=Globe>{{Cite news| last = Morrow| first = Adrian| title = McMaster professor embroiled in White House controversy over reports he attempted to muzzle scientists| work = [[The Globe and Mail]]| location = Toronto| url = https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/us-politics/article-mcmaster-university-professor-embroiled-in-white-house-controversy-for/ | date = September 17, 2020}}</ref>

At a [[2020 Trump Tulsa rally|campaign rally in Tulsa, Oklahoma]] on June 20, 2020, Trump claimed he had instructed his administration to slow down coronavirus testing in order to keep the number of confirmed cases down.<ref>{{cite web |last=Forgey |first=Quint |title='I don't kid': Trump says he wasn't joking about slowing coronavirus testing |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/06/23/trump-joking-slowing-coronavirus-testing-335459 |access-date=June 23, 2020 |website=Politico |language=en |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200629014925/https://www.politico.com/news/2020/06/23/trump-joking-slowing-coronavirus-testing-335459 |archive-date=June 29, 2020}}</ref>

On August 24, 2020 the testing guidelines on the CDC web page were quietly changed from their earlier recommendation that testing is recommended for anyone who has come into contact with someone who has COVID-19; the new message said that such people do not need to be tested if they do not have symptoms. Multiple public health experts expressed alarm at the new guideline, because people can be contagious even if they have no symptoms, and early testing of exposed people is considered essential to track and suppress the spread of the virus.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.statnews.com/2020/08/26/new-covid19-testing-guidelines-crafted-at-white-house-alarm-public-health-experts/|title=New Covid-19 testing guidelines, crafted at the White House, alarm public health experts|last1=Branswell|first1=Helen|last2=Sheridan|first2=Kate|date=August 26, 2020|work=[[Stat (website)|Stat News]]|accessdate=September 18, 2020}}</ref> On September 17 it was reported that the new guidelines had been written by the White House coronavirus task force, and been "dropped into" the CDC website by officials in the [[Department of Health and Human Services]] (HHS) without the knowledge of, or over the objections of, CDC scientists.<ref name =Mandavilli/> A July document on "The importance of reopening schools" was also placed on the CDC website by HHS rather than CDC scientists.<ref name =Mandavilli>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/17/health/coronavirus-testing-cdc.html|title=C.D.C. Testing Guidance Was Published Against Scientists' Objections|last=Mandavilli|first=Apoorva|date=September 17, 2020|work=The New York Times|accessdate=September 18, 2020}}</ref> Two former directors of the CDC said that the notion of political appointees or non-scientists posting information to the CDC website is "absolutely chilling" and undermines the credibility of the institution.<ref name =Mandavilli/> On September 18, the day after the manipulation of the CDC by political appointees was reported, the testing guideline was revised to its original recommendation, stressing that anyone who has been in contact with an infected person should be tested.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/09/18/health/covid-19-testing-guidance-cdc-hhs/index.html|title=Controversial coronavirus testing guidance came from HHS and didn't go through CDC scientific review, sources say|date=September 18, 2020|publisher=CNN|accessdate=September 18, 2020}}</ref>

In early March, President Trump directed the [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) to test certain medications to discover if they had the potential to treat COVID-19 patients.<ref name="WSJ-drugs">{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/trump-expected-to-detail-new-virus-therapies-but-expansion-could-be-controversial-11584629965 |title=U.S. Moves to Expand Array of Drug Therapies Deployed Against Coronavirus |newspaper=The Wall Street Journal |date=March 19, 2020 }}</ref> Among these were [[chloroquine]] and [[hydroxychloroquine]], which have been successfully used to treat [[malaria]] for over fifty years. On March 28, the FDA issued an [[Emergency Use Authorization]] (EUA) which allowed certain hospitalized COVID-19 patients to be treated with hydroxychloroquine or chloroquine.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/coronavirus-covid-19-update-daily-roundup-march-30-2020 |title= Coronavirus (COVID-19) Update: Daily Roundup March 30, 2020 |date=March 30, 2020 |accessdate=September 2, 2020 |publisher=FDA}}</ref><ref name="WSJ-drugs" /><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.pharmacytimes.com/news/fda-announces-two-drugs-approved-for-compassionate-use-in-treating-covid-19|title=FDA Announces Two Drugs Given 'Compassionate Use' Status in Treating COVID-19|last=Koppock|first=Kristen|date=March 13, 2020|work=Pharmacy Times|accessdate=April 25, 2020}}</ref><ref name="JustinWise">{{cite news |last1=Wise |first1=Justin |title=FDA issues emergency-use authorization for anti-malaria drugs amid coronavirus outbreak |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/490110-fda-issues-emergency-use-authorization-for-anti-malaria-drugs-amid |accessdate=March 30, 2020 |newspaper=The Hill |date=March 30, 2020}}</ref> On June 15, the FDA revoked the EUA for hydroxychloroquine and chloroquine as potential treatments for COVID-19. The FDA said the available evidence showed "no benefit for decreasing the likelihood of death or speeding recovery". On July 1, the FDA published a review of safety issues associated with the drugs, including fatal cardiac arrhythmias among other side effects.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://www.fda.gov/drugs/drug-safety-and-availability/fda-cautions-against-use-hydroxychloroquine-or-chloroquine-covid-19-outside-hospital-setting-or|title=FDA cautions against use of hydroxychloroquine or chloroquine for COVID-19 outside of the hospital setting or a clinical trial due to risk of heart rhythm problems|first=Center for Drug Evaluation and|last=Research|date=June 26, 2020|journal=FDA|via=fda.gov}}</ref> As of late July Trump was continuing to promote the use of hydroxychloroquine for COVID-19, despite the position of the NIH that the drug was "very unlikely to be beneficial to hospitalized patients with COVID-19".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/trump-doubles-defense-hydroxychloroquine-treat-covid-19-efficacy/story?id=72039824 |title=Trump doubles down on defense of hydroxychloroquine to treat COVID-19 despite efficacy concerns |date=July 28, 2020 |accessdate=September 2, 2020 |publisher=ABC |author1=Ben Gittleson |author2=Jordyn Phelps |author3=Libby Cathey}}</ref>

In August Trump pushed to get speedy approval of [[convalescent plasma]] as a COVID-19 treatment, because he wanted to be able to announce it as a treatment breakthrough at the August [[2020 Republican National Convention]]. A week before the convention he claimed in a tweet that people within the FDA were deliberately delaying approval of treatments and vaccines in order to hurt his chances of re-election; he tagged FDA Commissioner [[Stephen Hahn (oncologist)|Stephen Hahn]] in the tweet.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2020/08/22/trump-without-evidence-accuses-deep-state-fda-slow-walking-coronavirus-vaccines-treatments/|title=Trump without evidence accuses 'deep state' at FDA of slow-walking coronavirus vaccines and treatments|date=August 22, 2020|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=September 13, 2020}}</ref> The [[National Institutes of Health]] (NIH) had concerns about the effectiveness of the treatment. On the Wednesday before the convention Trump phoned [[Francis S. Collins]], head of the NIH, and ordered him to "get it done by Friday."<ref name = pressed/> On the eve of the convention the NIH still had concerns, but Trump announced that the FDA had given emergency authorization for plasma therapy to be more widely used.<ref name = pressed/> In his announcement he greatly exaggerated the effectiveness of the treatment, calling it a major breakthrough and suggesting it might save the lives of 35% of coronavirus patients.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.factcheck.org/2020/08/trump-hahn-mischaracterize-data-on-covid-19-convalescent-plasma/|title=Trump, Hahn Mischaracterize Data on COVID-19 Convalescent Plasma By Jessica McDonald|last=McDonald|first=Jessica|date=August 26, 2020|work=Factcheck.org|accessdate=September 13, 2020}}</ref> The FDA approval had been much more limited in its scope and application, but Hahn initially echoed the president's claims, for which he apologized the next day.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://perma.cc/QW8P-YKEJ|title=Inside Trump's pressure campaign on federal scientists over a covid-19 treatment|date=August 30, 2020|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=September 20, 2020}}</ref>

In September the CDC drafted an order that would require passengers and employees to wear masks on all forms of public and commercial transportation in the United States, including airplanes, trains, buses, subways, and transit hubs. Transportation unions had requested a federal mandate for mask wearing, citing the difficulty of working under a patchwork of rules. HHS Secretary Azar and CDC Director Redfield strongly supported the order.<ref name="masks">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/09/health/coronavirus-covid-masks-cdc.html|title=White House Blocked C.D.C. From Requiring Masks on Public Transportation|last=Kaplan|first=Sheila|date=October 9, 2020|work=The New York Times|accessdate=9 October 2020}}</ref> However, the White House's coronavirus task force, which is supposed to sign off on all coronavirus actions, rejected the order, saying that such orders should be left up to states and local governments.<ref name="masks" />

title: Elon Musk
deleted: [[Tosca Musk]], Elon's sister, is a filmmaker. She is the founder of Musk Entertainment and has produced various movies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.muskentertainment.com/toscamusk.html|title=Tosca Musk profile at|publisher=Musk entertainment}}</ref>{{secondary source needed|date=May 2020}}

title: Elon Musk
added: On September 6, 2018, Musk appeared on ''[[The Joe Rogan Experience]]'' podcast and discussed various topics for over two hours. Within five days, the appearance had accrued 10 million YouTube views.<ref>{{Citation|last=PowerfulJRE|title=Joe Rogan Experience #1169 – Elon Musk|date=September 7, 2018|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ycPr5-27vSI|access-date=September 12, 2018}}</ref> One of the highest profile and controversial aspects of the program was Musk's sampling a single puff from a cigar consisting, Rogan claimed, of tobacco laced with cannabis. To Rogan's inquiry on how often he smoked cannabis, Musk replied: "Almost never. I know a lot of people like weed and that's fine, but I don't find that is very good for productivity ... not for me." ''[[The Washington Post]]'' observed, "In the media's hands, it became a story about Musk's growing instability..."<ref>{{Cite web|last=Ohlheiser|first=Abby|date=September 7, 2018|title=Analysis – YouTubers might be just the renewable resource that Elon Musk needs|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-intersect/wp/2018/09/07/youtubers-might-be-just-the-renewable-resource-that-elon-musk-needs/|access-date=September 12, 2018|website=Washington Post}}</ref>

Tesla stock dropped after the incident, which coincided with the confirmation of the departure of Tesla's Vice President of Worldwide Finance Justin McAnear earlier that day.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Tesla exodus: Another executive exits as Elon Musk struggles to build mainstream automaker|work=USA TODAY|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2018/09/12/yet-another-finance-executive-leaving-tesla/1284197002/|access-date=September 16, 2018}}</ref> ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'' wondered if the cannabis use could have ramifications for SpaceX contracts with the [[United States Air Force]], though a USAF spokesperson told ''[[The Verge]]'' that there was no investigation being carried out and that the Air Force is still processing the situation.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Elon Musk's Pot-Smoking Podcast Appearance Could Open an Air Force Investigation into SpaceX|work=Fortune|url=http://fortune.com/2018/09/10/musk-weed-marijuana-air-force-spacex/|access-date=September 12, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=The Air Force is determining 'the appropriate process' for Elon Musk smoking pot|work=The Verge|url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/9/7/17833208/elon-musk-air-force-pot-smoking-investigation|access-date=September 16, 2018}}</ref> In an interview on ''60 Minutes'', Musk said of the cannabis-smoking incident: "I do not smoke pot. As anybody who watched that podcast could tell, I have no idea how to smoke pot."<ref>{{Cite web|last=Donaghey|first=River|date=December 7, 2018|title=Elon Musk Has 'No Idea' How to Smoke Weed, Says Elon Musk|url=https://www.vice.com/en_ca/article/xwj5pa/elon-musk-weed-i-have-no-idea-how-to-smoke-pot-vgtrn|access-date=March 21, 2019|website=Vice}}</ref>

title: Elon Musk
deleted: In 2015, Musk's statements were subject to further scrutiny when an ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' article claimed that [[SpaceX]], Tesla, [[SolarCity]] and buyers of their products had or were projected to receive together an estimated {{US$|4.9 billion}} in government subsidies over twenty years. One example given is New York state, which is spending $750 million to build a solar panel factory in Buffalo which will be leased to SolarCity for $1 a year. The deal also includes no property taxes for a decade, an estimated $260 million valuation. Tesla's former vice president of business development and former U.S. State Department official, Diarmuid O’Connell, was the automaker's lead negotiator.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-hy-musk-subsidies-20150531-story.html#page=1|title=Elon Musk's growing empire is fuelled by  billion in government subsidies|last=Hirsch|first=Jerry|date=May 30, 2015|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=June 2, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200826065353/https://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-hy-musk-subsidies-20150531-story.html|archive-date=August 26, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/09/13/teslas-vice-president-of-business-development-leaves.html|title=Tesla’s vice president of business development leaves|last=Ferris|first=Harris|date=September 13, 2017|website=cnbc.com|accessdate=May 18, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200823163400/https://www.cnbc.com/2017/09/13/teslas-vice-president-of-business-development-leaves.html|archive-date=August 23, 2020}}</ref>

title: Elon Musk
deleted: Elon Musk teased a Tesla-branded tequila in 2018 as part of an April Fool’s joke on Instagram. The proposed Tesla-branded [[tequila]] appeared to become closer to reality in October 2018 as Tesla filed an "intent to use" trademark application with the [[United States Patent and Trademark Office|U.S. Patent and Trademark Office]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/10/12/elon-musks-tesla-seeks-to-trademark-teslaquila.html?__source=twitter%7Cinternational|title=Elon Musk's Tesla files for a trademark of 'Teslaquila'|last=Whitten|first=Sarah|date=October 12, 2018|work=CNBC|access-date=November 29, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200817230832/https://www.cnbc.com/2018/10/12/elon-musks-tesla-seeks-to-trademark-teslaquila.html?__source=twitter%7Cinternational|archive-date=August 17, 2020}}</ref> The trademark is for distilled agave liquor. Musk reaffirmed his intention to release the product with a tweet, featuring a mockup of the bottle, on October 12, 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/1050792830732394496|title=Elon Musk on Twitter|work=Twitter|access-date=November 29, 2018}}</ref>

Mexico's Tequila Regulatory Council (CRT) publicly replied, "If it wants to make Teslaquila viable as a tequila it would have to associate itself with an authorized tequila producer, comply with certain standards and request authorization from Mexico's Industrial Property Institute."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/elon-musk-s-teslaquila-drink-faces-clash-with-mexican-tequila-industry/4657757.html|title=Elon Musk's 'Teslaquila' Faces Clash With Mexican Tequila Industry|agency=Reuters|work=VOA|access-date=November 29, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181130030332/https://www.voanews.com/a/elon-musk-s-teslaquila-drink-faces-clash-with-mexican-tequila-industry/4657757.html|archive-date=November 30, 2018}}</ref>

title: Elon Musk
deleted:
When asked whether he believed "there was some kind of [[destiny]] involved" in humanity's transition to a multi-planetary species, rather than "just physics", Musk responded:
Well, I do. Do I think that there's some sort of master intelligence architecting all of this stuff? I think probably not because then you have to say: "Where does the master intelligence come from?" So it sort of begs the question. So I think really you can explain this with the fundamental laws of physics. You know it's complex phenomenon from simple elements.{{cite web|date=June 2008|title=Going to Mars with Elon Musk|url=http://www.oninnovation.com/videos/detail.aspx?video=1549&title=Going+to+Mars|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160108144324/http://www.oninnovation.com/videos/detail.aspx?video=1549&title=Going+to+Mars|archive-date=January 8, 2016|accessdate=June 10, 2015|website=OnInnovation.com}}[https://www.thehenryford.org/explore/stories-of-innovation/visionaries/elon-musk/#gallery-video=JkNm43MToXXZ5r2zNap-Ixa5FkAkaILW Going To Mars] (alt link retrieved February 2, 2018){{dead link|date=May 2020}}{{better source|date=May 2020}}
Musk has stated that he does not pray, or worship any being, although he asked "any entities that were listening" to "bless the launch" before an important [[Falcon 1]] launch.{{Cite web|date=June 30, 2019|title=What Do Elon Musk, Frodo Baggins, & Luke Skywalker Share In Common?|url=https://cleantechnica.com/2019/06/29/what-do-elon-musk-frodo-baggins-luke-skywalker-share-in-common/|access-date=July 31, 2020|website=CleanTechnica|language=en-US}} When asked whether he thought science and religion could [[Relationship between religion and science|co-exist]], Musk replied "Probably not."{{cite web|last=Premier|date=February 17, 2017|title=Elon Musk: what the tech genius is teaching the church|url=https://www.premierchristianity.com/Past-Issues/2017/March-2017/Elon-Musk-what-the-tech-genius-is-teaching-the-church|access-date=July 31, 2020|website=Premier Christianity|language=en-GB}}

title: 2020 United States presidential election in Iowa
2020 United States presidential election in Iowa
2020 United States presidential election in Iowa
added: In 2016, [[Donald Trump]] won Iowa, a state that [[Barack Obama]] won twice, by almost 10 points, the widest Republican margin for the Hawkeye State since [[Ronald Reagan|Reagan]]'s 1980 landslide. Counties that haven't favored a Republican since Reagan's or [[Richard Nixon|Nixon]]'s landslide victories flipped comfortably red. Trump is still favored by some to win Iowa again in 2020, but by a much more narrow margin. One profound finding by the Des Moines Register poll is the 41-point gender divide in this contest with men favoring Trump by twenty-one points and women favoring Biden by twenty points.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Pfannenstiel|first=Brianne|title=Iowa Poll: Donald Trump and Joe Biden are locked in a dead heat six weeks to Election Day|url=https://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/news/politics/iowa-poll/2020/09/22/iowa-poll-donald-trump-joe-biden-tied-iowa-presidential-race-2020/5839311002/|access-date=2020-10-08|website=Des Moines Register|language=en-US}}</ref>

title: Vladimir Putin
added: A program was introduced with the aim of increasing [[Russia in the European energy sector|Russia's share of the European energy market]] by building submerged gas pipelines bypassing [[Ukraine]] and other countries which were often seen as non-reliable transit partners by Russia, especially following the [[Russia-Ukraine gas disputes]] of the late 2000s. Russia also undermined the rival [[Nabucco pipeline]] project by buying gas from Turkmenistan and redirecting it into Russian pipelines.{{citation needed|date=October 2018}}

Russia diversified its export markets by building the [[Trans-Siberian oil pipeline]] to support oil exports to China, Japan and [[Korea]], as well as the [[Sakhalin–Khabarovsk–Vladivostok gas pipeline]] in the [[Russian Far East]]. Russia has also recently built several major oil and gas refineries, plants and ports. Major hydropower plants such as the [[Bureya Dam]] and the [[Boguchany Dam]] have been constructed, as well as the restoration of the [[nuclear power in Russia|nuclear industry of Russia]], with 1 trillion rubles ($42.7 billion) which were allocated from the federal budget to nuclear power and industry development before 2015.<ref>[http://amur.kp.ru/daily/24458/620649/ Russia builds nuclear power stations all over the world] at amur.kp.ru</ref>

title: Vladimir Putin
deleted: Control over the economy was increased by placing individuals from the intelligence services and the military in key positions of the Russian economy, including on boards of large companies.{{Citation needed|date=October 2020}} In 2005, an industry consolidation programme was launched to bring the main aircraft producing companies under a single umbrella organization, the [[United Aircraft Corporation]] (UAC). The aim was to optimize production lines and minimise losses.<ref name=ato1>{{cite journal|url=http://www.ato.ru/content/state-sponsored-consolidation|title=State-sponsored consolidation|last1=Zvereva|first1=Polina|journal=Russia & CIS Observer|issue=26|volume=3|date=11 October 2009}}</ref> The UAC is one of Russia's "[[national champions]]" and comparable to [[EADS]] in Europe.<ref name=UAC2009>{{cite web|url=http://www.uacrussia.ru/common/img/uploaded/disclosure/Annual_Report_2009e.pdf|title=ANNUAL REPORT of Joint Stock Company United Aircraft Corporation for 2009|publisher=United Aircraft Corporation|location=Moscow|year=2010|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801193817/http://www.uacrussia.ru/common/img/uploaded/disclosure/Annual_Report_2009e.pdf|archivedate=1 August 2013}}</ref>

title: Vladimir Putin
deleted: In some cases, such as the [[Russia–Ukraine gas disputes]], the economic conflicts affected other European countries, for example when a [[2009 Russia–Ukraine gas dispute|January 2009 gas dispute with Ukraine]] led [[state owned|state-controlled]] Russian company [[Gazprom]] to halt its deliveries of natural gas to Ukraine,<ref name=naturalgas>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7240462.stm Q&A: Russia-Ukraine gas row], ''[[BBC News]]'' (20 January 2009).</ref> which left a number of European states, to which Ukraine transits Russian gas, with serious shortages of natural gas in January 2009.<ref name=naturalgas/>

Putin allegedly declared at a NATO-Russia summit in 2008 that if Ukraine joined NATO Russia could contend to annex the [[Eastern Ukraine|Ukrainian East]] and [[Crimea]].<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/91772/ "After Russian Invasion of Georgia, Putin's Words Stir Fears about Ukraine"], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (30 November 2010).</ref> At the summit, he told US President [[George W. Bush]] that "Ukraine is not even a state!" while the following year Putin referred to Ukraine as "[[Little Russia]]".<ref>Bohm, M. ''[https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2013/12/24/ukraine-is-putins-favorite-vassal-a30782 Ukraine Is Putin's Favorite Vassal]''. ''[[The Moscow Times]]''. 25 December 2013</ref> Following the [[2014 Ukrainian revolution]] in March 2014, [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|the Russian Federation annexed Crimea]].<ref name="walker-the-guardian-2014-descend">{{cite news|last=Walker|first=Shaun|date=4 March 2014|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/mar/04/ukraine-crisis-russian-troops-crimea-john-kerry-kiev|title=Russian takeover of Crimea will not descend into war, says Vladimir Putin|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|location=London|accessdate=4 March 2014}}</ref><ref name="bloomberg-news-2014-request">{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-03-04/russia-calls-ukraine-intervention-legal-citing-yanukovych-letter.html|title=Russia Stays in Ukraine as Putin Channels Yanukovych Request|first1=Sangwon|last1=Yoon|first2=Daryna|last2=Krasnolutska|first3=Kateryna|last3=Choursina|date=4 March 2014|accessdate=5 March 2014|work=[[Bloomberg News]]}}</ref><ref name=Radyuhin>{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/world/russian-parliament-approves-use-of-force-in-crimea/article5739708.ece |title=Russian Parliament approves use of army in Ukraine|work=The Hindu|date=1 March 2014|first=Vladimir|last=Radyuhin|location=Chennai, India}}</ref> According to Putin, this was done because "[[Crimea]] has always been and remains an inseparable part of Russia".<ref>{{cite news|title=Vladimir Putin signs treaty for Russia to take Crimea from Ukraine – video|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/video/2014/mar/18/vladimir-putin-annex-crimea-russia-ukraine-video|accessdate=28 December 2014|work=The Guardian|date=18 March 2014}}</ref> After the Russian annexion of Crimea, he said that Ukraine includes "regions of Russia's historic south" and "was created on a whim by the [[Bolsheviks]]".<ref name="cbsnews.com">{{cite news| url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/russia-president-vladimir-putin-approves-draft-bill-to-annex-crimea-after-residents-vote-to-leave-ukraine/ | publisher=CBS News | title=Russia President Vladimir Putin signs treaty to annex Crimea after residents vote to leave Ukraine | date=18 March 2014}}</ref> He went on to declare that the [[2014 Ukrainian revolution|February 2014 ousting]] of [[Ukrainian President]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]] had been orchestrated by the West as an attempt to weaken Russia. "Our Western partners have crossed a line. They behaved rudely, irresponsibly and unprofessionally," he said, adding that the people who had come to power in Ukraine were "nationalists, [[neo-Nazis]], [[Russophobes]] and [[anti-Semites]]".<ref name="cbsnews.com"/> In a July 2014 speech midst [[2014 insurgency in Donbass|an armed insurgency in]] [[Eastern Ukraine]], Putin stated he would use Russia's "entire arsenal" and "the right of self defence" to protect [[Russian speakers]] outside Russia.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/vladimir-putin/10951644/Has-Vladimir-Putin-blinked-over-Ukraine.html |title=Has Vladimir Putin blinked over Ukraine? |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=7 July 2014 |accessdate=22 March 2018}}</ref> With the split of the Ukrainian orthodox church from the Russian one in 2018, a number of experts came to the conclusion that Putin's policy of forceful engagement in post-Soviet republics significantly backfired on him, leading to a situation where he "annexed Crimea, but lost Ukraine", and provoked a much more cautious approach to Russia among other post-Soviet countries.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://euobserver.com/foreign/143094|title=Putin has lost Ukraine, US diplomat says|access-date=13 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2018-10-13/putin-is-loser-as-ukraine-s-orthodox-church-seeks-independence|title=Putin Is the Biggest Loser of Orthodox Schism|last=Bershidsky|first=Leonid|website=Bloomberg}}</ref>

title: 2016 United States presidential debates
added: Questioner Ken Bone, a power plant operator from Illinois, had a media presence and became an [[Internet meme]] in the days following the debate. His rise to popularity was due to his name, his red sweater, and his use of a [[disposable camera]] prior to and after the debate. Bone appeared on ESPN ''[[College GameDay (football)|College GameDay]]'' and ''[[@midnight]]''. He was portrayed by [[Bobby Moynihan]] during the [[cold open#Saturday Night Live|cold open]] of [[NBC]] sketch comedy show ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s October 15 episode, dancing to the song "[[Get Ready for This]]".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Vulpo|first1=Mike|title=SNL's Presidential Debate Isn't Complete Without Ken Bone|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/802245/saturday-night-live-s-presidential-debate-with-hillary-clinton-and-donald-trump-isn-t-complete-without-ken-bone|website=[[E! Online]]|publisher=E!|accessdate=October 17, 2016|date=October 15, 2016}}</ref> Bone received a short-term endorsement deal with American transportation network company [[Uber]] to promote the launch of Uber Select in [[St. Louis]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Vielma|first1=Antonio|title=Ken Bone lands Uber endorsement and t-shirt deal. |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2016/10/13/ken-bone-lands-uber-endorsement-and-t-shirt-deal.html|website=[[CNBC]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|accessdate=October 16, 2016|date=October 13, 2016}}</ref> A backlash against Bone happened after controversial posts under his username on [[Reddit]] were revealed.{{clarify|why were they controversial? what did they say?|date=July 2020}}<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sloane|first1=Garett|title=EBay Should Have Done 'Extreme Vetting' of Ken Bone|url=http://adage.com/article/digital/ken-bone-brings-brands-failed-extreme-vet/306302/ |website=[[Advertising Age]]|publisher=[[Crain Communications Inc.]]|accessdate=October 17, 2016|date=October 14, 2016}}</ref>

title: Roger MacBride
added: MacBride married Susan Ford. They then adopted a baby whom they named Abigail MacBride.<ref>[http://www.liwfrontiergirl.com/roger.html Laura Ingles Wilder database on MacBride]</ref>

McBride was designated by [[Rose Wilder Lane]] as her heir. He gained control of her literary estate on her death in 1968. In 1971 he had [[The First Four Years]] published. In 1974 he edited and published Laura Ingles Wilder's letters to her husband Almonzo as ''West From Home''. He was later the produced for the Little House on the Prarie TV series. He was the credited author of a fictionalized series on the life of Rose Wilder Lane.<ref>[http://www.liwfrontiergirl.com/roger.html Laura Ingles Wilder database entry on MacBride]</ref>

* Helped pass the Never Again Education Act, which helps provide resources to teachers in American so they can teach children about the horrors of the Holocaust<ref>{{Cite web|title=Congressman Suozzi Helps Pass Bipartisan Legislation of the Never Again Education Act on the 75th Anniversary of the Liberation of Auschwitz|url=https://suozzi.house.gov/media/press-releases/congressman-suozzi-helps-pass-bipartisan-legislation-never-again-education-act|date=2020-01-28|website=Congressman Thomas Suozzi|language=en|access-date=2020-04-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Never Again Education Act Gets Go-Ahead From House|url=https://longislandweekly.com/never-again-education-act-gets-go-ahead-from-house/|date=2020-02-07|website=Long Island Weekly|language=en-US|access-date=2020-04-30}}</ref>;

* Led the passage of the SHIELDS Act, which, now a law, sanctions members of Hezbollah and their foreign backers for their use of human shields and civilian infrastructure to hide hundreds of thousands of rockets aimed at Israel<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.aipac.org/resources/aipac-publications/publication?pubpath=PolicyPolitics/Press/AIPAC%20Statements/2018/12/Congress%20Targets%20Hamas%20Hezbollah%20for%20Use%20of%20Human%20Shields|title=ongress Targets Hamas, Hezbollah for Use of Human Shields|website=www.aipac.org|access-date=2020-04-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=US House passes bipartisan bill to prevent use of human shields|url=https://www.jns.org/house-of-representatives-passes-bipartisan-bill-to-prevent-use-of-human-shields-goes-to-trump-for-signature/|last=Richman|first=Jackson|date=2018-12-11|website=JNS.org|language=en-US|access-date=2020-04-30}}</ref>;

* Led passage of an amendment in 2018 which detailed Hezbollah’s nefarious activities in Lebanon, Russia’s cooperation with Iran in Syria, preventing Iran from establishing a foothold on Israel's border.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Bipartisan Bill Sanctioning Hamas, Hezbollah for Using Human Shields Passes Congress|url=http://www.thetower.org/6939-bipartisan-bill-sanctioning-hamas-hezbollah-for-using-human-shields-passes-congress/|date=2018-12-12|website=The Tower|language=en-US|access-date=2020-04-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=US House passes bipartisan bill to prevent use of human shields, now off to Trump|url=https://www.clevelandjewishnews.com/jns/us-house-passes-bipartisan-bill-to-prevent-use-of-human-shields-now-off-to-trump/article_c90e2b4f-f389-5b58-b108-3e11a23a1649.html|last=Richman|first=Jackson|website=Cleveland Jewish News|language=en|access-date=2020-04-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=House set to OK Iran sanctions, block Hezbollah funds|url=https://www.news-journalonline.com/news/20171025/house-set-to-ok-iran-sanctions-block-hezbollah-funds|last=Press|first=Richard Lardner, The Associated|website=Daytona Beach News-Journal Online|language=en|access-date=2020-04-30}}</ref>

title: Ralph Northam
added: In April 2020, Northam signed a bill that expanded the conditions under which fines and court costs can be paid for with community service credits; Virginia law had previously allowed these credits to be earned only before or after incarceration. The reform enacted by Northam in 2020 allows these credits to be earned during incarceration as well.<ref name="takes action"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wusa9.com/article/features/producers-picks/northam-marijuana-virginia-legislation/65-50960d97-9278-4d58-a8cc-db342a5c0359|author=Kyley Schultz|title=Simple possession of marijuana decriminalized in Virginia, prior conviction records now sealed|work=[[WUSA (TV)|WUSA]]|date=April 16, 2020|accessdate=October 29, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jurist.org/news/2020/04/virginias-governor-signs-multiple-progressive-bills-in-to-law/|author=Matthew Fischer|title=Virginia governor signs criminal justice reform bills into law|work=[[JURIST]]|date=April 14, 2020|accessdate=October 29, 2020}}</ref>

title: 2020 Tulsa Trump rally
added: The total attendance of the rally would be lower than was expected by the Trump campaign; roughly a week prior, Trump claimed that "almost one million" people had requested tickets.<ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=President Trump tweets that almost 1 million people have requested tickets to Saturday's Tulsa rally|url=https://www.tulsaworld.com/news/local/president-trump-tweets-that-almost-1-million-people-have-requested-tickets-to-saturdays-tulsa-rally/article_e54557f1-0b9e-5119-a46b-7424139c2dac.html|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=June 22, 2020|website=Tulsa World|language=en}}</ref> An outdoor overflow stage (which was also scheduled to have in-person appearances by Trump and Pence following the in-arena address) was scrapped just hours before the rally,<ref name=":8">{{Cite news|last=Lutz|first=Tom|date=June 21, 2020|title=Brad Parscale faces Trump 'fury' after Tulsa comeback rally flops|language=en-GB|work=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/jun/21/brad-parscale-donald-trump-tulsa-rally-covid-ivanka-kushner-rick-wilson|access-date=June 22, 2020|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> while Tulsa's fire department and Trump's campaign each reported crowd estimates of 6,200 and 12,000, respectively — less than the arena's capacity of around 19,000.<ref>{{Cite web|title=TikTok Prank May Account For Trump Rally's Low Attendance Rate|url=https://www.npr.org/2020/06/22/881559701/tiktok-prank-may-account-for-trump-rallys-low-attendance-rate|access-date=June 22, 2020|website=NPR.org|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":9">{{Cite web|last=Choi|first=Matthew|title=Trump supporters were scared off from rally, adviser says|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/06/21/trump-adviser-tulsa-rally-attendance-331556|access-date=June 22, 2020|website=Politico|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":8"/> It was reported that [[TikTok]] users and members of [[K-pop|K-pop fandoms]] had credited themselves with falsely requesting tickets for the rally, as part of a coordinated effort to "[[Internet troll|troll]]" Trump;<ref name="NYT-20JUN21-TikTokKPop">{{cite news |last1=Lorenz |first1=Taylor |last2=Browning |first2=Kellen |last3=Frenkel |first3=Sheera |title=TikTok Teens and K-Pop Stans Say They Sank Trump Rally |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/21/style/tiktok-trump-rally-tulsa.html |accessdate=July 1, 2020 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 21, 2020 |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=After Trump rally falls flat, TikTok teens take a victory lap for fake reservation campaign|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/after-trump-rally-falls-flat-tiktok-teens-take-victory-lap-n1231675|access-date=June 22, 2020|website=NBC News|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=O'Sullivan|first=Donie|date=|title=Trump trolled by TikTok in Tulsa|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/06/21/politics/tiktok-trump-tulsa-rally/index.html|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=June 22, 2020|website=CNN}}</ref> earlier, Mary Jo Laupp (who had worked for [[Pete Buttigieg]]'s [[Pete Buttigieg 2020 presidential campaign|campaign for Democratic candidacy]] in the [[2020 United States presidential election|2020 presidential election]]) uploaded a video on TikTok which encouraged viewers to request the Trump camp a ticket and not show up.<ref name="NYT-20JUN21-TikTokKPop" />

title: White House COVID-19 outbreak
added: On October 7 Trump insisted on doing some business in the [[Oval Office]], although he is supposed to be quarantined in the residence part of the White House, and rooms have been set up there when he can work. He reportedly entered the Oval Office through an outdoor entrance so as not to encounter staff. Only two aides - Mark Meadows and Dan Scavino - spent time with him there.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/trump-insisting-working-oval-office-quarantine-rules-infection/story?id=73472757|title=Trump returns to Oval Office despite isolation rules, infection risks|last=Phelps|first=Jordyn|date=October 7, 2020|work=ABC News|accessdate=9 October 2020}}</ref>

title: White House COVID-19 outbreak
deleted: The incident has been compared to the [[Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan|non-fatal shooting of Ronald Reagan]] in 1981, which saw similar concerns over [[continuity of government]] amid incapacitation of the president.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Rozdilsky |first=Jack L. |date=October 2, 2020 |title=Trump's hospitalization due to COVID-may 19 cause crisis of instability at the White House |url=https://theconversation.com/trumps-hospitalization-due-to-covid-19-may-cause-crisis-of-instability-at-the-white-house-147408 |website=The Conversation}}</ref>

title: White House COVID-19 outbreak
added: After Trump was hospitalized,  it was revealed that he was not being tested daily,  however the White House was unwilling to reveal the date of his last negative test. <ref>https://apnews.com/article/virus-outbreak-donald-trump-a6c145029afb7a28bd739969387813e8</ref> Prior to hospitalization, Trump had twice claimed to test negative:   in March, Trump physician Sean Conley had announced that the president had tested negative after he was exposed to COVID-positive individuals at his Mar-a-Lago resort.<ref>https://www.politico.eu/article/trump-tested-negative-for-coronavirus-white-house-physician-says/</ref>  After one of Trump's personal valets tested positive in May,  Trump told reporters "I tested very positively in another sense so— this morning. Yeah. I tested positively toward negative, right. So. I tested perfectly this morning. Meaning I tested negative."<ref>https://www.cnn.com/2020/05/07/politics/trump-valet-tests-positive-covid-19/index.html</ref>

title: White House COVID-19 outbreak
added: Also on September 26, Trump traveled to a rally in at the Harrisburg International Airport in Pennsylvania, which was attended by thousands.<ref>https://www.pennlive.com/news/2020/09/big-crowd-endures-drizzle-poor-sound-at-trump-rally-in-dauphin-county.html<ref/>  The governor opposed the rally, arguing "It is gravely concerning that the president would insist on holding this event with blatant disregard for social distancing and masking requirements. His decision to bring thousands of people together in a tight space in the midst of a global pandemic caused by an airborne virus is flat out wrong."<ref>https://www.pennlive.com/news/2020/09/gov-tom-wolf-puts-president-trump-on-blast-for-saturdays-harrisburg-airport-rally.html</ref>  After Trump's diagnosis was made public, Pennsylvania health officials advised  attendees to participate in the state's contact tracing program.<ref>https://www.abc27.com/news/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-pennsylvania/pennsylvania-health-department-asks-trump-rally-attendees-to-use-contact-tracing-app/</ref>   In the wake of the rally, the county saw a surge in COVID-19.<ref name="5spikes" />

title: White House COVID-19 outbreak
added: In mid-October, an unidentified staffer in the vice president's office tested positive, ABC News would later learn.<ref name="abcshort">https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/marty-obst-top-aide-mike-pence-tests-positive/story?id=73811825</ref>  Days later, it was announced that two close advisers to Pence had tested positive:  Marc Short, Chief of Staff to the Vice President, and Pence political aide Marty Obst. <ref name="shortaxios"/>
The White House announced that Pence would not enter quarantine despite having been in "close contact with Mr. Short". <ref name="abcshort"/>

deleted: A few months into his tenure as Postmaster General, the U.S. Postal Service’s watchdog concluded that the quality and timeliness of postal service deliveries had declined.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Palazzolo|first=Rebecca Smith and Joe|date=2020-10-22|title=Mail Service Deteriorated After Postmaster General Louis DeJoy’s Arrival, Watchdog Found|language=en-US|work=Wall Street Journal|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/mail-service-deteriorated-after-postmaster-general-louis-dejoys-arrival-watchdog-found-11603384937|access-date=2020-10-23|issn=0099-9660}}</ref> After DeJoy's reforms were walked back, USPS mail deliveries improved.<ref>{{Cite web|title=USPS Delivering More Mail on Time After Walking Back DeJoy’s Reforms|url=https://www.govexec.com/management/2020/10/usps-delivering-more-mail-time-after-walking-back-dejoys-reforms/169297/|access-date=2020-10-29|website=Government Executive|language=en}}</ref>

title: 2020 Oklahoma Senate election
added: A special election for [[Oklahoma Senate|Oklahoma State Senate District 28]] has been called for November 3, 2020. A primary was scheduled for June 30, 2020. The seat became vacant after [[Jason Smalley]] resigned his seat on January 31, 2020, to take a private-sector job with Motorola Solutions Corporation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ballotpedia.org/Oklahoma_State_Senate_District_28|title=Oklahoma State Senate District 28|website=Ballotpedia|language=en|access-date=2020-06-30}}</ref>

title: The Washington Post
deleted: In November 2016, the ''Post'' published a story that relied heavily on a report by [[PropOrNot]], an anonymous internet group that seeks to expose what it calls [[Russian propaganda]]. PropOrNot published a list of websites they called "bona-fide 'useful idiots{{'"}} of the Russian government.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Nelson|first1=Steven|title=Publications Called Russian-Propaganda Distributors Consider Suing Anonymous 'Experts'|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2016-11-29/publications-called-russian-propaganda-distributors-consider-suing-anonymous-experts|website=U.S. News & World Report|date=November 29, 2016}}</ref> Given PropOrNot's broad criteria for classifying sources as propaganda, the ''Post''{{'}}s decision to run the front-page article was criticized by commentators such as [[Andrew Cockburn]],<ref>{{citation|accessdate=December 11, 2016|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/12/09/washington-post-on-the-fake-news-hot-seat.html|work=[[The Daily Beast]]|title=Washington Post on the 'Fake News' Hot Seat|first=Lloyd|last=Grove|date=December 9, 2016}}</ref> [[Glenn Greenwald]],<ref>{{citation|title=Washington Post Disgracefully Promotes a McCarthyite Blacklist From a New, Hidden, and Very Shady Group|date=November 26, 2016|url=https://theintercept.com/2016/11/26/washington-post-disgracefully-promotes-a-mccarthyite-blacklist-from-a-new-hidden-and-very-shady-group/|author1=Ben Norton|author2=Glenn Greenwald|work=[[The Intercept]]|accessdate=November 27, 2016|author-link2=Glenn Greenwald}}</ref> [[Matt Taibbi]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/features/washington-post-blacklist-story-is-shameful-disgusting-w452543|title=The 'Washington Post' 'Blacklist' Story Is Shameful and Disgusting|last=Taibbi|first=Matt|date=November 28, 2016|website=Rolling Stone}}</ref> and [[Adrian Chen]].<ref name="Chen-Prop-about-Prop">{{cite news|url=http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/the-propaganda-about-russian-propaganda|title=The Propaganda About Russian Propaganda|last=Chen|first=Adrian|date=December 1, 2016|work=The New Yorker}}</ref>

In August 2018, the ''Post''{{'}}s article profiling the [[Jacksonville Landing shooting|Jacksonville Landing shooter]], a [[Esports|competitive gamer]],<ref>{{cite news |last1= Swenson|first1= Kyle|last2=Farzan|first2=Antonia Noori|date= 27 August 2018|title= Jacksonville shooting suspect: A serious player in the high-pressure, big-money world of competitive gaming

|url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2018/08/27/jacksonville-shooting-the-high-pressure-big-money-world-of-competitive-gaming/|work= Washington Post|location= |access-date= 6 March 2020}}</ref> was criticized by [[University of Oregon]] journalism professor Nicole Dahmen, who said, "The article reads like a glorified celebrity profile."<ref name=Biasotti>{{cite news|last=Biasotti|first=Tony|date=31 August 2018|title=Reporters shouldn't profile mass shooters, say experts|url=https://www.cjr.org/united_states_project/jacksonville-shooting-contagion.php|work=Columbia Journalism Review|access-date=6 March 2020}}</ref> The paper responded, saying: "As is true in all cases, reporting on the alleged killer is only one aspect of our coverage. In this instance, the story helps readers better understand the esports community affected and the accused killer's history within that community. These are not easy decisions to make and for each individual story, we must consider what is [[News values|newsworthy]]."<ref name=Biasotti/>

title: 2013 United States Senate special election in New Jersey
Chris Hollins (politician)
added: After graduating from Hightower High School in Missouri City, Chris went on to earn a Bachelor of Arts with Phi Beta Kappa honors from Morehouse College. Chris also completed a joint program with Yale Law School and Harvard Business School, earning both his Juris Doctor and Master of Business Administration degrees.

Christopher Hollins is a fifth generation Texan. Chris developed a commitment to public service through the selfless example of his parents and their devotion for improving the lives of others. His father, George, served for 34 years in the Houston Police Department, and his mother, Christie, managed a career as a secretary while raising Chris, his two sisters, and more than 20 young foster children.  Chris resides in the University Oaks neighborhood of Houston with his wife Morgan and their daughter Vivian.  The Hollins family attends Wheeler Avenue Baptist Church in Houston's Third Ward.
Today, Chris is admitted to the State Bar of Texas and Federal Courts for the Southern District of Texas.

Before transitioning into private practice, Chris attained a strong strategic skillset by working at some of the world’s most distinguished professional service firms. He was a Senior Engagement Manager at global consultancy McKinsey & Company, where he flourished in applying analytics and organizational best practice to transform public safety, defense, and security agencies. Chris was also a Summer Associate with Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz and the investment bank Goldman Sachs. Despite his private sector background, Chris’s most memorable professional experience ensued through his time with the White House Office of Presidential Personnel during the first year of the Obama administration. Chris is a lifelong Democrat and veteran campaign manager,

Chris has served on numerous nonprofit boards and has been a Big Brother for over a decade. He was recently appointed by the Mayor and City Council of Houston to sit on the board of the East Downtown Tax Increment Reinvestment Zone (TIRZ). Chris is also an officer in the University Oaks Civic Association.<!--

title: Donald Trump judicial appointment controversies
added: ====[[United States District Court for the Central District of California]]====

*[[Jeremy B. Rosen]]: On October 10, 2018,  President Trump announced his intent to nominate Rosen to serve as a United States District Judge for the United States District Court for the Central District of California. On November 13, 2018, his nomination was sent to the Senate.  Democrats claimed that Rosen was a conservative ideologue.  [[U.S. Senator]] [[Kamala Harris]] refused to turn in her [[blue slip]] consenting to the nomination.  Rosen's supporters pointed out that he is a well-regarded appellate lawyer and that many Democrats in the California legal community support him, but his nomination has not been acted upon.<ref>{{https://dailyjournal.com/articles/355234-us-judge-nominee-appears-stalled-over-his-affiliation-with-federalist-society}}</ref>

United States presidential elections in Ohio
deleted: No Republican has won a U.S. Presidential election without Ohio since the party's first major nominee in 1856.

title: United States presidential elections in Ohio
added: Ohio is considered a [[swing state]], being won by either the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] or [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] candidates from election to elecion. As a swing state, Ohio is usually targeted by both major-party campaigns, especially in competitive elections.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-odds-of-an-electoral-college-popular-vote-split-are-increasing/|title=The Odds of an Electoral College-Popular Vote Split Are Increasing|date=2016-11-01|website=FiveThirtyEight|language=en-US|access-date=2016-11-06|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161221013034/http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-odds-of-an-electoral-college-popular-vote-split-are-increasing/|archive-date=December 21, 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> Pivotal in the election of [[1888 United States presidential election|1888]], Ohio has been a regular swing state since 1980.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2004/10/02/arts/02camp.html Trolling the Campuses for Swing-State Votes] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150528014334/http://www.nytimes.com/2004/10/02/arts/02camp.html |date=May 28, 2015 }}, Julie Salamon, "[[The New York Times]]", October 2, 2004</ref><ref>[http://www.slate.com/id/2108640/ Game Theory for Swingers] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110201225851/http://www.slate.com/id/2108640/ |date=February 1, 2011 }}, Jordan Ellenberg, "[[Slate.com]]", October 25, 2004</ref>

Additionally, Ohio is considered a [[bellwether]]. Historian [[R. Douglas Hurt]] asserts that not since Virginia "had a state made such a mark on national political affairs".<ref name="holli162">Holli (1999), p. 162.</ref> ''[[The Economist]]'' notes that "This slice of the mid-west contains a bit of everything American—part north-eastern and part southern, part urban and part rural, part hardscrabble poverty and part booming

suburb",<ref>[http://www.economist.com/World/na/displayStory.cfm?story_id=5327576 " A grain of sand for your thoughts"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060226043446/http://www.economist.com/world/na/displaystory.cfm?story_id=5327576 |date=February 26, 2006 }}, ''The Economist'', December 20, 2005. Retrieved December 23, 2005.</ref> Since [[1896 United States presidential election|1896]], Ohio has had only two misses in the general election ([[1944 United States presidential election|Thomas E. Dewey in 1944]] and [[1960 United States presidential election|Richard Nixon in 1960]]) and has the longest perfect streak of any state, voting for the winning presidential candidate in each election since [[1964 United States presidential election|1964]], and in 33 of the 37 held since the [[American Civil War|Civil War]]. No Republican has ever won the presidency without winning Ohio, and only two Democrats have ever won the presidency without winning Ohio (in 1884/1892 and 1960).

title: Rick Gates (political consultant)
deleted: On October 16 2020 at a Florida rally for his reelection then President Trump referred to Matt Gaetz, a congressman and longtime Trump supporter, who was standing next to his podium, as "Rick Gates" several times.  The President did this as he was looking directly at Mr Gaetz.  The incident provoked discussion online as to the then Presidents fitness for office, as it was not the first time the President had confused who he was speaking with in a public setting.  The Presidential confusion extended beyond Mr Gaetz as well, as the President called hypersonic weapons "hydrophonic" and confused Ferguson Missouri with "Henderson".

title: Fake news websites in the United States
added: Marco Chacon created the fake news site ''RealTrueNews'' to show his [[alt-right]] friends their alleged gullibility.<ref name="chacon">{{cite news|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/10/28/the-man-who-duped-trumpkins-fox-news.html|title=This 'Conservative News Site' Trended on Facebook, Showed Up on Fox News—and Duped the World|last=Collins|first=Ben|date=October 28, 2016|accessdate=November 27, 2016|publisher=[[The Daily Beast]]}}</ref><ref name="chacon2">{{cite news|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/11/21/i-ve-been-making-viral-fake-news-for-the-last-six-months-it-s-way-too-easy-to-dupe-the-right-on-the-internet.html|title=I've Been Making Viral Fake News for the Last Six Months. It's Way Too Easy to Dupe the Right on the Internet.|last=Chacon|first=Marco|date=November 21, 2016|accessdate=November 27, 2016|publisher=[[The Daily Beast]]}}</ref> Chacon wrote a fake transcript for Clinton's leaked speeches in which Clinton explains [[bronies]] to [[Goldman Sachs]] bankers.<ref name="chacon" /><ref name="chacon2" /> Chacon was shocked when his fiction was reported as factual by [[Fox News]] and he heard his writings on [[Megyn Kelly]]'s ''[[The Kelly File]]''.<ref name="chacon" /><ref name="chacon2" /> [[Trace Gallagher]] repeated Chacon's fiction and falsely reported Clinton had called [[Bernie Sanders]] supporters a "bucket of losers" — a phrase made up by Chacon.<ref name="chacon" /> After denials from Clinton staff, Megyn Kelly apologized with a public retraction.<ref name="chacon" /><ref name="chacon2" /><ref name="bambury">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/radio/day6/episode-313-montreal-worship-ban-protecting-syrian-schools-jamaican-bobsleds-fake-news-and-more-1.3863764/marco-chacon-meant-his-fake-election-news-to-be-satire-but-people-took-it-as-fact-1.3863769|title=Marco Chacon meant his fake election news to be satire — but people took it as fact|last=Bambury|first=Brent|date=November 25, 2016|work=[[Day 6]]|accessdate=November 27, 2016|publisher=[[CBC Radio One]]|authorlink=Brent Bambury}}</ref>

Chacon later told [[Brent Bambury]] of [[CBC Radio One]] program ''[[Day 6]]'' that he was so shocked at readers' ignorance he felt it was like an episode from ''[[The Twilight Zone]]''.<ref name="bambury" /> In an interview with [[ABC News]], Chacon defended his site, saying it was an over-the-top parody of fake sites to teach his friends how ridiculous they were.<ref name="jujuchang">{{cite news|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Technology/fake-news-stories-make-real-news-headlines/story?id=43845383|title=When Fake News Stories Make Real News Headlines|last=Chang|first=Juju|date=November 29, 2016|accessdate=November 29, 2016|publisher=[[ABC News]]}}</ref> [[The Daily Beast]] reported on the popularity of Chacon's fictions being reported as if it were factual and noted pro-Trump [[Internet forum|message boards]] and YouTube videos routinely believed them.<ref name="chacon" /> In a follow-up piece Chacon wrote as a contributor for The Daily Beast after the 2016 U.S. election, he concluded those most susceptible to fake news were consumers who limited themselves to partisan media outlets.<ref name="chacon2" />
